Visited Hakone shrine because I had heard about it and seen the torii gate, so with time during the afternoon, I thought I would go an look. It's a shrine. Actually, out of the hundreds I've seen, I wouldn't recommend it as it is not particularly impressive (even with the torii

The shrine itself is a whole site that is nestled up the hillside - and really stunning. The path there from town is beautifully lined with lanterns and huge great cedars. Unusually (for me at least), it's still being built - and the new wings (in untreated wood) are stunning in
Good steps up and down the shrine. The gate is also placed in the lake. The shrine is a bit off from the main Tokaido historical road, but worth the visit.
Nice temple, most famous in the area. The highlight is the lake view at the bottom of the shrine. Steep walk up some steps, so be aware.
Can be seen from hakone pier but really not worth to take too much time there. Nothing much but has those tori gates.

This is a famous shrine at Hakone. It is very huge and mystic place. You should visit here if you come to Hakone. But, it gets very crowded around the beginning of the year because Japanese pray for their happiness of New year. We can get "Goshuin" (handwritten sign and stamp
This Shinto Shrine is similar to others in Japan but what is different is the setting. The lake and mountains with winds and mist just adds to its special sacredness.

Hakone shrine is just 15 mins walk away from Moto-Hakone pier stop. You will pass by 3 huge torii gates (2 from the pier stop) & finally reach the shrine. Climb to the top (a lot of stairs btw!) & give your prayers (good for fertility). & then walk down all the way down to the
Hakone shrine has a Long history and it is a beautiful place to visit. It is about 5-10 mins walk from Moto-Hakone boat pier. The hakone Shrine's lakefront torii is the best place to take pictures.

hakone is very famous and popular not only to Japanese but to foreigner too. nice to come in all season. best Autumn spring. too bad if stay only one night make it two or three there are too many things to see.not only hakone shrine.
Hakone Shrine sit in a nice quiet area, a little walking up the hill surround by trees and feel very peaceful. Good view of the lake Ashi
Had a very short time in hakone but wanted to see this. and its worth it. A v pleasant area . Would love to have more time to walk around the park. The trees there are v astounding.

The main shire is located on hillside away from Lake Ashino however you can see the first Tori gate as it sits on the shore of the lake One can reach the shrine by walking along the shore of the lake from the Motohakone stop if you are coming via ferry. However as you

Using the Hakone pass $4000. Took a train, cable car, rope way, boat ride, bus to see the sight of Hakone. Dropped off at the first boat stop Hakone tokaido walked to the Hakone Shrine passing the park and walked thru the cedar wood ave.
It's a very pretty shrine with a lot of history and atmosphere. It needs a short walk along the lake to get there but mostly you go through foliage. Lots of visitors but worth it.

With the Torii in the lake, the shrine itself is built around all the huge trees. Quite a staircase walk to the main shrine but it is worth going up. The shrine has a nine-dragon fountain for making wish.

The Hakone Shrine along Lake Ashi at Hakone-machi is a Shinto shrine. It has a historical significance as a place of worship for shoguns and samurais. The Tori of the Hakone shrine is on the shores of lake ashi and is symbolic. The shrine has a museum displaying many treasures.
It is a beautiful Japanese shrine. It is a highly photogenic place if you want photos that represent Japan. When you visit don't forget to do the "Omairi" which is the traditional praying.

The site on the picture is on one side of the road, but the actual shrine is across the road and a million steps up the hill. So if you have knee issues or just hate steps, keep the visit to the lower part, by the water. You can still get nice pictures, there are people
Visited here at 5am it was so peaceful and pure that I felt as though I was in a piece of literature.
This place is just stunning! Located right on Lake Ashi the shrine itself is beautiful and provides fabulous photo opportunites! Go here if you like nature and want to see great views of Mt. Fuji!

The red tori gate is a short walk from the third ferry boat stop we took on Lake Ashi. You can clearly see it as your boat comes in to dock. A short 10 minute walk should be enough to get you there. You can take the lower path closest to the lake or cross the road and take the

Such a fabulous shrine, it is a bit smaller than some other shrines but it is beautiful. I particularly liked the arch that overlooks Lake Ashi. Quite a few steps to the top, but lots to see on the way!
Nice shrine - especially with the gate at the lake. Try to sneak in between two chinese group tours.
There were always a few people waiting to take photos here but we didn't have to wait very long. The walk down to the shrine is very relaxing and pretty.

People visit this as a photo backdrop only and line up for a quick snap before moving on. Compared to others in the area it seems somewhat neglected with paint peeling off in numerous places. More information placing it within the history of the period would have been welcome.
A beautiful and peaceful spot with amazing scenery and plenty of places to stop to eat or drink. The lake views are amazing and the walk through the shrine and temple grounds are spectacular

Don't miss this relatively small but picturesque and historic sintoist shrine. The bright red temple gates on the lake add greatly memorable visual to beautiful Ashi lake. The shrine is about 10 minute walk from final cruise stop and the walk is up the mountain, the route is

Though we didn't view the Hakone Shrine up close, it makes its dramatic presence visible from many vantage points, most notably from Lake Ashi. However, you can see it as you descend the Ropeway and once you dock off the lake and walk around to the Old Tokaido Trail. You can't

Hakone Shrine is one of my favourite Shrine in Japan. Beautifully located on the lake Ashi side. Climbed few steps to reach to the top of the temple. The Shrine area surround with tress and very peaceful. From the Lake Ashi area you will not miss the Shrine because of the Tori

This shrine was quiet and chill despite many tourists visiting (both local and overseas). It's interesting to see many art students sketching and drawing the sceneries surrounding the shrine too. But I guess most people are here to take the amazing picturesque torii gate and

It's not as big as the Tori gate on Miyajima Island but it's also located in the water. Seeing this Tori gate, you definitely knew that you were still in Japan and not on some lake in the United States.

It is really a peaceful and beautiful place that you must absolutely see ! Around this main Tori, there are a lot of other temple and interesting things to see ! Really easy to access but at the same time you feel like you are far away from the civilisation !

this was the last spot we stopped at on a hakone day pass and the shrine, the scenery, location surpassed everything we had seen on the trip. it was a steep climb up the hill, but worth it to see the grand setting. it was so peaceful and beautiful.

In search of Hakone Shrine got an amazing view of Mt. Fuji. Dress warmly Lake Ashi is a crater formed from volcanic activity in close proximity to Mt. Fiji, the weather was warm at the beginning of the trip the closer we got to the mountain the colder it got. Beautiful shrine (
We enjoyed walking through the enormous cedars and seeing lovely natural gardens as well as the shrine itself. Fill your water bottle from the dragon fountain while you are there.

I took photos of this Tori gate at many angles. A great site for the perfect Japandse photo if the weather co-operates. With fog and rain the gate in water took on a mystical effect.The Lake Ashi area is a wonderful area to explore and come upon this shrine.
We took the pirate ship (Hakone Free pass) from the Cable cars to visit. It's a 15 minute walk from the ship dock but very picturesque.

Not far from the center this shrine is easy to access and the torii at the lakeside is beautiful. If you are lucky you can see the Torii and the Mt. Fuji behind it from the Motohakone Busstation next to the 7-Eleven

You've seen this a lot in pics and of course, you have to be here as well. It's a quick stroll with a nice view of Lake Ashi. A bit crowded and you have to line up to get a picture =) which is fine and orderly. You can come here before or after the Lake Ashi boat tour, takes

The shrine is not special and probably not something that you haven't seen before but if you're already near Ashi lake then I would recommend a visit. It's very close to the main road and has a nice view to the lake..
Great place to have a picture. The area is calming and quiet and the torii get is super interesting to look at.
Went here for a walk after visiting lake ashi by boat. This is a Nice place to walk through if you have the time, but it's not a must-visit-place. It's a short walk, so you will be quickly done.
We came across this shrine gate overlooking the lake as we ended our walk from Togendai along the lake. There was an orderly queue of people to take photos (and take photos of you too).

What a lovely peaceful setting this shrine is located at, slightly tricky to find but worth the effort. A gentle walk up the hill to a reasonable set of stairs with picture opportunities the whole time and opening up to a beautiful temple. On the walk down you are met by another
This is a lovely spot yo visit and is not to far from the main town, It is a lovely spot for pictures and was not to busy when we visited it.

We hoped to see a beautiful shrine at the side of Lake Ashi because some pictures of the torii was very nicely presented from the Lake. We were quite disappointed to see this rather small shrine with only a couple of buildings after almost a hundred steps up hill. We bought a

My day trip to Hakone was boring as it was rainy and windy for the whole day. I went to see the Hakone Shrine, which turned out to be a great decision. A quiet and lovely shrine hidden in the trees on the lake Ashi. It must be awesome to visit this shrine on a sunny day!

I went there in the morning where there is not many people around. Very calm and nice place to have your morning walk. Lots of stairs to climb and take it as morning exercise. I love the gate near the lake, spectacular
The trees are beautiful leading to the shrine and nice steps with trees on both sides leading up to the shrine. Afterwards you can stroll along the lake

very famous and good place to visit. the shrine is not bad, but not that amazing, but the torii is very uniqe, so good for taking photoes. they're many jinja together in an mountant ares, so maybe should visit from the upside to down side, will be more easy, and visit in morning
Beautiful shrine overlooking the lake. A must do if in Hakone. Peaceful walk and just stunningly scenic.
It's a little walk from the harbour and then there are steps to climb to get to the top of the shrine. The amulets are not translated into English so buying them requires some knowledge of Kanji .
My guide told us he didn't have baby for 10 years but once he prayed here his wife get pregnant. I am not sure its true or not ^^
I would t make a special trip to see this. It's worth a short walk if you have taken the boat across Lake Ashi

It is a very beautiful place to walk around in Hakone. We went there during early January. There were quite a lot of people lining to pray in the Shrine. We were in a rush so we didn't line up for the pray, but the Shrine is very nice and quiet. If you have time, I will
Long lines for the New Year's worship. There are beautiful trees surrounding the Hakone Shrine and street vendors offer food to people coming to line up to do worship.

If outdoor and nice photo shots is what you are looking for. This place is nice for photo shots.. popular to locals and tourist. Shrine is busy preparing new year so many Tentage is blocking the path.

The shrine sits beside a lake with views of Mt Fuji and connects well to a nearby temple. Worthwhile visit and good to pair with seeing other nearby shrines or the onsen (hot springs) about a 30 minute bus journey away.
The area was really beautiful and has lots of paths to walk around and explore. There's an area by the water and then up the hill there is the rest of the shrine.

Beautiful and peaceful. Scenic, lush greenery, combined with beautiful architecture. Temple was undergoing some expansion when I visited, but still a good place to take in the beauty and serenity of ancient Japan.
Made it just in time after the boat ride across the Lake to watch the sunset. Great location to watch the sun set over the lake.

We visited Hakone on a cold rainy day and this place was magical. The shrine up the hill was shrouded in clouds and mist while the torii gate at the bottom overlooked lake Ashi was the perfect spot to sit and take it all in. This shrine was quieter then the rest but was very

You can see this torii gate on the Lake Ashi cruise, beside it there is a smaller torri gate. Its a pretty far walk from the cruise station, took us about 30min from where we alighted after taking the cruise from the Hakone ropeway. However, along the way we walked past
Very pretty and right on Lake Ashi. The views from the shore were amazing and the lake cruse past right by the picture you see in the review.
Very nice and cozy place around this area. Beautiful shrine surrounded by nature and trees. You can walk around the small town in moto-hakone with plenty of small shops for gift and food.

during my first visit, it was misty, i couldnt find the red tori. During my second visit, we got there early in the morning. it was really beautiful and walked in, then i realized, that u can actually drive into the shrine area and park. It should be free parking too. Do
A couple getting married...what a wonderful photo opportunity for a slice of Japanese culture. Great
I lived in Japan for 2 years this is nothing but an ordinary shrine. Maybe good for tourists who visited japan first time.
Too many shrines, temples, monasteries. This was okay, but it was a long way out of the way and, for me at least, not worth the time.

It's a Shinto Shrine by Lake Ashi. I am into photography and it's just the most amazing place for beautiful photos. Even if you are not into photography or spiritual stuff this place is still worth a visit (otherwise why are you visiting Japan?). It's on the must-see list if you

Walking to the shrine alongthe lake is almost mystical. The shrine gate in Lake Ashi is lit, and very beautiful at dusk. it is especially nice viewed from the village with Fuji behind it. Postcard material.
A nice little shrine in Hakone with beautiful pathways and architecture as you would expect in Japan. Not super crowded which means you can actually feel the serenity at the shrine.

It is very scenic around the lake. You can take a bus from Hakone-Yumoto to Moto Hakone then on to Hakone. Outdoor activity still ch as pedal boats and boat rides around the lake. Great summer/warm weather activity. Although, when we went, it was quite chilly. The boats were

After our one night stay in Hakone onsen hotel, we decided to drive up to here and spend a morning strolling around, taking photos and enjoy lunch by the water at the nice cafes. If you have time when visiting Hakone, be sure to spend some time here. Lovely Photos taken.

This is peaceful and in a beautiful setting. There were a dozen or so tourists who were taking photos at the shrine but that was useful as there was someone to take a photo of when my boyfriend proposed to me!

Honestly, I think people come here to visit the torii gate that sites in Lake Ashi, more so than the shrine itself. It's a few minute walk if you get off the Hakone Tozan bus route at Moto-Hakone - walk towards the water and then turn right. Find the red torii gates and walk

We visited the shrine in the late afternoon. It was crowded but worth the 20-min walk from Moto-Hakone Port. I'm partial to forest shrines and this one had lots of big, lovely old trees in addition to the famous torii on the lake. This is a shrine worth visiting, even if

Truly a piece of quintessential Japan: ancient, peaceful, beautiful, balanced, meditative, the list goes on. My family and I weren't on any guided tours so after being dropped off by a Lake Ashi ship we made our way over to the Shrine which took us through a serene wooded
Visited here as the sun was setting. Very quiet and peaceful once you move away from the buses. A light does also come on at night but the walk path can still be quite dark.
Hakone Shrine is culture pure and you have to clean yourself with the water in a special way. Don't miss to go to the lake / pier.

Visited Lake Ashi with Friends on a rainy and foggy day, with ideas of seeing Fuji. Unfortunately, we weren't able to see the mountain, but Ashi and and the Kuzuryu shrine more than made up for it. The surrounding forest is like something out of another world, and the shrine
Nice place to relax and enjoy some peace and quiet. Not really much to see, but if you want a day away from dynamic life of big cities such as Tokyo, then this is place to come and reflect.
Traditional shrine set on a hill overlooking a lake. Very beautiful setting, and very beautiful shrine. Be sure to walk down to the lake!
Very nice spot for an hour or two on the lake side. If you are in Hakone you should visit here. Adequate parking if you're driving, reasonable public transport if you're not.
I stayed there for two days and I recommend the ship which goes down the river for everyone who goes to Hakone.

Hakone is a lovely sight seeing town only a short train ride away from Tokyo and I enjoyed it so much! In January we even managed to catch the snow scenery which we did not expect to see as most photos of Hakone that we saw in brochures and on the Internet were taken in Summer.

This is certain a great offshoot if you are visiting Kuzuryu Shrine. I would suggest doing this during Sunset which is worth the selfie picture. Be warn it could be crowded as many visitors would have the same idea.

It took us about 2 hrs to get here, We took a train, tram, cable car, bus and a boat and then walked for 15 mins to this shrine and it was worth every minute. Great place for a beautiful photo memory of our time in Japan.
worth the trip just to see the beautiful torii gate rising from the lake! 2 minute walk from hakone machi take a photo under the gate

The view of the Torri gate from the lake is breaktaking, we took the paddling boat by the pier at 1,500 yen for 30 mins and paddled our way near the gate to take pics, it was a great experience for the kids, from there we had bakery and coffee at a lovely three-storey

Hakone Shrine is definitely a "no go item", must visit place when you're visiting Hakone! Till now, I am still wondering how they actually came out with the idea to build such a big gate in front of the lake, and not to forget to visit their temple as well.
Very quaint temple and you got to visit it when you are at the lake. It can be accessed by foot or by car. Walking up the steps can be slightly tiring for older folks but it should be fine.
The area is so beautiful and serene. The weather is misty and cool. The architecture is just pretty. I would return to visit again.
Hakone Shrine stands at the foot of Mount Hakone along the shores of Lake Ashi. The shrine buildings are hidden in dense forest, its location given away only by the temple's hugh torii gates.

This temple exceeds my expectations from what I read in travel books. When I arrived I had to walk a long flight of stairs up to the temple. The temple is situated inside a forest and is covered by layers of mist. Adds a special sense of tranquility and holiness. At the

A MUST see, if you can then wall down to the shrine while the tide is out, then wait for the tide to come in and admire the beauty. I would recommend walking up to the rope way station the park with its small red Japanese bridges is very nice. The rope way and walk up the

The shrine is very lovely and the walk up to the top of the shrine is pleasant. This shrine was not especially crowded the day I visited, adding to its beauty. The setting is really pretty and it is possible to enjoy both from the top and close to the lake.

Walk from the boat to this beautiful shrine and take a good look around the grounds, walk down to the water and follow the path around the lake , truly wonderful, while I was there I was lucky to witness a young man propose marriage,a lovely experience in a stunning location.

I first read about Hakone Shrine on JapanGuide and saw how beautiful the torii gate looked across from the river. On the day that we had planned for Hakone, it was raining and terribly foggy. The view across from the river was so-so with low visibility. However, the main shrine

This Shrine is located closed Ashinoko lake. If you see from lake side, you can see beautiful viewing. Torii (Gateway to Shinto shrine), Lake, Sightseen boat, Fuji mountain. In side of shrine, there are many trees, calm air. It's solemn atmosphere.

We took the ferry and saw this Shrine from afar, it is large and impressive but then the whole island is lovely. Beware eating near the deer as these deer are not wild and frightened of humans but see them as a meal ticket and will actually jump up to steal your food bought
Loving this place so much. A peaceful place where you can see the beauty of Ashi Lake. Super huge gate making u feel tiny. Perfect.

This place is worth a visit if you are able to find the location. It is nicely hidden at a corner.Once you are able to locate it, you will amazed by its beauty. Prayers are done here with lots of charms available for purchase. Do drop for a short prayer or wish making.

A site worth the visit. Before heading up we ate at the diner near the carpark which had the best noodle soup ever for 850 yen. Dont miss it. Shrine is definitely worth the visit if you're in the area. Dont be daunted by the stairs, elderly ladies were getting up there at their

An easy walk from the Moto Hakone Pirate Ship Pier. You can see the shrine from the shore, so just walk that direction. The path was peaceful and enjoyable despite it being a cool and cloudy day. We did this as one of our first stops from Tokyo, so enjoyed the peaceful scenery.
A nice little temple with an interesting history behind it. It's a 15 min. walk from the pier and there are some nice restaurants on the way to Jinja shrine
If you decide to go to Lake Ashi then visit this Shrine. Not much to do on the lake except for taking pictures of the view and this shrine.
The walking street from the main road to Shrine is nice! A street with trees along at both sides. A good spot for photographing!
It is small Tori, similar to the one in Miyajima but at a smaller scale. I saw it from a boat I took at the ropeway station. It looks nice. I did not have enough time to visit it after disembarking.

We went to Hakone and visited Kuzuryu Shrine Singu. You can spot it easily from the boat (if you decide to take the cruise around Asahi river). After the boat experience, you can have a nice walk around moto hakone and see the others two Torii in the town until you end in Hakone

You can see the Tori of Hakone shrine from the boat. The temple is atop a small hill. The walk is nice and you need to climb a flight of stairs to reach the shrine. Once you are at top it is all peace and calm. When we visited it was already evening so hardly anybody was there.

Like a mini Miyajima if you don't have the time to go there. Be prepared to wait in a short line to take pictures underneath the gate. The walk (about 15 mins) is great to stretch your legs after all the different transport you take on the round trip. The trees provide lots of

After visiting Senso Ji and Zojo Ji in Tokyo city, this temple is so peaceful in comparison. It has beautiful grounds and towering trees. Some of them are sacred trees and you can tell by the ropes tied around them. There are many many many many stairs... So we initially

This is a really beautiful Shinto shrine on the shores of Lake Ashi, in Hakone. You cannot see Mt. Fuji from the shrine itself, but if you walk down to the shore of the lake to see the beautiful peace torii standing there, you can walk along the shore to a point where the
Its a beautiful monument but not worth the hike/car ride since you can see this from the Asi river cruise. There is nothing else to do there.
Nice, but not like Miyajima... Beautiful to look from the boat-ride. It is quite impressive, but would do it, only if you have a spare time.

The shrine was nice but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it again. There's always lots of people around and that kind of kills any charm or feel this shrine had. If you're already in the area you may as well stop to see it, if not I wouldn't bother.
There was something simple majestic and beautiful about the simplicity of this shrine, especially when visited at dusk.

The area is heavy with tourists and students on day trips but well worth a visit. Stay after the day people have gone for an extra special experience. Beware if you stay too late. There is very little food available. Quiet comes with a price!
We saw this shrine (one of many) from a boat. I had read about it and how at certain tides it appears to be floating. A lovely sight as you sail over to the island.

Take the path under the torii and lined with red lanterns. Don't be daunted by all the steps up to the shrine. If you need to there are rest spots on the way up. Male sure you wander off the path to look at smaller shines on the way up. There is such beauty and serenity
Not very well maintained. It is in a scenic setting, follows a path along the river. Easy to walk to from MotoHakone and pirate ship

Its a 20 mins walk from Hakone En. We loved the walk and you will see some or the other standing near the Tori gate taking a picture. It stands very tall and it commands a picture from you. Do not miss if you visit Hakone.

The Torii Gate rising from the lake is the entrance too a beautiful temple complex hidden within a mature Cedar forest. It is an easy walk from the Markone bus stop along the lakefront, then just as end the steep granite steps that are flanked by huge Cedar trees to reach the

Hakone shrine is a 20 min walk from Moto-Hakone pier. The walk to the shrine is an easy and gentle stroll along the banks of Lake Ashi. Arriving at the big red Torri gate that stands between land and water and you have arrived at the foot of Hakone shrine. After seeing many

We went with a taxi driver as there is not much to do in area especially without a car. He was so gracious spent time waiting, then showing us the shrine, telling us the history and little things as well as taking photo's of all of us. Would definitely spend time visiting
This floating red shrine on the Lake Ashi is possibly the most picturesque site on the entire Hakone.

The big orange Gate to this Shrine is actually in Lake Ashi, and is visible from the pirate ship cruising across the lake. It'll crop up in various photos. Otherwise, the Shrine is a relatively sort walk from town. There are many steps - as it's uphill from the lake's edge. If
Although this temple is not so impressive as the temples in the Kamakura or Nara area it is worhwile to visit if you have an hour to spend in the area. The nature around is nice and quiet.

Beautiful temple reached by a path through a cedar forest. A lot of nice Moss covered rocks along the way. Unique red color for the structures. Old samurai location turned shrine. The floating torii gate is very unique.

The Shinto Shrine Gate is as impressive in person as it is in pictures, the shrine itself is some steps up and hidden in the woods. It is a very short distance - about 5-10 minutes' walk by on a clearly marked path from MotoHakone.
A beautiful walk up to the temple among large beautiful trees! Worth the walk from the ferry terminal.
Had a wonderful time in Lake Ashi and Hakone Shrine. Very calm and peaceful, good vibes to carry away. Beautiful and scenic place, amazing for photography. Very recommended.
The huge red gate stood out from the murky lake water. It was pretty impressive to see from up close and afar. We looked so small standing underneath it.

If you love Dori like I do, seeing one just in the water is just breathtaking. This one is near the Hakone Shrine. The shrine itself is quite a few steps up and is not for the faint hearted. But worth the visit.
One of the only two toriis that are built over water. The other's in Hiroshima. Unique sight. When weather's fine, it's said that Fuji Mountain can be seen.
This is a fabulous area - there are sons magnificently tall trees, the shrine is beautiful and there's a lovely calm air to the whole place. I'm really glad we went.

The shrine is very popular with both oversea tourist and locals. If you've never experienced Japanese shrine, you can't really go wrong with Hakone Shrine in the forest. Very peaceful (when the crowd isn't too bad) with a fantastic view of Lake Ashi.

While traveling on one of the three Pirate ships that cross the lake, you can see this small version of the tori at Miyajima. The ship stops at three locations around the lake. Our three day Hakone pass allowed us to ride the ship as much as we wanted.
Nice place to quietly look at the lake. Then Go to the opposite way & give Hakone Jinja shrine a visit.
honestly we are not very impressed with the boat trip. probably because the ropeway is not fully opened.
So serene and beautiful! Time seems to sit still here. Great escape from the western culture, much needed at times.
A red Tori standing in the water...with Chinese tourists in Donald duck waterboats haha. Seriously. Looked more like the Shinto Disney parc to me.
It's a beutiful temple surrounded by huge old trees. It's easy to walk there, although you need to walk by the road for a bit. On a warmer day it's probably great to walk down by the water as well

From the pier, Hakone Shrine is about a 5-10 min walk. Its a great place to visit and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere. The Shrine isn't too large, so it should not take more than an hour there including taking photos etc. The highlights will be at the main temple of at the Shrine
Popular spot for photos, a pretty good place for a scenic view. People were queuing up to take photos of the shrine so it will be better if you go there early
This shrine is impressive with all the history and the lakes surrounding it. The are different routes you can take to access it. We took the boat across the lake and then wandered around.

Like taking a step into the past (if you ignore the visitors in modern clothes). It's architecture is beautiful, and its cultural heritage are a good read. It is located at Lake Ashi, which itself is a surreal place... It amazed me at how human structures can co-exist with so

If you are in Hakone-machi, before taking the ferry for the cruise in the lake, I definitely recommend to go to the shrine, is an easy 5 minutes walk from the ferry terminal and the shrine is very suggestive

The scenery is what does it - yet again. The walk up there is an unforgettable experience. You can see Mt Fuji from here at certain times of the year. The downside is that it takes a while to get here via public transport (bus or train- they both take ages). At night the only

If you love dragons definitely visit this shrine. They have many beautiful dragon statues here. The gate is a wonderful spot for a family photo! The scenery and feeling of this shrine is just something you should experience

This is Hakone's "big day out"- the pirate ship ferry ride around the lake to the villages. These places were so run down our opinion was - stay on the ferry. Ordinary food, dismal towns and attractions badly in need of repair. Forget it.

Took the gorgeous walk from the cruise boat stop to the Shrine and enjoyed the native rainforest style walk that led us there. Some beautiful views of Lake Ashi and clearly signposted explanations of the cultural significance of the site in English.

Visited Hakone on a coach trip from Tokyo, just spent the day in the area and loved it. The area around the shrine is simply lovely. The air has a refreshing quality - especially after a week in Tokyo! The surrounding forest is fantastic, with some huge and ancient trees. The
Nice little shrine surrounded by wild greenery is in the Hakone area, we got witness to a couple that took their weeding photos they where very nicely dressed etc.

What could be a quiet and calm spiritual place is in fact crammed with noisy day trippers and tourists jostling to take photos. Severe danger of being impaled by a selfie stick. If you want to really enjoy this part of Hakone, hire a pedalo or a row boat and escape the hoards on
The shrine was exactly as you'd expect, well maintained and full of nature. The views from the shrine over the lake were spectacular though! Made for a beautiful walk.

From Togendai, around 20-25minutes on foot. You can walk, pass the deck view to see Mt Fuji, walk thru Cedar Avenue then pass many restaurant before seeing the gate. I arrived in the evening so not many people around and it was perfect. So peaceful though it got dark so fast

text.wiki:
Hakone (箱根町, Hakone-machi) is a town in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. As of June 2012, the town had an estimated population of 13,492, and a population density of 145 persons per km². The total area is 92.82 km2 (35.84 sq mi). Hakone has been designated as a Japanese National Geopark by the Japanese Geoparks Network.
Hakone is to a great degree regarded as a traveler destination; Mt. Fuji can be seen when taking a day trip from Tokyo. In addition to hot springs, museums and other recreation activities, Hakone is known for its scenery during all four seasons.


== Geography ==
Hakone is located in the mountains in the far west of the prefecture, on the eastern side of Hakone Pass. Most of the town is within the borders of the volcanically active Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, centered on Lake Ashi.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture

Odawara
Yugawara
Minami-ashigaraShizuoka Prefecture

Gotemba
Susono
Mishima
Oyama
Kannami


== History ==
Hakone is the location of a noted Shinto shrine, the Hakone Gongen, which is mentioned in Heian period literature. During the Genpei War, Minamoto no Yoritomo prayed at this shrine for victory over his enemies, after his defeat at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, which was fought in neighboring Manazuru. As with the rest of Sagami Province, the area came under the control of the later Hōjō clan of Odawara during the Sengoku period. After the start of the Edo period, Hakone-juku was a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto. It was also the site of a major barrier and official checkpoint on the route known as the Hakone Checkpoint (箱根関所, Hakone sekisho), which formed the border of the Kantō region. Under the Tokugawa shogunate, all travellers entering and leaving Edo along the Tōkaidō were stopped here by officials. Their travel permits and baggage were examined to enforce Tokugawa laws that restricted the travel of women and weapons.
After the start of the Meiji Restoration, Hakone became a part of the short-lived Ashigara Prefecture before becoming part of Ashigarashimo District in Kanagawa prefecture in August 1876. Hakone attained town status in 1889. The imperial household established the summer Hakone Imperial Villa close to the lake.
After merger with five neighboring towns and villages in September 1956, it reached its present boundaries.


== Economy ==

The economy of Hakone is strongly dominated by the tourist industry. Hakone is noted for its onsen hot spring resorts, which attract both Japanese and international visitors, due to its proximity to the greater Tokyo metropolis and to Mount Fuji. Sights include the volcanically active Ōwakudani geysers and Hakone Shrine on the shore of the lake, as well as the Hakone Botanical Garden of Wetlands. In April the cherry blossoms (sakura) and in autumn the Miscanthus sinensis (susuki) are noted sights.
Hakone has a number of art museums, including the Hakone Open-Air Museum and Pola Museum of Art.
Major events include the annual JLPGA CAT Ladies Golf tournament and the Hakone Ekiden, a long distance collegiate foot race, held at the New Year, which runs from Tokyo to Hakone and back over two days, partly in commemoration of the couriers who ran the Tōkaidō road.
One famous hotel in Hakone is the historic Fujiya Hotel in Miyanoshita, which was patronized by noted literary figures, politicians and foreign dignitaries in the Meiji and Taishō and early Shōwa periods.
A noted local handicraft is a kind of marquetry called Yosegi.Hakone is also well-known among anime fans for being the main location in the manga and anime series Neon Genesis Evangelion, in which it has been renamed Tokyo-3, and there are numerous attractions related to the franchise offered in the town. In 2017, Hakone was included as one of 88 anime pilgrimage sites for 2018 by the Anime Tourism Association. In 2020, new decorations have been introduced to the city in the anticipation of the release of the final film of the Rebuild of Evangelion tetralogy.


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
Hakone Tozan Railway
Hakone Tozan Cable Car
Hakone Ropeway
Izuhakone RailwayOdawara and Mishima, the terminus of the Odakyū Odawara Line, 70 minutes from Shinjuku, Tokyo. From Odawara, the Hakone Tozan Line continues into various resort towns in Hakone. Odakyu also runs the Romancecar limited express between Shinjuku and Hakone-Yumoto. From Gōra, the terminus of Hakone Tozan Line, the Hakone Tozan Cable Car funicular goes to Sōunzan. Ōwakudani can be reached by Hakone Ropeway from Sounzan and the lake, while the lake is crisscrossed by cartoonishly decorated "pirate" ships for tourists. There is also Hakone Komagatake Ropeway, which goes to the top of Mount Komagatake.
A popular "Hakone Free Pass", allowing unlimited use of most forms of transport for several days, is available. Hakone Free Pass can be bought at Shinjuku Station, Odawara Station, any other chief station along Odakyū Odawara Line, Hakone-Yumoto Station, Gōra Station, any other chief station along Hakone Tozan Line, Sōunzan Station, Tōgendai Station, Sengoku-Annaijo Bus Stop, Moto-Hakone Port, Hakone-Machi Port, and JR Gotemba Station Bus Information.


=== Highways ===
Hakone Shindō
Japan National Route 1
Japan National Route 138


== Education ==
Private schools:

Kanrei Shirayuri Gakuen Junior/Senior High School


== Sister cities ==
 - Tōyako, Hokkaidō, since July 4, 1964
 - Jasper, Alberta, Canada from July 4, 1972
 - Taupo, New Zealand, from October 7, 1987
 - St. Moritz, Switzerland, from November 2, 2014 (Friendship City)

text.quote: Edo-era military checkpoint featuring soldiers' quarters, a lookout, a tea room & more.
google: A beautiful reproduction of the checkpoint and village setting.  It has a great little museum before the village with some great history and artifacts.  The village is complete with mannequins displaying normal daily life and there are …

We went here on a rainy day in spring. So it was rather cold. But still worth the visit. 
The recreated scenes and architecture gave a glimpse of   the past. It also reminded of most things that seem to remain in their culture to this date. …
Fun and interesting way to use up some time while waiting for the pirateship ferry. It's pretty quick and small so some people might not think it worth the cost, but we enjoyed it.

Beautiful exhibition and excellent restoration of old buildings. One feels like back in the old times where Hakone was used as a checkpoint for travelers to and from Edo. The area in general is very enjoyable to walk around as well! Absolutely recommended.
Beautiful view, you can see two islands when looking far away forward

They've done a wonderful job of recreating the checkpoint.  One word of warning, is that it isn't large, so it's best to visit as part of an overall trip to the area.

Very interesting museum, with various models, displaying the history of Hakone Takaido Checkpoint. You can also  enjoy beautiful view of the lake and pirate ship here. Nice place to visit as part of your Hakone tour.

Great stop to make - although it doesn't take long to see it. Note that there is a nice overlook of the lake if you are willing to climb the steps.

text.wiki:
The Museum of The Little Prince in Hakone (星の王子さまミュージアム, Hoshi no Ōjisama Myūjiamu) (French: Musée du Petit Prince de Saint-Exupéry à Hakone) is a museum in Sengokuhara, Hakone, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.  The museums is dedicated to the character in the story The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry.


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website
Official website (in Japanese)
text.quote: Cheerful museum honoring the 100th anniversary of the book, "The Little Prince," & its author.

Interesting small museum close to Hakone Highland hotel. Should be visited if you with kids in this area to introduce this famous book and get taste of French townscape and garden.

text.wiki:
Ōwakudani (大涌谷, lit. "Great Boiling Valley") is a volcanic valley with active sulphur vents and hot springs in Hakone, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. It was created around 3,000 years ago, as a result of the explosion of the Hakone volcano.It is a popular tourist site for its scenic views, volcanic activity, and kuro-tamago (黒卵, lit. "black egg") — a local specialty of eggs hard-boiled in the hot springs. The eggs turn black and smell slightly sulphuric; eating one is said to add seven years to your life.Upon seeing the hellish scenery, when Koubu Daishi visited Owakudani more than a thousand years ago, he offered prayer to Bodhisattva. The Enmei-jizo in Owakudani is said to have its origin in the prayer.


== Access ==
Access to Ōwakudani is via a funitel, the Hakone Ropeway (Ōwakudani Station), or a bus line from Odawara Station, Hakone-Yumoto Station, Kowakidani Station / Kojiri, the Izuhakone Bus (Ōwakudani Bus Stop). There is a road to a visitor's center just below the Kuro-tamago hot springs site.
Most visitors used to hike the roughly 1 km (0.62 mi) trail (which has been closed since 2015 due to increased volcanic activity) or take the Hakone Ropeway to close to where the eggs are boiled to participate in the ritual egg eating. The funitel offers a vast view of Mount Fuji (on clear days) and the sulphur vents just below the visitor's center.
Present day activities surrounding sulphur vents are the result of massive land slides in the past. Construction of concrete barriers and stabilization of the area have been under way for decades.


== Closure ==
The tourist site in Ōwakudani was closed in May 2015 due to volcanic activity. It re-opened on April 27, 2016, but not fully, as it is not possible to walk close to the steaming vents due to the hazards involved. People with asthma, bronchitis, heart disease, heart pacemakers, and pregnant women are advised not enter the valley because of high volcanic activity.


== References ==

Yes we stopped here during our Hakone Trip and had a good look around shops that sell mainly touristic items due to where it is - so many items sold relating to the infamous black sulphur cooked eggs that allegedly add 7 years to your life

While visiting the area we stopped here to have lunch and also get out of the weather, unfortunately it was raining and foggy the day we visited. Very good selection of food to choose from and also spent some time in the gift shop which was close by.
We went as part of a tour with Izumi, the great grayline tour guide. It is a good experience and you have to try the famous black eggs.

In my opinion a trip to Hakone without eating a kuro tamago (black egg) would be incomplete. This place is easily accessible by the local bus, and about 15 minutes from the downtown train station. Here you can buy souvenirs, and also the real black egg. They sell a bag of 5
google: The sulfur spilling down the hillside with vents all around was a blast to see (and ride over on the gondola). There's a bunch of neat foods to try like black meat buns, black ice cream which melts VERY fast, egg ice cream which is a …
Just went there to eat "Kuro Tamago" (black egg). it has been said that this egg will extend  your life 5~7 years.. Natural scenic views are also good. But suggestion would be to visit in clear day.

This is a very interesting place where you can see that the Hakone mountain is active. It was very windy and I didn't smell sulfur when I went there. It's also a great place to go when Tokyo is too hot to handle in summer.
Such a cool place! Riding the ropeway and eating black eggs are a must.
This place is amazing. Great views, great for pictures. If the weather is good you can see Mt. Fuji really well.
A very interesting place geologically, and the fact you can be so close to the volcano. Recommend at least half an hour at a bare minimum.
Nice place to see Live Volcano, unfortunately when I went that time it was closed to go outside since toxic level was high so I could not enjoyed the Black Eggs. Must visit place definately.
One of the best spots to visit in Japan !! The black eggs, charcoal ice cream, warm milk on top of the hill will surely make you estatic !!
If you don't mind the sulfur smell the place is amazing. Great black eggs (buy the freshly build not the packaged ones) and a great view of mount fuji.

Owakudani is realy mysterious place!!🗾
The smell is crazy, but to be expected from a volcanic crater. 
Great place!

Probably the most beautiful view of Mount Fuji can be seen from up here. If you get a day pass for the rooeways, buses and the tourist ships it’s nice to come up here even twice on the same day as the light changes and so does Mount Fuji. …

The view of Owakudani as seen from the observatory gets powerful full marks. The desolate mountain skin and the rolling plumes of smoke create a unique landscape that will convince you of the area which was once called Jigokudani. There are …

This place was a totally different experience for me. I had never seen any active volcanic crater before. there was smoke coming out of the mountain. Moreover, the smell makes it unique. They sell black eggs near the place. The view is also very nice from the top. I saw mount fuji directly from the black egg statue.

Whoa...this was very cool. Definitely a must see if you are in Hakone, however it can be hard to get to if the cable car is down. Still something you should see! Also try the black eggs. Eggs boiled in water from this volcanic valley that …

I had a great experience visiting Owakudani, it very was scenic and peaceful. A true representation of how beautiful rural Japan is. 

I took the cable car up the mountain from Lake Ashi, once you reach there, you are taken by suprise, not …

A must visit if you are in Hakone. A wonderful view when on the cable car to the site. Mt Fuji can be seen on a clear day. The place smells but what do you expect! Eat an onsen egg and extend your life by 7 years... or so the legend says.

Amazing scenic view of mount Fuji, Owakudani also famous with the black boiled eggs. If you were around the Hakone, this place is really good for spending time. There is a souvenir shop on this place with a various product from the local available.
Very interesting place to view Fuji San amazing sites and smells and the black eggs were delicious

If you don't mind the smell of sulfur sometimes blowing in your face or the general very high wind blowing then this is an otherwise great place to visit. Watching the steam bellow out is mesmerizing and has a great view of the surrounding …
Beautiful place for hangout.
Nice place to visit.

This is a very nice place to visit in Hakone. This is a valcanic valley. the day I visited, it was covered with fog and slightly drizzling. Here you can buy black eggs! eggs boiled in hot sulfur spring. Locals say, if you eat one black egg, 7 years is added to your life.There are active sulfuric geysers in this area.

A great place to visit in Japan. try eating a Black egg.
Its nutritious they said...
Awesome, awesome awesome!  The smell is crazy, but to be expected from a volcanic crater.  Great place to see nature in its sulfuric element.  Truly awe inspiring!

The hakone travel pass got us from Gotemba by bus to Hakone. Then walk a little bit to the ropeway. That takes you here. Amazing display of the anger of nature. The roaring plumes of noxious sulfur steam shoot out of the ground. Supposedly …

Breath taking view... Awesome loved it... It's huge and nice place to see the Japan's volcano only the smell was a bit....difficult but overall it was awesome experience with kids or family or friends!!

A great place to visit. You can see volcanic activity while eating a black boil egg (eggs boil on hot volcanic hot spring). The trip is well worth it. On your way up do not forget to stop by the Ninja cafe. :)

Wonderful place to explore - ended up spending an hour instead of the original schedule of 15mins. Nice shops to do some shopping, some food stalls around too. The best part would be to see Mt Fuji!
Try to come earlier in the morning as the clouds tend to shroud and cover the peak by noon time.

Unfortunately the hiking paths were all closed while they are securing them. It was cool to get there though. The place is famous for the back eggs which color is explained by the sulfuric hot water from the Vulcano used to cook them. The …

Nice view of the surrounding mountains. Make sure you go up there on a sunny day, otherwise there's nothing to see. There's a carpark, cost 600 yen. Better get there early on busy days as the number of car parking spaces are quite limited.

Must see! 4 stars because the mountain train was under repair due to earlier typhoon damage. Last time I came taking the mountain train it was very very nice great view, train maneuvered through the wooded area, trees and flowers all the …

Absolutely amazing views (when it's a clear day) being so close to an active volcano is awesome and scary, but a definite must see. Bit of a trek to get there but worth it, the black eggs and black ice cream and yum (just not together lol) the mini museum is definitely worth a visit to get some history on the area

Is super cold and windy today when I go up to the hill. Luckily the sky is clear and you may see Fuji Mountain. Otherwise, is difficult to take a look on it. You may visit here and get a “black egg” or “volcano egg” as a gift.

If the hike's closed, it's pointless visiting. We went early on a Sunday, queued in traffic for around 30 minutes and paid only to discover that access to the volcano/sulphur area was closed. We left after 5 minutes as there was nothing else to do so be careful when visiting here
Nice view & cool place, I'm very happy to visit this place as a trainees of FALIA201905

Came for their black eggs which is their Sulphur vent cooked eggs. The eggs do have a unique flavour of a slight bitterness. I recommend to try it at least once if you are traveling. it's a tourist spot although you can see minijg operations ongoing to mine the sulphur from the vents. Note that sulphur stains the ground yellow

The place is breathtaking in two meanings. Really strong sulfur evaporations, so it must be hard to look around without mask if you have respiratory disease. But at the same time, its cool scenery and tasty black egg. Geo museum must help …
Loved seeing the beautiful views of the town for early Sunday to the afternoon. The atmosphere and scenery is stunning the black eggs just so much fun to explore the moment.

Wonderful!!
KUROTAMAGO(boiled egg) good!!
Very interesting place, The black eggs are pretty good, they taste just like a regular boiled egg, but the yolk seems a little richer than usual.

Other than the Sulfur smell (rotten egg), the place is beautiful! You can even eat some black eggs here too. These are eggs have turned that colour from cooking in the Sulfur infused water of the volcano. You can even see some breathtaking views of My Fuji if you go on a clear day.
Overall, a great place to visit for sightseeing! However, the smell of sulfur is a bit too strong. Also the black egg's taste is exactly the same as a regular boiled egg.

Great volcanic area. Shame the routes to walk Futher were closed. Great sights, if you manage to get good weather. I would advise using the train and tram transports to get up as the buses can be really delayed. Really good museum for only 100 yen each well worth it for some great insight and history.

Great place to view Mt.Fuji. This is a place around the volcanic crator. You can see some fumes and gases. There is a ropeway which you can take to have a better view of the place. Don't miss eating the black eggs boiled in the hot springs.

I really enjoyed my visit here. As other people recommended, you should try the black eggs that are sold not far from the ropeway station, just a walk down the street. There's also amazing views of Mt. Fuji too. There's definitely a strong smell of sulfur here but don't let that prevent you from visiting!

Another ‘must-see’ places in Hakone. It’s quite smelly but quite unique place. I can recommend to check the advisory first before going there as they sometimes close the area due to increase volcanic activity.

The valley is so cool. The ropeway is a fun experience. The lines move very fast. If you just want to go to the valley, you only need a round trip to owakadani. No need to go all the way to the lake, unless you want to see that too. Getting there is an adventure. What a great day.
Nice ropeway ride with two stops.  A bit cold though but with great view and some smoke from the volcanic rocks. With little shops and you should try their signature egg
Caught a public bus here.  Nice place.  Ate the black egg which apparently adds 7 yrs to your lifespan.  Short queues. Great photo ops. Recommended if are in Hakone.

Great view of mountain Fuji when there isn’t much crowd. Definitely recommend. You should also try their signature black eggs(even though there is not much difference with normal eggs in terms of the taste) 😅😅😅

Amazing place in October. Amazing weather and beautiful landscape. We were in a hotel nearby. This mountain is just beautiful we had to take a ski lift to get up. Once you are up there are many shops with good food and cool things to buy. …

This area was incredible to visit. Riding the gondola up was very fun and if it is not cloudy or foggy out, there is a great view of Mount Fuji! The blackened sulphur eggs were also quite the treat and experience.

Definitely a tourist trap, but they make the most of it by offering some unique experiences. We enjoyed the black eggs, but unfortunately due to the weather we were unable to see most of the volcanic activity or scenery. This is not their …

With a view on the Mount Fuji, you can enjoy a nice walk in nature and hot spring sources. Be careful, it is really cold and can be difficult to access! You can also eat their famous eggs, cooked in hot spring water. Very tasty!
I enjoyed riding in the cable car! Such a nice view

Breadth taking views, including on Mount Fuji on a clear day. The lunar landscape is a real treat for the eyes and somewhat unexpected. It is really easy to get there from Hakone station and is ideal pit stop for a day trip from Osaka or …
Great view of Fuji-san on a clear day, the volcanic activity feels strong.

Seeing the steam escape from fissures along the mountain, reminds you that you are on a volcano!  That being said, the ride in a gondola provides a wonderful view!  Once at the top, gift stores abound. It is worth a visit, if only to eat a black egg!

Super cold up here at times. Especially whwn the wind is blowing. The path was closed when we came, only able to just hang around the restaurant and took some pictures of the sulphuric vents. Oh, and enjoying the warm black eggs as well.

Stopped at Owakudani on the way to Lake Ashi on the Hakone ropeway. The sulfur mine and landscape is unreal. Make sure to eat the black eggs - eggs boiled in the hot springs. The lines can get long to buy the eggs, so get there early in the day to beat the crowds.
Awesome view in Hakone!

Interesting geographical feature. First time to go near active volcanic activity. crater spews out choking sulphurous fumes. Good infrastructure (typical Japanese) around the attraction. Restaurants are there too.
Great experience friendly staff  throughout train,bus,boat,cable car, tram and cafes restaurants at the top
Best place to see Mt fuji at the back of the shop and have various souvenir. Tips, buy black egg while hot to make your finger warm and eat while it already cold
Super cool to see from cable car. The hot springs are truly hot. I’d recommend stopping by and visiting.

Convenience place to reach by road or by cable car which they called Rope way. Free parking if you were driving which is not very often to get in Japan. Nice place for site seeing volcanic water vaporized as sulfur smell fog and buy black egg claimed to extend life another 7 year if not mistaken.

The ride up here is the best part. The scenery at the top looks like Mars. It’s very interesting. Definitely worth doing once, at least. The volcano cooked eggs are a hit for the kids. We enjoyed taking the switch back train to the ropeway …

A very unique experience, especially taking the cable car over the still active volcano, while it is steaming (?)

Also eat the black eggs! Each one lengthens your life by 7 years!😄 My wife made sure I didn't eat too many 😕
I love this place. Winter time have the best view of scenery  for me here and alot of hot springs nearby.
Beautiful scenery. Worth the trip up the cable cars to see Fuji.
Awesome views of the sulphur mountain. Interesting food options at the top too.
Great experience but you will have to bare with sulfer smell

Great for Mount Fuji Views Only (no field access)

Great view. 
The black eggs.... Are black on the outside. 
Normal hard boiled egg. A little over cooked but I like it like that.
Tourist trap. The black egg only comes in packs of 5 and has a shelf life of 2 days. Who eats 5 sulfur eggs in 2 days ?! They say it gives you 7 years of life span per egg. Maybe worth it ?
Nice view of Mt. Fuji and the sulphur smoke coming out of the cracks of the mountain looks amazing.
It's cool if you haven't seen a volcano mountain before.
Great views! Must visit if you at Hakone

Center of sightseeing in Hakone! I recommend you to eat Black-Egg(Kuro-Tamago), so that you can extend your life-span according to a tradition..
Beautiful place. Good view of Mount Fuji.
Great views - hot water from active volcanic activity especially interesting - great museum/ science centre explaining the process here recommended!
This is the place you must visit.. Nice but, strong wind. Please wear more.
Good experience for the kids. Geo museum great for learning about the geology of the region.

Scenic view. You can get there by car (usually a bit crowded with a waiting time to park) or more convenient way is to use rope way, which offers also nice views during the trip. One of the attractions are black eggs boiled in the vulcano …

Would surely be 5 stars if the hiking trails were open. Still worth a visit!
Beautiful place, especially they had the black eggs

Take a tram or a bus to the top, views are spectacular. Try the black egg or wasabi ice cream. The gasses can be strong and high sulfur.
Good view of Mount Fuji. The steam rising up from the ground makes an interesting view. The black egg taste just like hard boiled egg. Put salt for taste.

Lovely tour  around mt fuji and the guide spoke excellent english and at time changed from a tour guide to a stand up comedian really funny at stop off she was making sure everyone was present before setting off telling ppl off that was late making them sing songs in front of all of us all in all a excellent start to our holiday

Can see mountain Fuji and has lots of good food.
Like the black ice cream and black shell eggs.
A bit cloudy cant see Fujisan but great experience !! Love the ropeway up

Nice stop along the Hakone doorway with a focus on the caldera and black egg - views of Mt Fuji are possible but on the other side of the scenic viewing area.
Amazing spot with splendid scenery. Also the geology museum up there is interesting and with English explanation. Also view of Mt Fuji is one of the best in the area. Definitely a must see :)
Simply beautiful. Breathtaking. No words.
Beautiful place to visit in Japan!!! Amazing view of Fuji-San can be seen from there!! Climate is superbly amazing

A must visit location if you are in the area around Hakone!

Always nice to come back here. This time the walk up the mountain at owakudani was closed for construction but it's always fun here otherwise. Black onsen eggs and charcoal black ice cream etc. Also superb view of Mt Fuji as you can see in my pics.

A must if visiting Hakone area. This place is accessed through a cable car from Gora station(3 stops to Souzan)

Very beautiful. Black eggs are supposed to give you +7 years of life. They taste like regular hard boiled eggs tho.
Went on a rainy day and it was beautiful as you could see the h2s clouds forming. Ropeway ride is pretty awesome too.

Aside from the black eggs, another great souvenir would be the keychain and coin (Astroboy, Ultraman or the ropeway gondola against a Mt Fuji backdrop) that could be personalized with your name and the date of your visit.
Awsome place to see active volcano and eat black eggs boiled on Volcanic magna.

Definitely worth a stop at this station! The volcanic activity only started in 2015 and the crater and Sulfur is very impressive! Make sure the weather is good and clear before you make the trip.

Owakudani provided such a clear view of Mount Fuji when I visited! The cable car ride up the mountain was quite pleasant and it was nice to see the gas coming out from the crater. The black eggs were not bad too!
Prepare for the smell...but not that pungent....black egg are good to try
Really really good photo spot and nice nature view. The cold air cant stop us from seeing the beautiful scenery
It’s amazing view if you’re lucky enough!)
Good to see the volcano and to buy some black eggs, really good view from the city, but lot a lot more to do there
Great view on Fuji (sunny weather required). Ropeway experience is cool.

This was a great experience. You could see steam hissing out of the earth and the air heavy with sulphur. This is a must visit in the Hakone area. I did try the Black eggs that this place is famous for. Have some to live longer!
Good to visit if you are already visiting Hakone, nice food and view on 2nd floor restaurant
Nice and long cable car, must have experience if you come to Hakone
You can have kurotamago (Black Egg). Nice place to see natural wonder of hot fumes from the earth

You will see diifrent things such as volcano rocks, smoke and so on. Compliment your journey ny the ropeway
  Pleasant crew know how to handle groups
Volcanic park. Interesting to see. Take the cable car to the lake for a cruise :-)

One of the most popular tourist attractions. Must try the black egg and the black ice-cream. Do not miss the chestnuts roasted in something like a big canon! Amazing place to click pictures with Fuji-san in the backdrop!
Great View! For the 'Black Egg'

Yummy Egg=  1 egg is 7years old.

Beautiful sceneries, but sometimes to much smoke so you can't see clearly. There is a spot when you can see mt. Fuji. There is several souvenirs shop and restaurants. They popular food is black egg. Taste good!

It really depends on what sort of weather you get when you decide to visit. I went on a rainy day with a lot of fog, and it was difficult to see the attraction. The volcanic sulfur is nice to see, but be warned, it's is very windy up there. …
interesting place, wonder of nature. a quick 20 mins drop by sufficient to cover this place.
Nice spot to view the volcano and catch Mt Fuji when it is not shy.
The Hakone Geopark Museum can be found here.
It was super windy the day we were on the top. There was some renovations going on but have ppl guiding us around. Mt Fuji was hiding under a blanket of cloud so didn't get to see much of her.

Such an awesome experience. You access this area by taking the train to Hakone up a mountain side, the tram straight up the mountain, and finally a cable car to the top. Be ready on the cable car because as you crest the ridge this volcanic …
Beautiful place. We didn't try to black onsen egg. That's a bit of regret of the whole trip
Great spot to see mount Fuji and have a lunch break. Furthermore a nice view of the sulfur crates can be seen.
Can be very crowded and the smell may be a turn off for some. Great views into the crater to see the steam gushing out of the ground.
Beautiful view and nice stopping area!

Truly amazing to see so much volcanic activity with steam clouds billowing up from fumarolic vents coloured yellow from all the sulphur. The mountains and the view are spectacular and add to the impressive atmosphere. I was disappointed to …
Amazing views. Fun high speed winds. Magical sulfur volcanoes. AND you can't miss the BLACK BOILED EGGS and black ice cream. A mist visit.
A great place though smells really bad because of the sulfur. Towards evening, it creates The Lord of the Rings-like atmosphere.

Great place to view mount Fuji. You will find food, souvenirs, mini shrine.
They have local specialties, a smoked egg. And some special flakes. The round trip in the cable train is around 8 dollars, for me it's a good price.
Great place to visit. Recommended to tour.
Great view of Mount Fuji on a good clear day and Hell valley.
Good to visit.

If you go to Hakone then this place is recommended. You can either reach there by ropeway or via your own vehicle. Very beautiful scenic view and you can enjoy sulphur boiled eggs.  We got chance to go on top where they boil egss in natural …
Great Mt. Fuji view cable car
Significant view... worth the journey.. great place for autumn view along the cable car..
The way people make "black egg" is fantastic.
We went to Hakone lake and this place was a true surprise. We really enjoyed the view.

Very scenic spot. Ropeway goes over a volcanic area and you can see the earth smouldering. Prepare yourself because there is a sulfur smell lingering. Very nice way to get to the lake. From there you can take a pirate ship (ferry) to other parts around the lake.

It is easy to get here from the 18seater cable car. Place has stunning view of Mt. Fuji if you’re lucky. The onsen manju costs more than Gora but delicious. The manju is served hot and it is fluffy with yummy red bean paste. The black egg …
Beautiful place good weather  good teast ice cream and boiled black eggs

If u don't mind the location is out of place a bit from within Tokyo ring, this is definitely a great place to visit… u get to be up close and personal to an area where a major landslide that was triggered by previous earthquake
The highlight of Hakone area! Try to go as early as possible to avoid the massive invasion of tourists. Nice view of mountain Fuji if you are lucky with the weather

Boiling valley of sulphur steam. Eggs treated with the sulphur steam turns black on the outside. A ropeway linking the base of the steaming mountain provides a spectacular view. Very crowded with tourists tasting the black shell eggs.
Must here! Recommended place

Try the black eggs of Owakudani - which according to legend holds eating just one of these black eggs can add seven years to one's life. The place smells sulfur. Ride the Hakone Ropeway tram to see the sulfur deposits.
The volcano and the hot sign of our earth.
Interesting place but tons of tourist during our visit

Area from which you can view thermic and volcanic activity with a restaurant, several shops and a geography and history museum. There are also several hiking trails which were unfortunately closed when we were there (late November).
This is a must do when in Hakone. We'll worth the gondola ride to get there.

Really nice day trip if you don't mind the smell of sulfer. Beautiful views of Mt Hakone and Mt Fuji weather permitting. The distinctive black eggs, hard boiled in the springs and blackened by the sulfer, are a fun tourist attraction. They …

Famous for Black Eggs and Volcanic Stream.
Nothing special. Waste of money and time to come here. The staffs here weren’t friendly at all

It's a great place to see Mt. Fuji while eating the black eggs that are believed to prolong your life by 7 years. The sulfuric fumes did not have a strong smell when we were there and there were some snow left when we visited.

First, drive a car. There is a way to Owakudani and a parking lot for the drivers. …

Great site to visit while in hakone, and some of the best views of mt Fuji from the hakone area. Beware though that the souvenirs can get pricey from up here, and the wind is typically blowing quite strong. Pack a jacket ad even on a warm …

It's really beautiful and unique. I heard it was dog friendly but it really isn't. Expect traffic as even on weekdays there can be long lined to park. If you're bringing a dog, you can skip the ropeway/cable car altogether. I wish I'd simply hung around the main parking area. The lake is lovely but you can just drive there anyway.

Great views of Fuji! There are some nice shops with good souvenirs as well.  Don't forget to try the black eggs; they'll add seven years to your life ;) Don't worry, they taste just like the regular eggs you're used to. They also have black …
Bus ride up to the top was not the most comfortable. The view was great and it was about 10 degrees colder than the base. Smells like sulfur but worth seeing.

I recommend taking the ropeway up. You will get to see a great view of the mountains and Owakundani! Once you reach the top, there's a small tourist center and restaurant, as well as a geological museum. After admiring the crater, we were done since there's not much else to do at the top.

Interesting place with active volcanic zone where sulfurous fumes rise from the ground. Get here using the Hakone Ropeway because hiking is not advisable due to the sulfur gas. Try the sulfur black eggs claimed to extend one's life. There's also a nice vantage point to view Mt Fuji

I'm glad that Owakudani is open to public once again after the typhoon. The smell of sulphur isn't as strong as expected. The place is super windy so it's very cold. Awesome spot. The pass for this place is worth it. You can see the sulphur gas coming from the mountain. Museum is a good place for spending time and knowing about the mountain and it's origin. The lake is pretty big. The shrine spot for taking pic is pretty crowded. It's very amazing place
Coming here once is good enough for me, not regretting, but just look at something unusual.

Getting there and being there were two completely different yet exciting experiences. If you want to see and active conglomeration of mounts as Hakone is, and you also enjoy the smell os sulfur, then pay this place a visit.

If the weather is good, I would recommend riding the ropeway to Owakudani. We went on a clear weather day and the view of Mt. Fuji was truly beautiful. The activity of the mountain was interesting to see too! It does smell like sulphur, …

Nice view of mt Fuji here

Amazing! We saw it on a cloudy day so you couldn't see Fuji buy the view of the hot spring water being collected is worth the trip alone. Also take the train there for Hakone Yumoto for one of the steepest train rides on earth. Your clothes and skin will stink of sulphur for a few days after
Awesome experience, I only have good things to say about this place!

Black eggs Really good taste 
Japanese people says that eggs are giving good hope in future. Also place is so good to see .

When I came here, unfortunately the hiking trail was closed. But I still could have some good time here.
This place is recommended to go:)

Nice view of Mount Fuji in the clear days. Easy transportation.

The sulphur mining is not as active as Indonesia Mount Ijen but it is surely more scenic and managed.

Awesome natural sights! I
Must go especially during March. Not too cold, still snowing, great views.

Best place to visit in Japan.. travelled by train a wonderful experience reaching Hakone and then by electic Bus to Lake Asahi after that unforgettable travel by waterways in a ship which was well crafted.. then the best one to reach here was by ropeways

Hokone must visit prime place...
Rope way cable car views are 😍
Volcano views and Fuji san view

7 times 7 times 7 times... How many eggs how can you eat?

A wonderful place !

Ōwakudani (大涌谷 lit. "Great Boiling Valley") is a volcanic valley with active sulphur vents and hot springs in Hakone, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. It was created around 3000 years ago, as a result of the explosion of the Hakone volcano

text.wiki:
Okada Museum of Art (岡田美術館, Okada Bijutsukan) opened in Hakone, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan, in 2013. A private museum of Asian art with the largest indoor exhibition space in Hakone, extending over five floors, the collection of some 450 pieces centres on early modern and modern Japanese painting while also including Chinese bronzes, lacquer, ceramics, and Buddhist sculpture.


== See also ==
Pola Museum of Art


== References ==


== External links ==
