text.wiki:
Odawara (小田原市, Odawara-shi) is a city in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.
As of February 2015, the city had an estimated population of 194,672, and a population density of 1,710 persons per km2. The total area is 113.79 km2.


== History ==
The area around present-day Odawara has been settled since prehistoric times, and archaeological evidence indicates that the area had a high population density in the Jōmon period.
From the Ritsuryō system of the Nara period, the area became part of Ashigarashimo District of Sagami Province. It was divided into shōen during the Heian period, mostly controlled by the Hatano clan and its branches. During the Genpei War between the Heike clan and Minamoto no Yoritomo, the Battle of Ishibashiyama was fought near present-day Odawara. During the Sengoku period, Odawara developed as a castle town and capital of the domains of the later Hōjō clan, which covered most of the Kantō region. The Hōjō were defeated by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the Battle of Odawara in 1590, despite the impregnable reputation of Odawara Castle. The territory came under the control of Tokugawa Ieyasu.
Under the Tokugawa shogunate, Odawara was the center of Odawara Domain, a feudal han ruled by a succession of daimyō. The castle town prospered as Odawara-juku, a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto.
After the Meiji Restoration, Odawara Domain briefly became 'Odawara Prefecture', which was merged with the short-lived 'Ashigara Prefecture' before joining Kanagawa Prefecture in 1876. During this period, the center of economic and political life in Kanagawa shifted to Yokohama. Odawara suffered a strong decline in population, which was made more severe when the original route of the Tōkaidō Main Line bypassed the city in favor of the more northerly route via Gotemba.
The epicenter of the Great Kantō earthquake in 1923 was deep beneath Izu Ōshima Island in Sagami Bay. It devastated Tokyo, the port city of Yokohama, surrounding prefectures of Chiba, Kanagawa, and Shizuoka Prefectures, and caused widespread damage throughout the Kantō region. Ninety percent of the buildings in Odawara collapsed immediately, and fires burned the rubble along with anything else left standing.Odawara regained some measure of prosperity with the opening of the Tanna Tunnel in 1934, which brought the main routing of the Tōkaidō Main Line through the city. Odawara was raised from the status of town to city on December 20, 1940. On August 15, 1945, Odawara was the last city in Japan to be bombed by Allied aircraft during World War II.
On November 1, 2000, Odawara exceeded 200,000 in population, and was proclaimed a special city.


== Geography ==
Odawara lies in the Ashigara Plains, in the far western portion of Kanagawa Prefecture. It is bordered by the Hakone Mountains to the north and west, the Sakawa River to the east, and Sagami Bay of the Pacific Ocean to the south.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture
Minamiashigara
Ninomiya
Ōi, Kaisei, Nakai
Hakone, Manazuru, Yugawara


=== Climate ===


== Economy ==

Odawara is a major commercial center for western Kanagawa Prefecture. Manufacturing includes light industry, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and food processing. Agriculture and commercial fishing play a relatively minor role in the local economy. Odawara is also a bedroom community for Yokohama and Tokyo.
Companies headquartered in Odawara include:

Suzuhiro Co.
Meganesuper Co., Ltd.
Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd
Odawara Auto Machine MFG. Co., Ltd.
Odakyu Sharyo Kogyo Co Ltd
Odakyu Hakone Holdings Co., Ltd.
Hakone Tozan Railway
Sagami Trust Bank
Nippon Injector Corporation


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
JR Central - Tōkaidō Shinkansen
Odawara
JR Central - Gotemba Line
Shimo-Soga - Kōzu
JR East - Tōkaidō Main Line
Kōzu - Kamonomiya - Odawara - Hayakawa - Nebukawa
Odakyu Electric Railway - Odakyu Odawara Line
Kayama - Tomizu - Hotaruda - Ashigara - Odawara
Hakone Tozan Railway - Hakone Tozan Line
Odawara - Hakone-Itabashi - Kazamatsuri - Iriuda
Izuhakone Railway - Daiyūzan Line
Odawara - Midorichō - Isaida - Gohyakurakan - Anabe - Iidaoka  - Sagami-Numata


=== Highway ===
Odawara-Atsugi Road
Japan National Route 1, to Tokyo or Kyoto
Japan National Route 135, to Shimoda
Japan National Route 138, to Fujiyoshida
Japan National Route 255, to Hadano
Japan National Route 271, to Atsugi (toll)


=== Bus ===
Bus service to Izu Peninsula


== Area attractions ==

Besides Odawara Castle, Odawara is a major transit point for the Hakone hot springs resort area and the sightseeing locations of the Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park. Within the city itself, the Yugawara area is a well-known hot spring resort.
Enoura, a coastal area of Odawara known for its pristine sea, has an abundance of kumamomi, a type of fish that prefers clear and clean water. Sea turtles are sometimes present there. Because of the clear water and plentiful undersea life, many people come to Enoura for scuba diving.
Traditionally, Odawara is known for its production of kamaboko processed fish, stockfish, umeboshi salted plums, and traditional herbal medicines. The Suzuhiro Kamaboko Village is a place to experience making and learning more about Odawara Kamaboko.


== Sister city relations ==
 - Nikkō, Tochigi, since December 19, 1980
 - Kishiwada, Osaka, since June 26, 1968
 - Chula Vista, California, United States, since November 8, 1981
 - Manly, New South Wales, Australia (friendship city), since 1991
 - Shenzhen, Guangdong, China, since February 4, 1993


== Notable people from Odawara ==
Kai Atō - actor
Yōhei Kōno - politician
Ninomiya Sontoku - Edo period economist and philosopher
Rumina Sato - mixed martial arts fighter
Kitamura Tokoku - author
Yoshiyuki Tomino - anime movie director
Baku Yumemakura - science fiction author


== Notes ==


== References ==
Hammer, Joshua. (2006). Yokohama Burning: The Deadly 1923 Earthquake and Fire that Helped Forge the Path to World War II. New York: Simon & Schuster.  ISBN 978-0-7432-6465-5 (cloth)

Visited Odawara Castle after a few hectic days in Tokyo. It was a pleasant escape from the pace & noise of Shinjuku. It is a lovely older area with some very quaint shops. We used this is as a stop point for a quick bullet train adventure from Tokyo. The Castle is amazing,

The interactive ninja museum was worth the 300 yen entrance fee. We're adults and had just as much fun as the kids running around. There's not a lot of English but the staff tried where they could. The samurai museum was interesting. The views from the top of the tower were

We had a quick visit to odawara from hakone going back to tokyo. We only get to visit the castle and the mall near the station. It is a short walk from the station. And we really enjoyed going up the castle and looking at the historical displays inside.
Well maintained castle within walking distance from Odawara station. If u are not a fan of museums, go to the top of the castle for a panaromic view of the surroundings.
Although it’s not the original castle. It still looks beautiful on the outside. It’s actually a museum. You can wear a ninja, samurai or a princess costume here. Pretty neat if you ask me.

Quite impressive from the outside and approaching the castle through the neighboring streets, but underwhelming when inside. This castle was reconstructed only recently, so looks authentic from outside is certainly worth a visit to the grounds which is free. I wouldn't bother

小田原市のシンボルである城址です。小高い山の上に建てられているため、市街地のどこからでもすぐに見つけることが出来ます。2016年に大改修が行われ、それに伴い展示も一新。北条氏が治めていた戦乱の世を筆頭に、小田原合戦や江戸時代以降に至るまで事細かく、ビジュアルとしても判りやすい展示だったと思います。往年の歴史を勉強する上で、歴史、特に戦国時代マニアには垂涎の的の史料館ではありますが、英語などの他言語での解説が少ないように見受けられましたので、海外からの観光客にとって史料館の展示はやや物足りないと思うかもしれません。

Very much in keeping with other castles in Japan this one is beautiful. But so too is Odawara. Spotlessly clean. The castle itself is lovely and has great views from the top. There is a Ninja museum but it’s an interactive thing for kids which I wasn’t aware of. If you’re just

The grounds are beautiful. Felt like a local attraction. Not much English on a lot of the displays in the castle/museum. I don't think there were even English subtitles on the videos. But it didn't matter. Very nice place and affordable.

It was my first castle and it was beautiful and impressive, the castle also houses a museum explaining it's history, but most of it will be in japanese, still in my opinion it is worth stopping by if you are passing through Odawara and have the time.

This castle had been rebuilt, as the original had been burnt down. Not a very steep walk but nice to see. There is plenty of shaded areas around the castle, and there is a cage of monkeys that can keep the kids occupied.

Looks lovely from a distance, and the grounds are beautiful. The gardens with their old trees, wisteria trellis, azaleas in glorious full bloom, the iris ponds, the moat full of carp and water lilies, make up a little for the disappointment inside. I know the castle is old and
This castle is beautiful. Pure white. The tour inside is fantastic. The surrounding grounds beautiful. The walk up to it is lovely. Plenty of shopping nearby.

Odawara Castle was a great day trip! It is only a 20 min ride on the Shinkansen from the Yokohama/Toyko area and it is very close to the station. The place is very family friendly, just not for strollers. The grounds are wide open with lots of tables to stop and eat or rest
A wonderful side-trip. The walk is worth the time. The ‘castle’ is quite impressive and the history is significant and very interesting. Do take the time.

quite difficult to reinvent a review The place is a landmark of japanese history As such it’s a must see if you are around The museum- castle provides great view of the city and good insight of life at 13-16 centuries Highly recommended

Beautiful castle in the Sakura season. Only 10-15min walk from the train station. You can easily spend a good hour or two there.
I strongly recommend to visit this place with a nice castle . I did the visit during sakura period with nice cherry blossoms 🌸 . Moreover it is close to the train station, no excuse not visiting it !

It ls small but beautiful-looking castle that has been turned into a museum. It is about fifteen minutes walk from the Odawara Station. It cost 500 yen to enter. This is the cherry blossoms season, so there are lots of cherry blossoms to see on the way to the castle as well as
Odawara is a great very local authentic town. Fun to walk around local streets and see how the people live.

Beautiful castle which has been rebuilt and is now like new which allows you to understand exactly what a castle with the surrounding moat and walls was like. Great visit, about 80 minutes from Tokyo and 10 minutes walk from the station.

Not crowded which made it all the more enjoyable. Wish more of the exhibits were in English. Really enjoyed our time here. The Samurai Museum while small was worth the money.

It would have been better if I could have read anything.. I would have enjoyed all the interesting things displayed..

Nice rebuilt castle. Worth a visit if you're in the area on the way to Hakone since you have to change trains anyways. Nice photo op from outside. Panoramic from the 5th floor. Would have been really good if we caught cherry blossoms.

text.wiki:
Hakone (箱根町, Hakone-machi) is a town in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. As of June 2012, the town had an estimated population of 13,492, and a population density of 145 persons per km². The total area is 92.82 km2 (35.84 sq mi). Hakone has been designated as a Japanese National Geopark by the Japanese Geoparks Network.
Hakone is to a great degree regarded as a traveler destination; Mt. Fuji can be seen when taking a day trip from Tokyo. In addition to hot springs, museums and other recreation activities, Hakone is known for its scenery during all four seasons.


== Geography ==
Hakone is located in the mountains in the far west of the prefecture, on the eastern side of Hakone Pass. Most of the town is within the borders of the volcanically active Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, centered on Lake Ashi.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture

Odawara
Yugawara
Minami-ashigaraShizuoka Prefecture

Gotemba
Susono
Mishima
Oyama
Kannami


== History ==
Hakone is the location of a noted Shinto shrine, the Hakone Gongen, which is mentioned in Heian period literature. During the Genpei War, Minamoto no Yoritomo prayed at this shrine for victory over his enemies, after his defeat at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, which was fought in neighboring Manazuru. As with the rest of Sagami Province, the area came under the control of the later Hōjō clan of Odawara during the Sengoku period. After the start of the Edo period, Hakone-juku was a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto. It was also the site of a major barrier and official checkpoint on the route known as the Hakone Checkpoint (箱根関所, Hakone sekisho), which formed the border of the Kantō region. Under the Tokugawa shogunate, all travellers entering and leaving Edo along the Tōkaidō were stopped here by officials. Their travel permits and baggage were examined to enforce Tokugawa laws that restricted the travel of women and weapons.
After the start of the Meiji Restoration, Hakone became a part of the short-lived Ashigara Prefecture before becoming part of Ashigarashimo District in Kanagawa prefecture in August 1876. Hakone attained town status in 1889. The imperial household established the summer Hakone Imperial Villa close to the lake.
After merger with five neighboring towns and villages in September 1956, it reached its present boundaries.


== Economy ==

The economy of Hakone is strongly dominated by the tourist industry. Hakone is noted for its onsen hot spring resorts, which attract both Japanese and international visitors, due to its proximity to the greater Tokyo metropolis and to Mount Fuji. Sights include the volcanically active Ōwakudani geysers and Hakone Shrine on the shore of the lake, as well as the Hakone Botanical Garden of Wetlands. In April the cherry blossoms (sakura) and in autumn the Miscanthus sinensis (susuki) are noted sights.
Hakone has a number of art museums, including the Hakone Open-Air Museum and Pola Museum of Art.
Major events include the annual JLPGA CAT Ladies Golf tournament and the Hakone Ekiden, a long distance collegiate foot race, held at the New Year, which runs from Tokyo to Hakone and back over two days, partly in commemoration of the couriers who ran the Tōkaidō road.
One famous hotel in Hakone is the historic Fujiya Hotel in Miyanoshita, which was patronized by noted literary figures, politicians and foreign dignitaries in the Meiji and Taishō and early Shōwa periods.
A noted local handicraft is a kind of marquetry called Yosegi.Hakone is also well-known among anime fans for being the main location in the manga and anime series Neon Genesis Evangelion, in which it has been renamed Tokyo-3, and there are numerous attractions related to the franchise offered in the town. In 2017, Hakone was included as one of 88 anime pilgrimage sites for 2018 by the Anime Tourism Association. In 2020, new decorations have been introduced to the city in the anticipation of the release of the final film of the Rebuild of Evangelion tetralogy.


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
Hakone Tozan Railway
Hakone Tozan Cable Car
Hakone Ropeway
Izuhakone RailwayOdawara and Mishima, the terminus of the Odakyū Odawara Line, 70 minutes from Shinjuku, Tokyo. From Odawara, the Hakone Tozan Line continues into various resort towns in Hakone. Odakyu also runs the Romancecar limited express between Shinjuku and Hakone-Yumoto. From Gōra, the terminus of Hakone Tozan Line, the Hakone Tozan Cable Car funicular goes to Sōunzan. Ōwakudani can be reached by Hakone Ropeway from Sounzan and the lake, while the lake is crisscrossed by cartoonishly decorated "pirate" ships for tourists. There is also Hakone Komagatake Ropeway, which goes to the top of Mount Komagatake.
A popular "Hakone Free Pass", allowing unlimited use of most forms of transport for several days, is available. Hakone Free Pass can be bought at Shinjuku Station, Odawara Station, any other chief station along Odakyū Odawara Line, Hakone-Yumoto Station, Gōra Station, any other chief station along Hakone Tozan Line, Sōunzan Station, Tōgendai Station, Sengoku-Annaijo Bus Stop, Moto-Hakone Port, Hakone-Machi Port, and JR Gotemba Station Bus Information.


=== Highways ===
Hakone Shindō
Japan National Route 1
Japan National Route 138


== Education ==
Private schools:

Kanrei Shirayuri Gakuen Junior/Senior High School


== Sister cities ==
 - Tōyako, Hokkaidō, since July 4, 1964
 - Jasper, Alberta, Canada from July 4, 1972
 - Taupo, New Zealand, from October 7, 1987
 - St. Moritz, Switzerland, from November 2, 2014 (Friendship City)

When I heard we are going on a pirate boat I thought there must be a mistake and probably meant "private" boat but no it was a beautiful pirate ship. It has 3 decks and a snack bar. First and second decks are shaded, third deck is out in the sun. The third deck also has a VIP

this was part of the day tour that i had arranged and was not expecting a very large pirate boat to turn up . the cruise i took was the length of Lake Ashi and although there is a first class section to be honest it was up at the from of the boat and in my opinion not really

The cruise is included if you purchase the Hakone Pass. The Lake is huge and the boat is large enough and is very stable. Went during a cloudy day hence could not see Mount Fuji but nevertheless was a very good experience.

Unfortunately our group was the only people in the cruise...lovely n green all over...bit windy but on the deck was lovely n good for photographers.. Mountains around and from somewhere where Mt Fuji was in its form..seemed following us from Tokyo itself...so lucky to have

Why would you put yourself through that??? Queues to get on, utterly packed. There was a deserted (blissfully non-pirate themed) ferry 2 mins along the pontoon which we had virtually entirely to ourselves!

Crowded and definitely touristy but a good way to see lake Ashi if on a clear day and able to sit at the top deck. It was otherwise wet and rainy and the boat course had to be shortened due to the bad weather. We had the Hakone free pass so we’re not too disappointed about the
It was an awesome early morning ride across the lake with a light mist / clouds floating by above. If you like boat rides around instead of a bus, climb aboard.

My Fuji is the focus of everything in Hakone. So the ride on the cruise is a must for some picturesque shots. It’s also a good alternative to the cable cars as the Hakone Ropeway was suspended for volcanic activity. We took a return trip from the northern tip of the lake. You
We took ride And it's nothing special. Unfortunately weather wasn't the best that day but it was relaxing to sit for a while and soak in the sights and scenes.

My husband and I decided to take the boat across the lake to see more of Hakone during a two day visit. Weather was drizzly and visibility poor - and the cable car that the hubby wanted to take part in was suspended.... so this was the best alternative to drinking coffee at the

The cruise took around 1 hour. The view is fantastic but would recommend to plan the trip along with weather forecast even though it’s a lake but if it was raining the current could become a bit hectic.

We had some time left so we thought about the ferry today which was 2 minutes from our hotel. When we got there we asked what is the next boat...3pm was the reply. How long does it take? 35 minutes was the reply. What’s at the other end ? Some restaurants. What time is the last

We as Indian tend to every thing whatever is included in free pass to get the maximum of what we have paid. This is one of the activity included in pass. I stayed in hakone for 2 days and by mistake bought a 2 days pass whereas 3 day pass is also available with hardly few extra

The ship was amazingly beautiful and it was a fun experience. We enjoyed it very much. The interior was elegant and the scenery was gorgeous. The one way trip was just long enough. There was a restaurant at the destination with good lunch choices. We took the bus back for a

We purchased our tickets in the ticket office where the signs are in English and Japanese for the Hakone Sightseeing Cruise or 'Pirate Ship'. We had spent all day on the Hakone circuit and this was our last step -- across Lake Ashi from Hakone-Machi-Ko to Togendai-Ko. Yes,
Took a Pirate ship across Lake Ashi to get to our hotel in Hakone. An uneventful trip with pleasant views. Bit bizarre!
The boat itself is pretty and some of the sights are very nice, but it is kinda hard to get a window seat on the boat, it is a nice way to cross Lake Ashi and getting to Togendai station though.
Great views of the shore though a little touristy and kitsch. Can get very busy but it’s the best way to enjoy the surrounding mountains and shrines with screaming children.

Boarded the pirate ship with fake sails from Hakonemachi-Ko at the south end of Lake Ashi to the north end at Togendai-Ko. It sails a rather slow and smooth across the Lake. Lake Ashi is a crater lake that lies along the southwest wall of the caldera of Mount Hakone, a

Free admission with Hakone Free Pass. We took the sightseeing cruise from the Togendai-ko to Motohakone-ko after taking the ropeway from Owakudani. Arguably the best way (and probably the only way) to thoroughly enjoy Lake Ashi. Even though the cruise ship can get crowded, feel

We really enjoyed this trip. Loved the boat. Highly recommend paying the additional for the first class ticket. Economy looked to be overcrowded and from first class your at the front so can see all the views. We also paid for a return and you can hop on and off. You just ponder
No toured information in English, and relativley quick with decent, but not amazing views of Mount Fuji
Best way to see the lake and surrounding countryside. Don’t be put off by the tacky name of ‘pirate ship’, it’s absolutely fine

I quite enjoyed the ride, the boat is beautiful, it was crowded but not uncomfortable - No Mount Fuji for us, never mind we caught it elsewhere and being Summer it's just a mountain, but would not have missed it!

The ride gives you a nice view of the lake area. But the ship gets packed and it can be uncomfortable. Pay the little extra to get into the VIP section - that gives you access to the front of the ship with less crowd obstruction.
Beautiful and peaceful place with delightful views from ships on Lake Ashi. The curry lunch was good. Recommend a visit as you also to get a view of Mt Fuji on a clear day

Yes, the cruise was all ok, but it’s just part of the manufactured process of moving tourists through the Hakone area in a bit of a loop. And when you have the pass that includes the cruise and you have some time, then why not? The cruise would have been a lot more special if
The cruise is free if you are holding a Hakone free pass. The ships will make a complete tour of the lake with amazing view on the wonderful nature.

It was a beautiful day for a sail across the lake to a great lunch! The ship is comfortable, & the views quite stunning. Best to get pics of the ship & Mt Fuji in the background if the weather is kind & it was!
Not really a cruise. It's just a way to get back to the train via boat (and horrible bus ride). I cant recommend in any condition.

The Lake Ashi Pirate Ship sightseeing tour is definitely a worthwhile experience. As you ride the ship to the other side of the lake to get to the town centre of Hakone you can enjoy the beautiful views of the surrounding nature, mountains, hills and of course the lake

We took the cruise (it was free for pass holders) to get to the other side of Lake Ashi which is known for getting a view of Mt Fuji. You could also get a view from the ship. However, we weren't lucky. It gets crowded with not sufficient seating for everyone. The views in Autumn

We enjoyed our trip on the boat while in the area although the sceywas not as good as we thought as the trees were not in leaf. We did not get off at the end but did around trip and went back to the start as we want to go bake to Hakone

Togendai-ko sight seeing cruise is located in Moto-Hakone, Hakone-machi, in Ashigarashino, a 70-minute sight seeing cruise that serves three ports along lake Ashinoko. This ship has a gorgeous first class cabin for your extra comfort, a 3D art spot for photo shooting, and the

Not sure really about the pirate theme as the crew just sailed the boat but best that they concentrated on the task in hand as there was no safety briefing and no visible signs of any emergency equipment. Pleasant 30 minutes crossing the lake. Pirate ship additions to the boat
Don’t go Nothing to see Just a packed boat on a lake No commentary Avoid at all costs People push and stare at you And talk lound
The hakone free rail pass includes this. It is an awesome experience. You can go to the top deck which is open and around noon time in March you get good tolerable weather.

You can take an Odakyu Bus from Gotemba or Shinjuku to Togendai-ko (port) with many stops in between. At Togendai, check the TV screen for sightseeing cruise timing, it has a 30-40mins frequency! Once on the ship, you can get seats in economy class and it will most likely
An inspired Pirates of the Caribbean ship its an IG worthy place also towering Mt. Fuji. It really is a must try experience when you visit Hakone
Touristy Should get first class seats otherwise hard to get a seat and then you don’t see anything else 500 yen extra for first class 30 minutes ride It was okay 👌🏿
Sometimes it stops operating if there is heavy snowfall the day before, due to ice on the deck. We arrive early March, had to wait 3 days before we could go onboard.
This is a great transport to connect between Moto Hakone to Togendai During our travel, Mt Fuji is visible and you can take as many picture as you want. The ride are smooth and the service is great.

This was a fun adventure while in the Hakone area on Lake Ashi. The company operates several of these modern recreation pirate ships that sail daily across the lake. Worth while going on if in the area. The ship was amazing to see and are quite detailed. BOTTOM LINE: Do it!
We went there last November 2018. We booked the Hakone Free Pass from Klook which made our trip easier. The ship was nice and you can take different photos of the beautiful scenery in Lake Ashi.

“Victory” was built as a replica of the HMS Victory, an 18th-century British warship, but with some modern-day conveniences. Nice views of Mount Fuji and water views from the upper deck. Beware that it in the late fall through early spring, it can be chilly out on Lake Ashi, so
Pretty views however I did feel it was a little too crowded, and infrequent (40 mins) so if you plan to disembark at a stop or two best to get an early start.

The cruise was comfortable. If not for the rain, wind and cold, we would have sat at the upper deck and enjoyed the awesome view. Do catch the earlier timing cruise during winter as it gets dark after 4pm.

Did this as part of the hakone free pass and it was great, probably would not have done it if it wasn’t included in the free pass but it was great to have a view from the lake, and fantastic views of mt Fuji from here.
If you are looking at scenery, take the deck. In the hold, you will not be able to see much scenery and the boat ride becomes a chore. So if you want to take some cool pictures, go up to the deck.

Suggest start your day early so avoid the crowd. Travel in between from rope rail stn to makamoto, follow the sightseeing path as suggested by local travel guide. Best viewing with normal ticket rather than vip seat for better viewing. You can see the mt fuji in this boat from

We took a round trip ride from Motohakone-ko. The boat was clean and provided a commentary of the sights shpping the route it took to the 2 other stops/towns on Lake Ashi. Unfortunately we were short of time else we would love to got off to explore the two little towns.

Take this cruise from Togendai pier to Motohakone Pier take around 15 - 30 minute. the Scenery was great and you can see the Tori gate (temple gate) in the lakeside. i recommend you to buy the hakone free pass at Odakyu Mall Shinjuku for the best price. you will have a free

This is a lovely way to cross Lake Ashi, included as part of the Hakone travel pass. It was too cloudy for us to see Mount Fuji but we still enjoyed views of the lake, mountains and famous tori. Plenty of seats inside or stand outside.

If u intend to visit Hakone, then to Gotemba Premium outlets and do some sight seeing while u’re here. It is best to buy the Hakone Pass. U can take this sightseeing cruise free if u purchase the Hakone Pass. (Note there are 2 sightseeing cruise, don’t take the one not included

We had the free pass and this was included so it seemed a good way to see a bit more of the area. We caught a fairly late boat (about 3.40 I think) and it was getting dark by the time we reached the end. Not much of a commentary and very hard to hear. Didn't swap ships to see

Lake Ahi is a beautiful lake nestled into a valley--it a skinny little lake that is surrounded with trees that go to the edge of the water. The mode of transportation is described as a "Viking Ship" in the brochures, but it is more like a poor reproduction of a pirate ship.
You can see Mount Fuji for a short time from the Motohakone-Ko end but most of the trip is just of the lake itself. Means to an end to get from one end of the lake to the other more than anything.
Covered by the cost of the Hakone Free pass, this is a European-looking ferry that has the function of transporting tourists across the lake. Very functional.

Lake Ahi is must see place as for Hakone sightseeing. From Togendai station to Moto-Hakone(25mins) to Hakonemachi ko (10mins). Most shops around Hakonemachi ko close on 5pm. So be careful to choose time schedule. Around Hakonemachiko there are leiden museums and sekisho.
Looked his thing. Wasn’t crowded. Great views and felt safe. The boat does a swing around at the end worth of face and furious with a huge boat. Loved it.

Big pirate ship that does a cruise on Lake Ashi from Togendai station of Hakone Ropeway to Hakonemachi and Motohakone. (can do a return circuit) Snacks and drinks available on boards. Nice scenery along the way but not much else to see. Change ships at Hakonemachi for
Pretty lame. It feels like you are getting herded around like sheep from one mode of transportation to anther this might be for you. The whole day felt like a long ‘travel day’.

When you see the cruise, you're really impress and hope for a magnificent trip. But it's not really the case. The trip is ok, the views are good, but it's nothing compare with what you'll see from the ropeway. But still, it's the fastest way to go to Hakone after the ropeway.
This trip gets you around Hakone while also showing off the lake’s beautiful scenery. The ship accommodations are just okay, but it’s a relaxing, efficient, and fun trip.
I take the boat to go to the opposite site of the lake. It was great! We saw the lake from another point of view. Unfortunately we were not able to see the mount Fuji but we appreciate it anyway

Their are two types of Hakone sightseeing ferry, the old pirate boat and modern ferry. I surely recommend the pirate boat as it has got amazing views from deck and it's the only ferry which takes you right till the cable trolley station. Modern ferry doesnt go there and hence
Hakone is a beautiful and serene place to visit. The sightseeing cruise was a nice bonus to our visit and very enjoyable.
The cruise is okay, you have to pay extra for First Class, but the lake is beautiful and on a clear day, the views of Fuji must be sublime. Fun for families with small kids, I'm certain.
This boat ride was a fun way to get around to the small villages surrounding the lake and was included in our rail pass. Charming and cute.
The boat was very clean and pretty ! You could see the view of outside everywhere and they explained you little things about the river, and places around.

We took the cruise late in the afternoon on a cloudy day, and so had no chance of seeing Mount Fuji. However, the journey was enjoyable anyway. The lake is so high up in the mountains that we were able to see clouds reaching down to the surface of the water, and the weather is
The Hakone Sightseeing Cruise in lake Ashi runs between Moto-Hakone Port, Hakone-machi Port and Togendai Port. You can enjoy the beautiful landscape and also Mt Fuji.

The pirate ships looked very impressive! The views of Mount Ashi and the Mountains were good. We spent about $50 AUD each for the Tozan Railway, cable car, ropeway and sightseeing cruise which we thought was very reasonable. This was an enjoyable journey!
A cramped ship in the style of a pirate galleon. It is part of the transport network around Hakone but it’s not a highlight in its own right. Reasonable views at best.

If this is a cruise, then it's the biggest rip off in Japan! It's not really a cruise, it's transportation from one side of Lake Ashi to the other. We spent US $80 for a family of five to sail a few minutes from central Hakone to the opposite shore, all so we could partake in
Nice trip to add into the rope way and bus trip. Novelty pirate ship which the children seem to enjoy. The views around the lake are good and the sail gave a good perspective.

Cruise is about 30 minutes long. Water not crowded so you can see sights on shore. Ship is crowded and middle seats are no good for picture taking. To better see and take pictures stand by a door or window.
Its free if u take the hakone pass. Can see the view of mount. Fuji also but it depends on the weather.

Go to the top deck... a Must.. to enjoy the best view of Lake Ashi. Pay extra at the station before boarding approx ¥500 for First Class a.k.a. Captain’s Deck... great spot for the ‘Titanic’ selfie moment. Can also enjoy the ride inside the lower decks especially when it rains
I enjoyed the tour around the lake- even though all the good views of the mountains were covered in fog.

Ultimately, this is just a ferry that gets you from one side of the lake to the next. Little kids will be happy that the ship is dressed up with pirates, but for everybody else it’s all just a bit kitsch. But, hey, it’s included in the Hakone multi-day transportation pass, so

It's so worth it to pay 5 more yen for the first class. There's a special section you can be in that is so much less crowded! There are decks inside and on top for just first class tickets. The trip is not long. There are 2 stops that you can get off at or go round trip.
This is a good option to relax a bit. While enjoying the ride, you may see the Fuji Mountain if you are lucky. It’s also good that you can hop off to 2 other different stops. I enjoyed it a lot!
It’s just a way of getting across Ashinoko. Stayed above the deck, but it was cloudy, windy and cold. Not an enjoyable experience on the day. My kids stayed inside and enjoyed the free Wifi.
Pirate ship in a Japanese lake. Why not? Fun trip to an interesting area. There are 3 ships that offer a ferry service with a difference. The Hakone rail pass covers this experience.
Part of the round trip the boat takes you from one end to the other. Nothing spectacular but worth doing

The Hakone Pirate Ship is a pleasant cruise across Lake Ashi and part of the Hakone loop. It can be accessed using the Hakone Free Pass and is connected to the Hakone Ropeway on one side of the lake and the bus at the other end. The boats look great from the outside. The
Coming down by the cable car from the volcano we took a ride aboard the Viking style ship in the beautiful lake and the breathtaking relaxing scenery

It was a glorious sunny day and Lake Ashi sparkled in the sunlight. We got there at about midday and the next scenic boat ride across the lake (included in our Hakone Free Pass) was at 12:30pm. We found a spot overlooking the lake to sit and have a snack before joining the

We didn’t manage to sit on the seats on board. But we did sit on the stairs on the top deck whilst the ship was sailing across Lake Ashi. We rather came late for the Sakura blossoms but I bet the view is amazing and breathtaking when it’s spring or autumn. This is part of the
