Hakone National Park is such a busy place with queues for everything. The Hakone Free Pass allows you to travel on most transport at an inclusive rate. We were lucky in that we went to Togendai but the pirate cruise was a cancelled due to strong winds. We went for a walk and by

Rather depressing hall greets you once you leave the ropeway. The cafeterias were rather grim too, and there didn’t appear to be anywhere outside the building to get a coffee or a snack. Had to wait quite a while for a boat to leave. It was well organised but there were such
Great way to travel the lake and enjoy the scenery and ride. The boat ride is at most 45 minutes but on a clear day you can get a picture of My. Fuji and other points of interest.

We had a Hakone pass (worth buying) which allowed us unlimited trips on this ship. The first trip we took was late in an evening from Motohakone - the last round trip to Motohakone. It was quite cold and misty and hence could not get to see Mt Fuji. The next day we took the
We had lots of fun on this boat. Much recommend to take it for a day! Also if you can spend a bit more $ I would recommend getting first class :).

Boarding this pirate ship in the end of winter, which the chilling air is about 7 degrees, with the wind blowing on deck. My face freezes. Yo Ho Ho, fuji-san appears towards the middle of the journey, its like finding the one piece! Fuji-san is known to hide behind the clouds
We can see the Mt.Fuji on this ship! A bit windy, but you can view the nice view on board! Must try this ship!

Beautiful scenery along Lake Ashi, but not nearly enough seats. It was very cold went we went, and cloudy. We couldn’t see mt. Fuji, which is just luck. There is a kiosk on board for drinks and some snacks. There are pirate themed areas like a cannon for kids. Cute novel boat
The ship looked amazing.. we had a wonderful time on this ship.. I do recommend visiting here... good place to spend time with your partner

The trip took only about 30 minutes between Motohakone Port to Togendai Port but was fun and provided great views of Mt Fuji. We spent longer lining up to get on board, but as we have come to expect everything was handled in an orderly process. The lake is very beautiful

My kids enjoyed the ride in the lake. It is interesting to find a lake in the mountainous area. It was ok weather but still Fujisan was not visible. There was a first class room you can pay 500 yen to get in and avoid crowd. We took a bus to come back to Odawara. We
Fun trip with kids - totally enjoyed the trip . It was a cold day but we all stayed out to see the beautiful scenery

The Hakone pirate ship at Lake Ashi is part of Hakone Visit suggested “model sightseeing” route. They have 2 ships to take you go across Lake Ashi, we got on from Hakone machi ko, a shorter ride around 20-30 minutes to go across the tame Lake Ashi to Togendal Ko- terminal of
Efficient but touristy way of retracing your route without duplicating (e.g. bus one way, boat the other way).

The ship trip was the part of Hakone visit (which is pretty obvious trip for gaijin). We bought the Hakone pass on the Shinjuku station covering the ropeway, busses and ship. We walked to the shrine, the Hakone streets and took the ship. The weather was FAB, so we could see the
Recommend to be on the deck where you can see and feel like on the real pirate ship. It is the best place for the scenery as well.

We took the Hakone Ropeway from Sounzan down to Togendai-ko (see separate review) to take the Pirate Ship . Of coarse it is a must to take the Pirate ship across Ashi Lake . Even with all the tourists around you . They all want to enjoy the same things you want : The beautiful

Awesome experience even we didn’t have little kids to travel with, even it was chilly outside on the deck, we stayed almost the whole trip out in the front deck! It offers fantastic views of the lake, other ships as well as distant scenery

Nothing much on deck. With indoor door and outdoor sitting. Top deck is open and able to feel the smooth sailing on Lake Ashi. Only the First Class ticket holder enables you to go to the forward bow . Total duration 30mins .
This was a fun way to get to our hotel. Crossed the lake on this pirate ship. Nice view of the scenery from the lake. A lot more fun then taking the bus!

Basically packed with tourists and no place to sit. Even the priority seats are taken up by everyone else rather than the priorities. The view is jus the lake and the mountains of trees...nothing really exciting.

Still don't get the pirate ship thing, but it was a pleasant short trip across the lake. Unfortunately a very overcast day meaning a bit cool & windy on deck, no sighting of My Fuji & not much else to see. Lots of people on board, so moving around not easy. A logical part of

Strange to find pirate ships in Japan. The kids will love this. Buy tickets at the pier. The ships run regularly and you have 2 stops. One takes you to the cable cars which take you up to the sulphur crater. Always plenty of eateries, souvenir shops and superb toilets.

I would just take a photo of the ship and be done. On the day we went on the ship, it was foggy so we could not see a thing. They also tend to overload the ship so that you could not see much if you sat in the middle as we did. The entire cruise was over in 30 minutes. I would

Surreal experience that would only happen in Japan! I never thought I would be on a pirate ship crossing the lake! I read reviews before going that gave some really good advise! Get there early and pay the extra to go first class as it gets very crowded and you want to see all

This boat takes you to different points on the lake. As it’s name suggests it looks like a pirate ship but is a bit of fun and obviously touristy. However nice way to see the lake and get some lovely views and photograph the Hakone shrine in distance as well. The trip we took to

Oct 4 We did not have to wait long before embarking on one of the "pirate" ships that crosses Lak Ashi. The exterior might remind you of a pirate ship, but the interior is like any ferry boat. Prime seats go fast. There is little to do on board besides enjoying the scenery.

There are 3 beautiful porate ships for cruising in Lake Ashi. We managed to try 2 of them: Victory and Wasa. The 3rd one is Royale II. Dyring our cruise on board the Victory, one of the crew members was dressed up in a Captain's outfit for photo-taking opportunities.

We went one way on the pirate ship which I think was enough to enjoy the views of the lake and the torii on the edge. Today was a rubbish day in terms of weather and view, but you’re inside on the boat so at least ta warm and dry. Your Hakone Free Pass gets you as many rides

The whole journey take 90mins but one can also do 15mins trip from departure point to 1st stop at Motohakone-ko as well which is also cheaper. We bought economy tickets & went to the top deck. It got really busy as everyone wanted to see the view from the deck. It got really

If you are visiting Hakone and want to see Lake Ashi, this is probably the most efficient way to do it, you have three stops and if you purchase the round trip you can get off in each stop and ride the next boat. We really enjoyed the views from the boat and it saved us a lot of
We took the boat across the lake. We enjoyed a beautiful view of the lake. Even Mount Fuji was somewhat visible. The sunset gave it a special touch.

It's very much want you expect from a Japanese pirate ship. Well managed, excellently cleaned and entirely enjoyable. We read somewhere that it's worth taking the first class tickets - which is definitely true - as they get you access to the front of the boat (both the cabin and

We used the boat on our trip around Hakone having taken the bus from Hakone -Yumoto station. This is a nice 30 minute ride across the lake you can take in the amazing views the scenery is breathtaking. If this fits within your plans around the lake I would recommend it as
Take the ship across the lakes for great views of Mount Fuji, it's a real must and very reasonably priced.

The views are lovely as you travel across the lake. The ship/ferry is very busy so if you want to guarantee a view and have some space book into the first class area. Only takes about 30 mins to cross the lake one way.

We were staying in Hakone and paid 4000 yen for an all day transportation pass. It included this boat ride and we did it. Just a pleasant 30 mins ride across a mountain Lake. You see the Otorii Gate for the Hakone shrine standing in water as well as another little

Really enjoyed our cruise along The Ashi. It's a nice way to travel about. We got an early boat and it was pretty quiet, the ones leaving later looked pretty busy. We missed the last boat back accidentally when we arrived, it's at 16:30....we had assumed 5 would be the last. We

Nice and sedate trip. Could combine with the cable car and ideally that would be the best. We had low cloud and a white out so didn't do this plus we ran out of time. Next time however would do the cable car which is situated at the end of the boat ride. Its 30 minutes

Its covered by Hakone Pass (if you have one), but you can also upgrade it to First Class for 400 yen! But the experience will be totally different from the normal one, since the normal one is so packed and crowded, you will barely see anything on high season! in the first class
Trips are well organised and you can stop at different places. Sort of a hop on hop off boat trip. Great experience.
The ferry take us to the next destination, The Hakone Ropeway. the Ferry experience was great. we can see the lake Ashi from the deck. very calm and beautiful scene

Honestly, I have no stinking clue to as to why the tour boat is in a pirate ship form but I don't care because the design is the coolest I have ever seen and will ever get to ride on. The ship itself is very large and very well made. And it's awesome because it's a perfect tour
We saw this majestic ship from our cruise ship and it looked amazing. Hope to go on it next time we are there.

A great way to see lake Ashi. They have 3 boats working to a schedule and the whole operation is well run. Opted for VIP seats and although it was less busy felt like there wasn't that extra money you paid for in value. Free water or complimentary map would have made the

We were talked into buying a first class ticket which gave us more space and an even better view up front when crossing the lake. The views from the lake are amazing. Mt Fuji hid until we were back on the ropeway but if the weather is clear you should be able to see her from the
Lake Ashi is a place I want to return to visit for many days. Riding across the lake in Shogun style was very fun. Not a view of Fuji, but lovely views along the lake.

We paid the extra fee to get first class cabin. We also bought the Hakone Free Pass which is 4000 yen when bought from Odawara station. Being in first class on the ship is nice. You get a separate cabin that is not crowded. And also a separate section on the upper deck of the
Three ferrys all done up as pirate ships which is great for kids but is really only a nice way of seeing the lake as part of a round trip with the rope way and Hakone buses and trains.

We took the Hakone Pirate ship. I really appreciate with the cleanliness and the hospitality of the people. We pay more for having the private space until the top of ship. So we can took many pictures and we love it.
The boats that travel over Lake Ashi definitely provide awesome views of the area. It is part of the Hakone Free Pass, so no complaints here!

Loved it, it was my first time to do a short cruise trip, and I really enjoyed it. The view is just so picturesque. The photos I took couldn't even give justice to them. This would definitely be a romantic thing to do with a partner

The pirate Ship was an unusual surprise when we got there. The trip isn't much to write home about, but was unusual. I was told that we could possibly see Mount Fujiyama, but either I was told something that was not true, or the weather did not allow us to see the top of the
The Pirate Ship was an interesting ride. The theme of the ship was quite different from the surrounding area. The views were quite incredible however which made the whole experience worth it.

To finish our Hakone trip we took the Hakone pirate ship. It is a well equipped ship with enough seating places. On bord you can have a photo opportunity with a real pirate and when you are luck you can see Mount Fuji from the water. Unfortunately we had a cloudy day, so we were
You can use a Free Pass to ride free but I recommend you pay the surcharge to have uncrowded seating at the bow and to get some some great shots.

Okay it is a bit corny but still a fantastic way to travel across Lake Ashi. Go up on the top deck for the best views and exhilarating breezes. If it's cold and rainy then you are better off staying inside - although the views aren't as spectacular.
ENJOY the sights and sounds of Hakone Bay while cruising in a pirate ship. FUN and enjoyable and picture-perfect for those who want to take great selfies or groupies.

We booked this cruise over lake Ashi in a pirate ship over Viator. I'm glad we did this. The view was amazing. Unable to see mount fuji though as the sky was not clear. I really enjoy the cruise and the view.
It's quite bizarre to see that huge pirate ship on the lake. As it was chilly, we stayed inside the ship fully protected and unharmed by other pirates. If you are up there at the lake, it's a must.
Fun scenic ride. It is about 1/2 hour across, so not enough time to get bored if you are restless. Clean and well maintained ships. Staff very courteous and helpful.

Realky enjoyed the boat trip. Its not that long and you can get on and off at the three stops, one of which has cable car. We went for the first class cabin which is at the front, v luxe and gives access to the very front and top of the boat so no other tourists get in the way

The pirate ship ride was ok, just like a normal ferry ride. We did not have the chance to see Mount Fuji but I can imagine the beautiful view one would have on a clear day. Lots of people on the boat and it is spilt into ordinary and first class but I wonder why they bother

The replica pirate ship is fairly large with both enclosed and open decks. There is an area at front of ship for First Class customers who can pay a supplement to the normal fare. Travelled on many different lake ships/boats in both USA and Europe but never seen one like this
Pleasant cruise on the lake for 30 mins. Not a lot to see, which was a shame. Pretty crowded with tourists
The only reason to go on the pirate ship is to get to land the Village across the lake after you disembark from the wrong way It's a nice voyage but very hokey and contrived

If you are traveling on a cold and wet day pay the extra for first class otherwise you will be stuck outside on the deck in freezing conditions with no shelter. There is very limited closed space unless you pay extra
We took the pirate ship to hakone shrine and had lunch here it was a good way to kill a day and worth it to get first class ticket

I would do this again for the views... but the ship itself is pretty cheesy with photo ops with pirates. Skip the inside seating areas and head right to the top of the ship for the best views... it's only 20 mins and worth it

Standing up top of the pirate ship was freezing but a must do to see the view. We caught a quick glimpse of Mt Fuji before it disappeared behind the clouds again. The pirate ship is part of the Hakone package and helps get you around the loop to the cablecar.
Personally I recommend this. The scenery is good.Condition of the ship is still reasonable.worth trying

Visited during the winter, it is very very cool out there. The cruise are so big and can be cater for more than 200 pax and view from the cruise are so spectacular especially the view of Mountain Fuji!

The Hakone Pirate Ships are a main tourist attraction in Hakone. Indeed there is nothing like taking a scenic cruise around Lake Ashi after a full day of sightseeing! There are three Hakone Pirate Ships - the Royal II (a replica of the 18th century French warship, the Royal

Crossing the lake Ashi by the Pirate ship is a nice experience, I wish the weather had some mercy on us. The clouds made sure that we did not get scenic views of the lake. But its a must do experience in Hakone. Its covered by the Hakone Pass.
A bit cheesy but comfortable cruise on a Pirate ship across lake Ashi from Togendai to Hakonemachi ko, which takes 30 minutes one way. Great view of the environs.

We (my self,brother,sister) went with this ship last November..It was very cool climate there..But it was a nice ride with this ship.this takes around 40 minutes ride to the destination..any way you can see the Mr Fuji as well..

A lovely boat with drinks available to buy. Seating inside or standing outside. Great views of Mount Fuji half way on lake. Have to take a bus at other end but there are plenty. You can also return by same boat. First class available but you don't gain anything for that really.
A fun ride on the Pirate ship. The kids loved it, the views were absolutely gorgeous, and the ride was smooth and comfortable. Free using Hakone Free Pass.
When we go for the ride it was super sunny, so we could see clearly the beautiful view of the lake and mountain. Highly recommended if you have time!
Nice 45 min trip with very pleasant scenery and some views of Fuji. Makes a good day combined with the ropeway

The winter weather was very kind and we enjoyed a calm, beautiful ride in the ship. With plenty of vantage points to see the impressive scenery, including Mt. Fuji, the boat is very popular. Actually there are about four of these and they ply their routes to and fro across Lake
Although cramped on that Sunday, the short ride was refreshing with the breeze taking off the cramped queues earlier. The view of Mt Fuji was spectacular, if you are lucky to spy it.
I like it the boat trip. It takes around 15 minutes, but it is very nice mainly if you are lucky and able to see the Mt. Fuji.

Interesting and fun mode of transport to bring you across the lake. It's about 35mins long for a trip. Good views of Mt Fuji on a clear day. A must-do! If you've a freepass, do a return trip for the fun of it!
Cool way to ride across lake Ashi. Value for money with Hakone pass. Can be rather crowded at times. If u wanna get seats, try to go early and be at the dock to wait for the boat.
After a ride in the ropeway it's a pleasant hour on the water. Nice view and overall enjoyable experience.

The ship sails from one end of Lake Ashi to the other end, with a stop on the way. It is a large ship, and probably because of that, the ship does not cruise close to shore. At a distance, we cannot see clearly the coastline features nor the lovely scenery. With so many tourists

If you are in japan or visit japan in autum(November) you should not skip hakone trip!!! You can take the train from tokio to there about 2hours by train. It is very beautiful, you will be travel by ship about 20km to see the moutain, a red and yello moutain, if you are lucky,

I liked it. It provided a great view of the lake and it was a comfortable way to travel instead of on a bus or train, all squeezy... Although I would make sure to purchase the 4000yen pass, otherwise paying separately, I probably wouldn't have done it. The first level is
My family was visiting for the holidays so we went to Hakone for a few days. The pirate ship is a must. Something cool to do on the lake. Easy to find & can park at the port.
This is a cool way to get around lake Ashi. It is a ferry to get you around the three major towns. The price is included in your Hakone Free Pass.
Enjoyable with great sceneries. We did a round trip and it took around 45mins. The upper deck have statues of pirates and great view of the lake.

The pirate ship is one of the transport modes you will use if you make a round trip using the Hakone one day pass. You also get to use cable cars, funicular railway and local train so it's well worth buying. The ship itself is ok, not authentic in case you thought it might be.

This ship can be found at the final stop of the Hakone ropeway, travelling along Lake Ashi. There is a second class and a first class deck and there is a pirate walking around entertaining the children. It looks spectacular and it is quite fun to travel on and watch the

Great way to wrap up touring around Hakone to see the sites of the lake from water level. The boats are very cool (they run 3 different ones) and I found it a great way to transit from the southern part of the lake to the northern to get back to my hotel.

Initially I was shocked at how fast this ship was going, but realized they were running fast to pick up more people in the second port. After that initial burst of speed, the cruise becomes more chill and scenic. End to end the tour is 40 minutes. Worth it.

This is a very busy attraction and you'll need to deal with some crowds. But the ship is impressive and on a sunny day you'll get an amazing view of Lake Ashi and the surrounding mountains. You can also get off at some stops and explore another part of Hakone, usually with good

While it was a novel way to cross Lake Ashi, it really was like being on a ferry that looked like a pirate ship. It was very busy and difficult to get a seat. We had to stand for the journey. I think this would provide stunning scenery when the weather is good / clear but low

Take a small cruise on the lake in this nicely decorated and grandiose pirate boat is a great way to end your day trip/trip in Hakone. You can take it one way and then from there take a bus back to Hakone JR station or you can take 2 ways and go back to where you got on!

Pirate ship is magnificent. There is a lower level, middle level, and upper deck that is outside with plenty of seating. They also have a VIP seating area if you buy the more expensive ticket. Nice to see the beautiful greens and mountains. There were a lot of kids so this is a
Although it's a bit raining when I arrive there. But it's recommended to go up where you can enjoy the view more than inside the ship.

Not much special about this cruise. I need to take this to bring me to a museum. For kids this may look fun. For adults, really not much interesting. Indeed, we felt like a bit ripped off to pay that much to take the ship.
It's a leg of the Hakone touring route and well worth it. One of several pirate ships sail Lake Ashi. Great views from the top deck and plenty of picture opportunities.

Visited Hakone on an escorted tour of Japan and took a trip on the pirate ship. Not sure of the relevance of a pirate ship on the lake but it was quite atmospheric in the fog. Don't sit downstairs, get up on deck and enjoy the breeze. Great for families with kids I would say.

The Hakone Sightseeing Ship takes you from Togendai station, where the Hakone Ropeway ends, across Lake Ashi and stops at Hakone-machi and Moto-hakone. It's a nice ride, on a large ship,you can sit inside or on deck. we sat on deck there is lots to see. The green energy the blue
After our gondola ride up the mountain we went back to the lake to enjoy about an hour cruising Lake Ashi. The ship had its own pirate captain to entertain us.

Captain Pirate is on board mingling and happy to have his photo taken with tourists. Relaxing cruise The water is pristine but we didn't see any Black Bass or trout😞 which are inhabitants of Lake Ashi.

Took this cruise from Hakone Machi to Togendai then continued onto rope way to cable car, then back again. The view from lake Ashi is just beautiful. Too bad we couldnt get to see Mt. Fuji because it was quite cloudy outside.

See my review of Ashi Lake. The Pirate Ship is the 'ferry' I refer to and is a fantastic way to see this spectacular lake. The ship is in immaculate condition, very comfortable seating inside and plenty of space for everyone on the upper decks....and the first class lounge area
This is a very well decorated and done up pirate ship. Spare the extra yen and get the first class ticket to enjoy great views and photo takings.

It's a bit odd having a Caribbean-style pirate-themed boat on a Japanese lake. But obviously, someone's decided that it's a good idea as there are in fact three separate vessels ferrying passengers through the day across Lake Ashi between Togendai and Hakone-Machi. And with
Ok. It's funny. Does it need a pirate ship on this lake ? Not sure. It just doesn't fit my taste :-) If you have a freepass, go for it

Very touristic. Modern boats built with some romantic glimpse at European sailing ships. For me it was a way to get from the rope way to the village. It did not cost me anything as the Hakone pass was valid at the boats.

hubby didn't want to do this bc seems so touristy . that it is, but it also a very easy & pretty way to cross the lake (much better than car sickness on the bus or train). the views are lovely & you get to take a picture with a Japanese pirate- how many time sin you relief can

It was a lovely sunny morning, perfect for a cruise around Lake Ashi. Even better it is included in the pride of the Hakone free pass. We just went one way. The cruise was smooth and quiet. Staff were helpful and food and drinks were available for purchase. Perfect position to
With a number of choices by the lake, we opted to take the cruise to the other end of the lake and cable car and train home. Easy easy.
fun for the family, they only start every 40 mins so plan accordingly. The view was beautiful, it gets foggy halfway through the trip but we enjoyed it anyways

Worth the trip across the lake, for the scenery and the fun of the boat. On a hot day, we had a lovely breeze on the water. Make sure you have the Hakone Free Pass to travel on this, and many other things

The pirate cruise was on the tour itinerary and I thought it was going to be hokey. I have to admit, it was very enjoyable. The cruise was free due to our Hakone passes but we decided to upgrade to 1st class, $4, that allowed access to the front of the boat. We got the Black

I bought the first class ticket. As informed, the difference is that I got the chance to view at the front deck compared to the normal ticket. This can be purchased with about 400 yen TOP up with Hakone freepass. Good thing is that you do not need to squeeze with the crowd to
We spent some time sailing on the lake and we enjoyed the couple of hours looking around the area. It's great for kids and people who like fake pirate ships.
Very colourful ship and the distance is just nice about 20 min. We enjoyed the ship ride. You can buy day pass and take the ship ride unlimited to another route.
nice ship one had a cannon very large with a lift to different levels as well as steps. sone commentry in english

We took this cruise on a recent visit to the Hakone area. The fees were included in a two-day transportation pass to the area that we bought and had we not had the pass, we might have skipped this attraction. The boat seemed a bit over the top with a pirate theme. Nonetheless, I

We took one of the pirate ships for a short cruise round Lake Ashi and apart from the views of the surrounding countryside and Fuji, if its a clear day not much else to see. Some good picture opportunities however on board, and sure the kids would love it.

I got a free ticket from my in law, if not I would find toy looking pirate ship a little to childish for my taste. I wish it was more like a Japanese Pirate Junk with entertaining crew members (Maybe a Japanese Johny Depp impersonator?), than the cartoon pirate of the Caribbean

If you have the Hakone free pass this is a good way of getting across lake Ashi. I would regard it as a transportation vessel, rather than something fun and entertaining. But with that said - maybe it is better on a clear day. The day we traveled with the ship it was cloudy,

For me, this is the prettiest way to see Hakone from one end to another. Also the easiest. (The streets are winding and if you get on a full bus it can get hairy. Also views from the bus are obstructed most of the time). The ships are meant to be atmospheric and it does

There are few of these ships (I saw green, red and brown colored ships) taking tourist cruising the lake Ashi. There is someone dressed as pirate for photo together. It is very expensive if you don't have Hakone free pass. ¥1000 for one way or ¥1840 return trip from Togendai to
Had a lot of fun with my 10 year old nephew. First class was worth it. You get a nice new from the front of the ship. The have snacks and drinks on there.

The cruise was smooth sailing , partly thanks to the great weather. However, it was a cloudy day and Mt fuji is nowhere to be seen. A big disappointment. There are ample of seats available in the cruise including both indoors and outdoors. It is definitely worth a short sail
We took the vessel with the idea of being able to get a good view of Fujiyama, unfortunately weather and volcanic activity prevented that, but the trip, not long, was safe and enjoyable.

From the outset, it looks like an impressive replica of a pirate ship but once you set foot inside, it is basically just another ferry. There is 1 pirate captain on board for one to take pictures mainly for kids. There is an inside seating area as well as an outdoor deck area

Relaxing cruise on Lake Ashi - beautiful views and just a nice time. 45 min on the boat. Get Hakone Free Pass at Odawara train station You can use it on the following 1. Tozan Line (train from Odawara to Gora) 2. Tozan Bus 3. Tozan Cable Car 4. Ropeway 5. Sightseeing Cruise
I really enjoyed these boats. The navigation is smooth, and we had trips on a rainy day without any problem. It was beautiful anyway😃

A very pleasant cruise across the lake high up in the mountains. Can be a bit crowded in the cheap seats with everyone wanting to be on deck. Perhaps if your lucky you will see Fuji as it was noit visible on our trip.

We went with our two small boys and they will remember this pirate ship ride for some time. There's two ships docked at Lake Ashi and both look gorgeous. It helped that our boys are into the manga "One Piece" so we spent some time discussing if Monkey D Luffy's ship would look

Love the ship from outside and inside. The interior were so pretty and antiques too. Kids loved it and so did we. The lift inside was great for wheelchair and seniors. We had a nice 45mins cruise on it.

The boats are designed like Pirate ships of yore. Kids will enjoy recalling their favourite pirate be it Jack Sparrow or Long John Silver. The boat has a first class section and an ordinary class. The ordinary class has 4 decks, with seating on the second deck. The third deck

30 mins relaxing cruise @ Lake Ashino! From Hakone-machi port to Motohakone port, we could see nice view of lake Ashino & mt Fuji. As cable cars operated only between Togendai which is the another end of cruise, and Owakudani, we took return cruise. I would be better if there

It was fun to go on the boat along the lake ... the boat ride was 30 minutes and very little information. Destined to hakone machi. Only a few coffee shops but one lovely shop selling handmade wooden items which was wonderful. Only stayed 20 minutes as nothing to do! .. trip

One of those things you just have to do and try and explain when you get home. Great views of lake and surrounding area but need to get a window seat. Catch bus from rail station then pirate ship then rope way and then train back to start.
The pirate ship was a nice way to get from one end of the lake to the other. You can use your Hakone free pass to get on it so that's a bonus.

A nice one hour ride . Not an amazing view of the Fuji if that's what you're after but definitely a fun ride over a nice lake The boat is fairly big and not bumpy at all so we didn't feel any sea sickness
Just a foot ferry really but looked like a pirate ship, 'Captain' dresses up & walks around posing for photos, and is accompanied by their own photography.

We had a sail on this ship as part of a tour itinerary. It was absolutely torrential rain and we could barely see the shore never mind the scenery. So worth it only if weather is good. We were all huddled below decks. I am not sure whether you can be ondeck in good weather.

It's included in Hakone free pass so it's worth a try. I recommend going from Togenda-Ko pier and getting off at Hakonemachi-Ko pier. Then you can continue to walk to Onshihakone Park to enjoy the view of Mt Fuji.

The ship is rather crowded, so I would recommend getting to the top early to be able to get a good spot for taking photos if that's your thing. On a good day you get a decent view of Mt Fuji- obviously this is an attraction that works well in good weather. On the day we visited

We used hakone free pass to board the pirate ship. The ship has three stories. There is an elevator for senior and handicap person. It takes 30 minutes from Togendai to Hakonemachi. They have a small shop selling some snack& drinks (a little high price). Ashi lake is very large,

The sight-seeing cruise was nice, but the weather was absolutely terrible. As an avid photographer I did not have many chances for good pictures. I could not see any of the mountains further away. Weather can't be controlled so this is no fault of their own of course. I

The cruise didn't really appeal to me perhaps because it was too crowded with tourists. The weather wasn't very good on the day l took the cruise so the view from the ship wasn't fantastic. Hence l alighted at the first stop. But l guess the cruise will appeal to kids who wish
It is an average ride on nice lake created 3000 years ago. Probably great ride for the kids. All the destinations can be accessed via the tozen bus

We took the bus to the start of the Hakone Ropeway and were disappointed that the ropeway was closed from the first stop so after taking the ropeway (which is actually a cable car) to the first stop and back again, we had lunch and then decided to take this across Lake Ashi to
Caught the ferry while visiting Hakone and was impressed with the pirate ships they had. Caught the ship from one end of the lake to the other. Good day out even though the weather was miserable.

As part of quite a big Hakone round trip I took the ship. It is free for those with the Hakone Free Pass. From Togendai to the other end of the lake it takes 30 minutes, where you can get off, or an additional 10 minutes to Moto Hakone. I paid 400 yen for a first class
We loved that it was a pirate ship on the lake. It was such a relaxing ride. The boat was warm inside too.
Great views of Mount Fuji and a very calm crossing was quick and a big boat. Staff are great, Hakone Free Pass was great to get about with

From my own experience I'd only rate this a transport, not an attraction. It's a ferry boat, admittedly a rather decorative one, but it was a ferry. I'm not sure what other ways there were to cross the lake but that's what we were offered when we were dropped off by the bus.

This tour was so great!! We had breathtaking views of Mt. Fuji and got to explore Hakone and eat black eggs and black ice cream!! It was just the two of us on this trip but it would be great for kids too! The pirate ship is awesome too!!

We took the 'pirate boat' across the lake and back as it suited our journeying - otherwise one trip would have been enough. We had to queue for a long time for one of the journeys. It's a fun vessel and families seemed to be enjoying it. Some good views. Good, rather than very
Travelers : My family of 6. My husband and I with 4 kids. 17, 14, 12 and 9. We boarded the pirate ship when we visited lake Ashi. Cool ship with a clean interior.
took a bus from hakone yumoto station to hakone machi and rode one way to togendai as we were staying at hakone lake hotel. try to choose a sunny day for best view.

First up, the cruise and views were all spectacular and for visitors to Hakone, this cruise is a must-take for the photographs and scenic views. It was freezing since we were on it on Dec 22. You could go up to the deck for photos and enjoy the chilling breezes, or you could

Part of our trip around Hakone and not to be missed. The lake is about 25 m deep and formed by volcanic activity. You are surrounded by seismic activity - Mt Hakone (currently active), the onsen spas and even Mt Fuji. The location is very picturesque and a must do leg of your

Must do! Lovely to get beautiful scenic photos on this ship. Remember, get the one or two day Hakone pass for this trip. U will safe a lot when using the public transportation, this inclusive. Snacks and drinks are sold on board. Do note too that there are two 'arrival' jetties.
We bought Hakone pass which includes this ship trip. Along the lake, we can clearly see the Fuji Mt (it was a perfect sunshine day!).

We went there in November and it's really cold and windy specially if you want to see the view from the top part of the ship. There are no long queue as there are several ship servicing the tourist. You can ride the ropeway right after the sightseeing tour.
A relaxing way to tour Hakone, similar to the boat ride at Lake Como in Italy. Too bad we didn't see Mt Fuji due to cloud.
The ship was modelled after the royal Vasa ship from Sweden, which was fun and strange. The view from the ship was great and it was a convinient way to get across the lake
It was quite an enjoyable ride on the sightseeing ship, and the staffs were efficient and punctual in the operation of the ship.
At first we were excitedly queuing for our turn to board. But perhaps due to the large crowd we fell asleep sometime in the cruise journey. There was nothing special to shout about.

Cold and a bit windy ok the open deck. Beautiful lake, and not too busy this time of the year. Great for us. Cable car arrival and Balt departure time is synchronized which is great but does mean you have to hurry.

The cruise ship takes you along the river with a nice view of Mt Fuji (depends on the time of year/day of course) and of the Hakone shrine gates. It is motorised so doesn't sway in the water, which is vital for me since I'm prone to motion sickness. The boat leaves and arrives

the boat ride is nice way to end the route of the hakone free pass, the cable car finishing is route at the waiting room for the boat ride. the boat is just a gimmick design as pirate ship, but still its nice ride on the amazing lake and another way to see the scenery. day

nothing special about it. You can enjoy the beautiful views without having to go onboard. it is a way to get to the other side of the lake Ashi though (but not cheap). there are other ways to get there (bus..).
Nothing much to add to past reviewers. Found the ship gimmicky, but go for the views of Lake Ashi, not the ship.

We are a family of 4 from Australia with two daughters aged 13 and 11 and thoroughly enjoyed the cruise we took on the pirate ship on Lake Ashi. The tickets for first class were not much more than standard price so we lashed out and cruised first class. We were the only ones in

Nice and quiet boat trip on lake Ashi, stepped of in Hakone-Machi-Ko an took a walk to the neighboring village, a bit overpriced I guess but ok. When we where here the rope-way was unfortunately closed due to increased seismic activity in the area.

Went to take this sightseeing ship and never regret it, the ship was quite well maintained and it has a lift inside the ship too! The view was really very nice and breathtaking and you could see Mt Fuji at a certain part and the lake was really beautiful! Go all the way up to
Try to catch it as the sunsets. It can be breath taking. But it will get a little chilly at that time. But there are 2 floors on the inside for u too sit if it the deck gets too crowded

It's a very unique experience to take the ship to cruise the Lake Ashi. The ship, Royal II, is a first-class warship with beautiful red and white colors. The duration of the route from Togendai port to Hakone-machi port is around 45 minutes. In good weather, you can see Fuji

We surprised ourselves by enjoying our trips across the lake - we boarded as a means of transport but were unsure what to expect from a ship that looks like it came from a Disney-film. No worries, there were no costumed characters to intrude on the scenic mountain beauty, just

Ahoy jim lad! Use the Hakone free pass to save queuing up! It's a pirate ship on lake Ashi......it's just a great fun adventure....everyone on board was happy and smiling! I didn't see johnny depp though :(

Shaped just like a pirate ship, this one isn't hard to miss. Friends and I purchased tickets for this boat to take us around to Togendai before we made our way up to Owakudani. It's a very scenic ride out on Lake Ashi and perfect for families (visited in May 2012)
These ferries modeled on pirate ships are a great way to get around the lake and are a hit with kids. It's included in the Hakone Freepass.
The ship was a great way to cross the lake, although the pirate theme is a bit kitsch, but probably fun for kids.

Free and nice pirates ship ride if you grabbed "Hakone Pass" before starting your trip :) You can get great view outside deck but do remember to bring a jacket and hold-on your stuff else staying indoor also not that bad. Ashi lake is so beautiful, pray for a less crowded ship
You can use Hakone free pass for unlimited access. On a (very) clear day you can see mount fuji. Try free food samples at the port.
It was interesting to ride a prirate ship to get to the other side of the lake. The view looking out was very nice. You could either sit inside or outside and there were 2 levels. Fun to ride!

There is no getting around how touristy this idea is of having pirate boats go back and forth. However, it is a good way to get from one side of the lake to the other. Also if you purchase the "Free Hakone" pass for about $40 it is included. I do recommend that, since you can

We went on the Hakone Pirate Ship as part of the Mt Fuji day tour with Sunrise Tours. My daughter loved it. Just like Jake the Neverland Pirate. The scenery on the cruise is good from the outside decks. Bring a jacket as it gets very windy outside. You might get blown overboard.

This boat sucks because we couldn't get on it. Of all the pamphlets given to us, nowhere does it mention in either Japanese or English that the last boat leaves the pier at 5 PM, which means that you have to be physically at the dock at 4:55 PM. I really respect Japanese

The trip to the lake was stunning scenery and then I wasn't exited at the fake Pirate ship but forget that the 30min cruise was a highlight of the trip the lake is so beautiful. And if your in the area or going on this then dont miss it its a sight seeing trip you will love ,

Hakone Sightseeing Ship traverses over Ashinoko, between Hakone-machi and the bottom of Mt. Hakone, and it is a very pleasant ride. You can walk around the whole ship to search for the best viewing spot, and the surroundings around Ashinoko are absolutely beautiful.

A relaxing 30 minutes to enjoy the lake and the hidden views only seen from the ship looking at the shore. Best spot is the top deck but ensure to bring a jacket in case of windy conditions. An old pirate ship look adds to the thrill of it.

The ship is so beautiful!! We don't see outside much as the fog is heavy. If the fog is worse, it ride to Moto-Hakone only (not go to Hakone-Machi) as safety come first. No choice to get bus to Hakone-Machi.

It was clear, but cold and windy. But fortunately, by the time we got through the line and onto the sightseeing ship, there were no more spaces where we could see the sights, such as they were. Instead we were crowded toward the center of the stern where we were partially
very nicely decorated ship, the top deck(3rd floor) is a standing only area, but u have full view of the surroundings not blocked by anything. get your hakone travel pass, this is included in

We took a return journey from Togendai port. It took 30 minutes to Moto-Hakone and another 10 minutes to Hakone-Machi. We would suggest taking the cruise on q clear sunny day - so you will be able to see Mt Fuji together with the Hakone Shrine as a classic picture!

On a beautiful fine day in spring, we have been to Hakone, using the Hakone Free Pass which is a special pass for exploring Hakone serviced by Odakyu Railways. After sightseeing Owakudani, we took the Hakone Ropeway to Togendai. This Ropeway gave us a magnificent view of Mt.

Visited on March 2015 with a group of family and friends. After walking adventure, finally we can rest our legs for 45mins. With a big pirate ship, we were traveling from the pier to catch our bus to Hakone Yumoto. Great view and a must visit if you have Hakone Free Pass.

I really enjoyed the cruise on board the pirate ship. Just being out in the water on a ship really takes you to another place(figuratively and literally). Besides the ship, I think seeing Mt. Fuji while sailing along lake Ashi just adds to the trip. No rough seas here, just

A drive from mount fuji to hakone would remind you of the picturesque landscape of switzerland. During autumn u see leaves of all colors and hues. Its a dream drive thru the silver grass of Hakone , in autumn. In case u take a conducted tour from Tokyo, pl avoid the lunch
Raining day to make this trip be more memorable . Heavy rain to make us can't see the mt fuji. But inside the boat is pretty n comfortable . There selling drinks and snack , take around 40 mins .

The grandiose look of the ships goes perfectly with the setting ,the lake ,Mt Fuji in The distance ,picture postcard . That aside the ships are very spacious ,makes for A fantastic photo Opp . The service is timely ,there is also a first class section for A price . A small
The title pretty much sums it up! Some good views but overall pretty average boat ride although a good way to complete a loop around the hakone sites.
It was an average boat ride in the lake. Definitely worth to stand on the deck and enjoy the beautiful scenery.

If you are in the area and have the Hakone pass then you might as well as it forms part of the tourist route along with the cable cars. As for the boat ride, the views are quite nice but nothing breathtaking in my opinion. We went first class so that we could see the views

It was a fun ride, especially for the kids (age 5 and 7). We got the first class tickets (only a few dollars more with the Hakone Free Pass), and I'd say it was well worth it! You got seats right at the very front. Make sure you board early so you can grab those front seats.

Arrived at the harbour after alighting from the ropeway. The ride is most welcome after all the tiring bus and train rides around the areas. Have a moment of peace and enjoy the view as the ship cruised across the lake and arrived at Hakone-machi.

This was a calm cruise within a hectic holiday in Japan. As the weather had been poor the previous day the ship was not crowded - plenty of good seating to enjoy the views; fairly good commentary in english and easy walk via the Cedar Path to next port which has lots of shops

The Hakone Sightseeing Ship takes you from Togendai station, where the Hakone Ropeway ends, across Lake Ashi and stops at Hakone-machi and Moto-hakone. It's a pleasant ride, a large ship, plenty of seating inside, but not many on the deck. You can catch a good view of the
I like the lake cruise. I can see a temple, some boats, nice scenic view from 2nd floor. Even though so crowded but I enjoyed the trip.

I never expected to enjoy this lake cruise. But to my surprise, it was really something else. You can see a temple out of nowhere!!! Then we stopped at a resort, boarded our bus for a cable car ride. After the cable car ride, we were told to try this sulfur cooked eggs,

Lake Ashi and the surrounding mountains are beautiful, and from the sightseeing boat you have a lovely view. Don't get your hopes up about seeing Mt. Fuji -- it's really a luck of the draw, even in the winter (when you have the most chance of seeing it). The boat is decorated

If there is any cruise to ask that should be missed for tourists, it will be this Hakone Kankosen / Sightseeing ship!!! Cruising the Lake Ashinoko, and giving a 360 degree all round view of the lake waters, dun miss it!!!
The cruise on Lake Ashinoko is splendid! Definitely worth it!!! U get to see the majestic views all around and never get bored!!!

This came as a great surprise,who would have thought that in this ancient area full scale replica Spanish galleons would sit on this lovely lake. Take the trip it is well worth the hour or so then head off up the cable car route to the Volcanic area and buy a pack of Black

Had a wonderful boat ride on Lake Ashi. We try to take a boat trip on every vacation we go on. This one is on our list of top 10 best boat rides. The boats are unique and fun to be on. Young kids will love this. Bring a camera and enjoy the ride. We rode to the opposite
A tacky pirate ship themed ferry provides a convenient way to cross the lake. and thats about it!
The boat ride across the lake is not to be missed. Lovely scenery, beautiful views and even a real life pirate for the kids. Thoroughly enjoyable!

the ships themselves are just beautiful, and the lake and surroundings are really spectacular with Mt. Fuji looming ahead. There are 3-4 ships, and they are all equally great. Journey is about 30 mins and well worth it.
Can get cold on teh decks if teh air temperature is low - but its great fun. Drinks on board are a bit expensive...

I enjoyed the cruise immensely. But just a word of caution, do take note of the timing of the last ship. You wouldn't want to be trapped, especially during winter. It is best if you take the cruise in the earlier part of the day, then move on to other sights you have in mind.
Although not spectacular, it was a nice, quiet cruise around the lake. Very peaceful.
nothing special. but if you want to complete the route, you need to get on it. the pirate like ship looks excited for kids (i think). other than that, it's a ship.

Standing on the deck with cool winds blowing on my face, I felt so refreshed. We're crossing Lake Ashi in one of the experiences we will never forget for the rest of our lives. Take note: 1) You have to pay extra money to have your pic taken with the man dressed up as a
This is a fun way to explore the Hakone area. It can get cold on the water even in sunlight when its warm elsewhere. The first class area is not worth the extra money.

This is the infamous pirate boat on lake Ashi. It runs relatively frequently but the last rides are usually before sunset so plan accordingly. Most people will will take the ropeway to Togendai then catch the next boat. If you have the Hakone Freepass (sold by Odakyu) you can
google: Great way to get a distant shot of the torii gate. Plus it was relaxing. I was able to buy a beer on the ship and not have to worry about the bus schedule.
It was fun and had a nice view from pirate ship. I didn’t see the mt fuji because kf the clouds. Sad.
Not much to say. Cruise on a boat, nothing more, nothing less. No commentary during the travel. Beautiful lake and Mount Fuji if the sky is clear enough. The cruise is about 30 minutes long.

There are scheduled times for the lake tours, so be sure to catch it. I took one of the last ones (4pm+) to get the last glimpse of the views. As I visited in the autumn, hours are short.

Must do when visiting Hakone. A beautiful lake and glimpses of Mt Fuji. Great photos. Go First Class for a bit of extra yen, well worth the upgrade to get away from the crowd and better position for photos. Compared to the cable car (waste of time and money) this cruise is highly recommended.

Relaxing boat, I mean, ferry trip from the north side of the lake, to the south. It took about 25 minutes and there are different "cabins" though I believe I was in the standard cabin, right below the deck. You are also able to stay above …

Very efficient and unique way to travel the lake. I recommend getting to the port early if it is cold outside so you can have a good seat inside the boat. Wouldn’t bother paying extra for first class, not much benefits.
good way to go around lake Ashi.  Reasonable price. Waiting time for each ship is short. VIP for front seat is available and not too expensive, affordable. there are 3 ports to choose to board.

Hakone was one of the best autumn destination..
We took the pirate ship on Togendai port where we reached via ropeway ..
The cruise experience was awesome ..
It was a decked cruise with pirate themed open arena on top...

The pirate ship ride was included on our Mt Fuji tour. It has beautiful sights of the lake. But it is something you can surely skip if you are not taking a tour. The nearby city looks very interesting and have many souvenirs stores and spa …

Very beautiful place. It wasn't very crowded so the pirate ship feels really comfortable. Bought normal tickets. Should have bought first class tickets as it is more luxurious. Seating space is also separated for first class tickets. You …

Awesome bit of history and a fun way to travel. Certainly a novelty, but the kids had a blast and you get to see a lot of views normally not seen by driving. Worth the upgrade to get the first class starting and access to the deck.
Beautiful place, must go if you come to Japan

With the Hakone freepass you can take unlimited rides on the pirate ship. It is a fuss-free and convenient way to get around easier. Make sure you get a view on the deck of the ship before heading to rest in the cabins below.

Good trip. Good for children. One way is about 1050¥. Trip is about half an hour. At one end you can go to Temple. Other end go to cable car to mountain. The lake is surrounded by mountains. Beautiful scenery. The ship is really like pirate …
A fun way to see all of Hakone! There are three stops in total, and you can get off and on as you like.
Great ride. I recommend buying the extra for the first class seat. You get a great view of the river and mountains around.

Very comfortable and big shop with plenty of seats both indoor and at deck. Beautiful view when the ship is sailing on the lake. 

The ship travels in one loop so stay in the shop throughout if u want to take the rope way back to Gora.
This is a beautiful ship, which looks like a Pirate ship. Lake is really beautiful as well.

Amazing views, this was one of the best expirences i had when travelling around japan simply breathtaking. It is well worth upgrading to first class, the standard class was really full but 1st class was empty only 3 families including mine …

Great ride and exceptionnaly nice ships to do the transfer. Was not expecting that. Nice view on Mount Fuji when their are no clouds.

Interesting travel option. Clean and comfortable just like every other form of transportation in Japan.

Good ferry service to get across the lake. The pirate ships are somewhat out of place here, but they are fun as a tourist attraction and offer a great view of the lake and Mount Fuji if you are lucky with the weather/clouds.
It was a great experience. The view of Mt. Fuji and the mountains is magnificent. The ship it self is very beautiful and when you purchase Hakone free pass the entrance fee is Free.
The cruise will take you from Togendai to Hakone-machi and onwards to Moto-hakone before ending at the same pier. Quite a relaxing and scenic ride

For the nature around it was pretty neat. Taking the other boat on the lake did however go to a ropeway leading to a great viewpoint (which this did not).

You can buy ordinary ticket or first class. The first class gives you access to a reserved place. If the boat is not very crowded this is not worth. The trip is nice if combined with the train and cable car tour of the park. Ship is clean and fancy

Amazing ride to enjoy the beauty of the Lake Ashi. At the end of the ride u will see the Mount Fuji view.
It's a nice cruise. If you have the Hakone free pass it's free and worth it. Otherwise I will likely not buy it. It drops you off on the other side of the lake depending on where you take it.

trip: This is a small geo museum and is relatively near the gift and restaurant stops. It charges a nominal fee and you can pretty much read and view everything in about an hour. It gives a good insight in the developement of the volcanic activity, sulphur vents and hotsprings etc.
I wish we had more time to visit this nice and interesting small museum, but the bus was due to leave. Give yourself some time. Not everything is translated into English
Cost 100 yen, which was good value for a really informative small museum. Plenty of English descriptions

A small museum but small entrance fee, was just 100 yen, the illustrations and working models are good, they explain in Japanese and English the geology of the area. It is suitable for the young and old.
The museum is not large, but it presents its content quite impressively. It makes you shiver a little to learn the history of the volcano you are currently standing upon.
Even if you are not into museums this is worth a stop. You will learn that the Onsen hotsprings water is artifically made, and how it is done, as well as learn about the geology of the area.

This is nice small museum with loads of information and fun for kids. You will learn about the history of hakone area and some replicas of how the hot spring works. There are also some classic pictures dated back to 1926. Time to spend 20 - 30 mins is enough for me. Worth to

Hakone area is called a Geo Park designated by the government. Owakudani, for example was formed approximately 3,000 years ago. This area around Mt. Kamiyama erupted subsequently a still volcanic fumes of hydrogen sulfur emitted. Geo Museum is good lesson place to know overview.

Small museum at The Owakudani stop on the Hakone Ropeway. 100 yen and it will explain what you see outside in the sulphur fields in a fun interactive way. Microscope samples, working models, interactive experiments. 20-30 minutes to walk through.

Don't miss this museum if you are interested in volcanoes or the local geological history of the area. Small but good English language explanations - plenty of models and for only 100 yen well worth the time to understand what you are looking at outside the museum.

The museum can be done in around 30 minutes but is nevertheless worth a visit. At the price of ¥100 per person it is practically free (someone on this site said that with the Hakone free pass entrance IS free, but this is incorrect) and is more than worth what you see. The

Interactive museum with clear explanations about the geological history of the area. Clearly explained in English, so that even non-geologists can understand. A lot of models and pictures. Only 100 yen.

its got free entry on one day. cant remember which day we went but it was free we were so happy. its an interesting place and then there are beautiful views from around it and its quite cold there too.. its on top of the hill. have fun. i want to go back there.

there was nothing much to see unless you want to learn by reading all of the details provided . Close by to the stores if you need to get some souvenirs

Neat the cable car and adjacent to the hot springs lies the museum complex. A good place to learn about the area and how the springs work and see some localculture

我預定的旅館在仙石原，在查看地圖的時候發現了這座有一個中式的名字——“長安”佛教寺院。因為我對中日兩國之間的歷史和文化非常感興趣，就將這座古寺納入旅程。 儘管日本的佛教是從唐朝時期的中國傳入的（根據我們的課本），但這座佛教寺院並沒有完全照搬中國的，而是在部份程度上日本化了。 -中國：寺院入口處不用洗手；長安寺：像進神社之前，需要先洗手。 -中國：在中國的寺廟裡似乎沒有普通民眾的墓（我個人從未見過，如有異議，歡迎提出）；長安寺：寺廟的後山上有許許多多墓碑（因為去的時候天色已晚，我獨自一人不敢靠近墓地）。 -中國：參拜時不用搖鈴；長安寺：有搖鈴的設施。

text.wiki:
Hakone (箱根町, Hakone-machi) is a town in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. As of June 2012, the town had an estimated population of 13,492, and a population density of 145 persons per km². The total area is 92.82 km2 (35.84 sq mi). Hakone has been designated as a Japanese National Geopark by the Japanese Geoparks Network.
Hakone is to a great degree regarded as a traveler destination; Mt. Fuji can be seen when taking a day trip from Tokyo. In addition to hot springs, museums and other recreation activities, Hakone is known for its scenery during all four seasons.


== Geography ==
Hakone is located in the mountains in the far west of the prefecture, on the eastern side of Hakone Pass. Most of the town is within the borders of the volcanically active Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, centered on Lake Ashi.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture

Odawara
Yugawara
Minami-ashigaraShizuoka Prefecture

Gotemba
Susono
Mishima
Oyama
Kannami


== History ==
Hakone is the location of a noted Shinto shrine, the Hakone Gongen, which is mentioned in Heian period literature. During the Genpei War, Minamoto no Yoritomo prayed at this shrine for victory over his enemies, after his defeat at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, which was fought in neighboring Manazuru. As with the rest of Sagami Province, the area came under the control of the later Hōjō clan of Odawara during the Sengoku period. After the start of the Edo period, Hakone-juku was a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto. It was also the site of a major barrier and official checkpoint on the route known as the Hakone Checkpoint (箱根関所, Hakone sekisho), which formed the border of the Kantō region. Under the Tokugawa shogunate, all travellers entering and leaving Edo along the Tōkaidō were stopped here by officials. Their travel permits and baggage were examined to enforce Tokugawa laws that restricted the travel of women and weapons.
After the start of the Meiji Restoration, Hakone became a part of the short-lived Ashigara Prefecture before becoming part of Ashigarashimo District in Kanagawa prefecture in August 1876. Hakone attained town status in 1889. The imperial household established the summer Hakone Imperial Villa close to the lake.
After merger with five neighboring towns and villages in September 1956, it reached its present boundaries.


== Economy ==

The economy of Hakone is strongly dominated by the tourist industry. Hakone is noted for its onsen hot spring resorts, which attract both Japanese and international visitors, due to its proximity to the greater Tokyo metropolis and to Mount Fuji. Sights include the volcanically active Ōwakudani geysers and Hakone Shrine on the shore of the lake, as well as the Hakone Botanical Garden of Wetlands. In April the cherry blossoms (sakura) and in autumn the Miscanthus sinensis (susuki) are noted sights.
Hakone has a number of art museums, including the Hakone Open-Air Museum and Pola Museum of Art.
Major events include the annual JLPGA CAT Ladies Golf tournament and the Hakone Ekiden, a long distance collegiate foot race, held at the New Year, which runs from Tokyo to Hakone and back over two days, partly in commemoration of the couriers who ran the Tōkaidō road.
One famous hotel in Hakone is the historic Fujiya Hotel in Miyanoshita, which was patronized by noted literary figures, politicians and foreign dignitaries in the Meiji and Taishō and early Shōwa periods.
A noted local handicraft is a kind of marquetry called Yosegi.Hakone is also well-known among anime fans for being the main location in the manga and anime series Neon Genesis Evangelion, in which it has been renamed Tokyo-3, and there are numerous attractions related to the franchise offered in the town. In 2017, Hakone was included as one of 88 anime pilgrimage sites for 2018 by the Anime Tourism Association. In 2020, new decorations have been introduced to the city in the anticipation of the release of the final film of the Rebuild of Evangelion tetralogy.


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
Hakone Tozan Railway
Hakone Tozan Cable Car
Hakone Ropeway
Izuhakone RailwayOdawara and Mishima, the terminus of the Odakyū Odawara Line, 70 minutes from Shinjuku, Tokyo. From Odawara, the Hakone Tozan Line continues into various resort towns in Hakone. Odakyu also runs the Romancecar limited express between Shinjuku and Hakone-Yumoto. From Gōra, the terminus of Hakone Tozan Line, the Hakone Tozan Cable Car funicular goes to Sōunzan. Ōwakudani can be reached by Hakone Ropeway from Sounzan and the lake, while the lake is crisscrossed by cartoonishly decorated "pirate" ships for tourists. There is also Hakone Komagatake Ropeway, which goes to the top of Mount Komagatake.
A popular "Hakone Free Pass", allowing unlimited use of most forms of transport for several days, is available. Hakone Free Pass can be bought at Shinjuku Station, Odawara Station, any other chief station along Odakyū Odawara Line, Hakone-Yumoto Station, Gōra Station, any other chief station along Hakone Tozan Line, Sōunzan Station, Tōgendai Station, Sengoku-Annaijo Bus Stop, Moto-Hakone Port, Hakone-Machi Port, and JR Gotemba Station Bus Information.


=== Highways ===
Hakone Shindō
Japan National Route 1
Japan National Route 138


== Education ==
Private schools:

Kanrei Shirayuri Gakuen Junior/Senior High School


== Sister cities ==
 - Tōyako, Hokkaidō, since July 4, 1964
 - Jasper, Alberta, Canada from July 4, 1972
 - Taupo, New Zealand, from October 7, 1987
 - St. Moritz, Switzerland, from November 2, 2014 (Friendship City)


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		


== References ==


== External links ==
 Hakone travel guide from Wikivoyage

Official Website (in Japanese)
Hakone Portal Website
 Geographic data related to Hakone at OpenStreetMap

text.wiki:
Hakone Ekiden (箱根駅伝), which is officially called Tokyo-Hakone Round-Trip College Ekiden Race (東京箱根間往復大学駅伝競走, Tōkyō Hakone kan Ōfuku Daigaku Ekiden Kyōsō), is one of the most prominent university ekiden (relay marathon) races of the year held between Tokyo and Hakone in Japan on January 2 and 3. The race is telecast on Nippon Television.
This two-day race from Ōtemachi to Hakone and back is separated into five legs on each day.  Due to slight variations in the courses, the first day distance is 107.5 km while the distance on the second day is 109.6 km.


== Rules ==
Five legs are provided between Tokyo and Hakone each way. Each runner runs one section, and alternates with the next runner at a station. Each team has ten runners, who each run with their team's sash which is handed over to the next runner on the team at each station.
If a runner cannot get to a station within a certain time after the leading team reaches it (10 minutes for legs 1-2, 15 minutes for legs 3-4, 20 minutes for all subsequent legs), the next runner starts with a substitute sash. The time difference is added to the goal time.


=== Participation ===
Twenty universities, which belong to The Inter-University Athletic Union of Kanto (関東学生陸上競技連盟, Kantō gakusei rikujō kyōgi renmei), can participate in this Ekiden. Ten of them are seeded teams that qualify by virtue of finishing in the top ten the previous year. Nine more teams qualify through their team results at the Hakone Ekiden Yosenkai, a 20 km qualifier held in the October preceding the race. A final select team, the Kanto Region University Student United Team (関東学生連合チーム, Kantō gakusei rengō chiimu), made up of top-placing individuals at October's Yosenkai 20 km Road Race from universities that do not qualify for Hakone as teams.  The 2014 race did not include a select team, and before 2014, the select team was called the Kanto Region Select Team (関東学連選抜チーム, Kantō gakuren senbatsu chiimu), and were also constituted by a selection of top runners from universities that did not qualify as one of the 19 participating teams.


=== Seed rights ===
Teams who finished 10th place or better will be seeded and guarantees participation in the Hakone Ekiden for the next year.


=== Forfeiture ===
If a runner retires en route to a station because of an accident, his team is treated as retired. Although runners for following sections may run, their times are not officially recorded.


== Course ==


=== Day 1, January 2 ===


==== Leg 1 (21.3 km) From Ōtemachi, Tokyo to Tsurumi, Yokohama ====
The race begins at 8:00 a.m. in front of the Yomiuri Shimbun Building in Ōtemachi, Tokyo, and follows a relatively flat course past various Tokyo landmarks such as Tokyo Imperial Palace, Tokyo Station, Hibiya Park, Zōjō-ji, and the shadows of Tokyo Tower. Past Shinagawa Station, the runners will encounter some slopes at Shin-Yatsuyamabashi (新八ツ山橋) as well as Rokugōbashi (六郷橋) at the 17 km mark, before arriving at the Tsurumi relay station.
This is one of the most important sections because the first runner’s rank affects the flow of the entire ekiden for his team. As a result, teams usually enter a strong runner run in this section.


==== Leg 2 (23.1 km) From Tsurumi to Totsuka ====
After departing the Tsurumi relay station, the runners follow National Route 1 on their way to Totsuka relay station. As part of the traditional 53 Stations of the Tōkaidō, the runners will face a significant uphill climb at Gontazaka at the 13 km mark. The last 3 km section is also made up of a combination of uphill climbs and downhill descents.
As this is the longest leg of the race, the fastest runner in each team traditionally runs on this course as it has influence on the overall pace of the race. The leg is often referred to as Leg 2 of Flowers (花の2区) in reference to its often star-studded runners and status.


==== Leg 3 (21.4 km) From Totsuka to Hiratsuka ====
The first 9 km of leg is marked with a gentle descent as the course gradually departs the urban areas towards the Shōnan coastline. The runners join National Route 134 at Chigasaki, and travel along the coastline with Mt. Fuji in front of them and Sagami Bay to their left. Leg 3 finishes after the runners cross the Shonan Bridge, and reaches the Hiratsuka relay station on the coast.
Though considered to be the most scenic leg of the entire race, strong and sometimes unpredictable sea winds force runners to adapt as they exit the urban sections of the race. Like leg 2, leg 3 also often sees placements of the strongest runners of each team in order to keep pace.


==== Leg 4 (20.9 km) From Hiratsuka to Odawara ====
The shortest flat section of the race, leg 4 leads runners parallel to the Tokaido Main Line past towns of Ōiso and Ninomiya, before crossing the Sakawa River into the heart of Odawara. Passing by Odawara Castle, the last 3 km stretch of this leg sees a gradual uphill climb, a prelude to leg 5.
From 2006 to 2016, runners ran a shortened leg 4 at 18.5 km, the shortest of all legs, as organizers attempted to create a leg that would better highlight mid-distance runners of each team. However, the 20.9 km length was reinstated for the 2017 edition and has remained in place since.


==== Leg 5 (20.8 km) From Odawara to Lake Ashi, Hakone ====
After passing by Hakone-Yumoto Station, the runners run past (or in earlier editions, run through) the Kanreidoumon Gallery to begin their climbs, and pass by various Hakone sights such as the Fujiya Hotel, Hakone Kowakien, a railroad crossing for the Hakone Tozan Line, and Hakone Keimei Gakuen before reaching the highest point of National Route 1 at 16.2 km. Finally, the runners run through the town of Moto-Hakone under the Torii of Hakone Shrine at 19 km, and reach the finish line at Lake Ashi.
Colloquially called The Mountain Climb (山上り) , leg 5 is considered to be one of the most grueling sections of the race that sees runners climb up to 874 m at the highest point of leg. While almost all competitors forego tank tops and opt to dress in long sleeved apparel to combat the low temperatures, leg 5 sometimes sees runners fall to conditions such as hypothermia and hypoglycemia due to its trying nature. This legs often sees uphill specialists from each team being deployed, with many often only running this section for their universities throughout their collegiate career. Those who have consistent high finishes in this section are traditionally referred to as God of the Mountain (山の神).


=== Day 2, January 3 ===


==== Leg 6 (20.8 km) From Lake Ashi, Hakone to Odawara ====
Day 2 of the race begins at 8:00 a.m. with leg 6 being a reverse course of leg 5 from day 1, and its first 4 km section is an uphill section before rapidly descending the mountains, past the same sights as those of leg 5. The teams' coaches are not allowed to join the teams until they have reached Hakone-Yumoto Station at the base of the mountain.
As a reverse of leg 5 and colloquially called The Mountain Descent (山下り) , the downhill leg 6 is a speedy and challenging affair with average runner speeds of 25 km per hour. Runners also need to combat the morning chills of starting early in the morning atop of the mountains, and icy and slippery course conditions are not uncommon dependent on weather conditions. As a combination of these challenging conditions, leg 6 also sees a high number of specialist runners much like leg 6, and those who participate often take tolls on the their legs and feet as they reach the bottom of the mountain.


==== Leg 7 (21.3 km) From Odawara to Hiratsuka ====
A near-reverse course of leg 4, leg 7 is slightly longer than its parallel during day 1 and sees its runners leave the mountains and head to the coast near Hiratsuka on a mostly flat course with minor inclines after 9 km.
As the sun rises throughout the course of leg 7, the difference of temperature between the start in Odawara and the finish at Hiratsuka is the largest out of all other sections. Runners have to combat and adapt to the changing weather conditions as they move towards Hiratsuka.


==== Leg 8 (21.4 km) From Hiratsuka to Totsuka ====
A reverse course of leg 3, the first half of leg 8 is mostly flat, however near Fujisawa there is a significant uphill section near Yugyōji-no-saka (遊行寺の坂) which may causes some runners difficulties.
As the temperatures continue to rise, some runners fall into states of dehydration near Yugyōji-no-saka, and proper management of runners' physical conditions is critical in leading the way to a successful final 2 legs of the race.


==== Leg 9 (23.1 km) From Totsuka to Tsurumi ====
A reverse course of leg 2, leg 9 is the longest leg of day 2. After revisiting Gontazaka, now as a downhill section, the rest of the course past Hodogaya Station is a mostly flat affair leading to the Tsurumi relay station.
Like leg 2, Most teams place their second-best runners for this leg, and it is likewise called Leg 9 of Pines (松の9区) to indicate its importance. The leg is critical for leading teams to cement their lead or for trailing teams to close their distance, either in a fight for the championship or a top-10 seeding position to guarantee their return to the next year's race. Owing to the strength of runners in this sections, overtakes are not uncommon during leg 9.
Additionally, the Tsurumi relay station at the end of leg 9 is the most common place for early starts (Kuriage-sutāto (繰り上げスタート)) to occur, as teams need to reach Tsurumi within 20 minutes of the race leaders to prevent a forced early start. Because of the symbolic importance of physically relaying the Tasuki to each teammate throughout the race, emotions often run high when teams fail to do so. The 160 m clear straight section at Tsurumi exacerbates this: teams close to the 20 minute cut-off physically see their teammates near the relay station, but not all teams make the successful exchange at this final relay station.


==== Leg 10 (23.0 km) From Tsurumi to Otemachi, Tokyo ====
A near-reverse course of leg 1, and similar to the opening leg, leg 10 is largely flat as runners head towards central Tokyo. The leg follows the same course as leg 1 until the final section, where it deviates east at Babasakimon (馬場先門) in front of the Nijubashi of the Tokyo Imperial Palace before turning north on Chuo-Dori through Kyōbashi. After crossing Nihonbashi, the race returns and concludes in front of the Yomiuri Shimbun Building, where the finish line awaits.
The spectating crowds grow gradually as the race progresses through leg 10, and runners have to face strong winds between tall buildings as they enter more built-up areas of Tokyo. As the final runners of each team closes out the race, their teammates awaits them at the finish line in celebration and reflection.


== Origin ==
Hakone Ekiden was started in 1920.  Shizo Kanaguri, who is known as the father of the Japanese marathon, conceived the idea.  His enthusiastic idea of bringing up a runner who could compete in the world became the driving force of establishing Hakone Ekiden. When Kanaguri was a Tokyo Koto Shihan school (Koshi) student, he participated in Olympic Games in Stockholm in 1912 as one of the representative Japanese marathon runners.  He had to give up his race on the way, however.In the meantime, the first ekiden, Tokaido ekidentohokyoso (東海道駅伝徒歩競走) was held in 1917 between Sanjō Ōhashi, Kyoto and Ueno Shinobazunoike (上野不忍池) Tokyo, celebrating 50 years after Tokyo became the capital. This race was a big relay race between Kyoto and Tokyo (516 km) held by Yomiuri Shimbun for three days. It succeeded and became the original form of Hakone Ekiden. Kanaguri was influenced by the success of the race and persuaded many universities that they should race in the Hakone Ekiden.  As a result, Waseda Univ., Keio Univ., Meiji Univ. and Tokyo Kōshi replied to his offer and Hakone Ekiden started. Hakone Ekiden was started with great energy of the pioneers in Japanese sports society. It started during World War I, so industrial areas gradually expanded to the west and the Tokaido road was widened.  Reflecting this active atmosphere, the Japanese sports society, including ekiden one, were developing great challenging spirits at that time.


== Level of competition in 2010 ==
In the 2010 (86th) race, of the 380 athletes (190 runners and 190 alternates) that represent the 19 universities, 328 have run under 14:40 for 5,000 meters; 150 at 14:20 and 33 under 14:00.　This figure compares very strongly with US collegiate men from all schools: athletic.net's list of collegiate men 5000 meters in 2009, which lists approximately 400 athletes at 14:40, 200 at 14:20 and 60 under 14:00 in 2009. Stepping up to the 10,000 meter distance, the same sources show that these 19 Tokyo universities list over 190 runners with personal bests under 30:00 (14 more sub 30 minute runners make up an all-star team of runners from other Tokyo universities); about 90 US collegians ran under 30:00 in 2009.

== In popular culture ==
Run with the Wind is a Japanese novel by Shion Miura that narrates the build-up and training of a team to run the Hakone Ekiden. It has been adapted to manga, live action film and anime.
