trip: If you walk between Motohakone and Hakone-machi (a worthy alternative to the bus/boat), then you'll do this short Hinoki pine avenue by default. But I don't think it's anything special. What the photos cleverly hide is that it's immediately parallel to the main road. It's not
I love cedars and these are quite impressive. But the cedar road is quite old and there is the paved street right next to it. Unfortunately no place for spirituality.
Amazing to walk on the old travellers road. It was so beautiful surrounded by cedar trees or Japanese pine.
It’s a nice way to get between Motohakone and Hakone Machi. Better than bussing it. Add the gardens in as well - they’re relaxing and up the top is a lovely view.
Nice road with the trees lining the road. Very cooling to walk in the month of June. Information boards that tells visitors how vulnerable these trees are and would be gone forever if not protected.
This a small path that goes from Motohakone-ko to Hakonemachi-ko, the path lined up with trees and nature, and a welcoming change of pace as it had very few people walking it.

This was a nice path just off the main road. It's hard to believe this road is so old and still in regular use. With nice weather you can actually see Mt. Fuji from here when you get near the openings along Lake Ashi. Despite being next to a main road it was very peaceful. Would
Up the hill from Moto - Hakone you find the entrance to the stone paved Old Hakone Highway. It's a trail with old cedars. You'll pass a wonderful teahouse on your way to Hakone - Yumoto.

I was expecting a forest full of old cedar trees, but it was just a pathway beside the main road lined with tall ancient cedar trees. You can have a nice quiet walk from Moto-Hakone to Hakone-Machi town.
Nice alternative way of getting from Hakonemachi to Motohakone - on foot. Peaceful surroundings despite running parallel next to traffic. After rain it gets muddy. Wear the right gear.

The cedars require a bit of a walk to reach, after you alight from the pirate boat across the lake, but the diversion from the trams and trains and buses and boats and cable cars is well worth it. The scenery is not spectacular, but nice, peaceful and a flat easy stroll from

Tea arrived on a rainy day and it was majestic. the walk is easy and probably the best places to feel the history of Hakone-juku and the amazing nature of Japan. Dont miss out on this even if you have a short visit to Hakone.
This is a lovely walk under the cedar trees. They are truly majestic and provide an awesome backdrop for the lake and surrounding countryside. A special experience.
Take a stroll from Hakone to Lake Ashi. We thought it would be an hour walk but get to finish in about 15 minutes. Recommended.

We walked part of the old Tokkaido road and today found these cedars which are the 'beginning' of the road after the checkpiint at Hakone machi. Be nice to know how old they are..but they are impressive trees.
This was a lovely peaceful walk along this old road amongst 400 year old cedars. A good way of travelling between Hakone Checkpo=in and Mohakone-Ko.
The Cedar Avenue is an historic site and forms part of the Old Tokaido Road which linked Tokyo and Kyoto in the Edo period. ( Shogun rulers 1603 to 1868)
Our guide pointed out the trees and explained how they were used to mark a path. Wonderful ambience here

For those into Japanese history it’s a great experience to walk down the old road used during the Edo period when people walked from Edo to Kyoto. The trees are beautiful and to just walk down the road imagining what it would have been like to live back in that time period of
after our pirate cruise ship experience we walked to the next bus stop but in between we came upon a beautiful path with cedar trees which felt really nice

Cedar Trees of Hakone Old Road AKA Old/Ancient Cedar Avenue is not a must . But if you are limited in time - take a stroll here instead of the longer track of Hakone Stone-Paved Road . After crossing the Ashi Lake you leave the Pirate Ship at Hakone Checkpoint Atoko to turn
google: Absolutely amazed me. The trees are so BIG! It's cool to think this once used to be a main road for people hundreds of years ago. Worth a visit if you are in Hakonemotomachi-ko port. It's only like a 5 minute walk from their.
Peaceful walk thats quiet enjoyable. Not too long and near the road
Way with tall and old cedrs trees.
A must for any Japanese history buff. One of the few remaining stretches of the original historic Tōkaidō.
So nice to see old growth trees!
Beautiful trees but trail is right next to a loud street. Not worth a visit
Beautiful place in Hakone
Peaceful.

trip: There are the Yunessun Park for everyone with pools with: choco, matcha, green tea, wine, coffee, etc... and the Mori No Yu space with tradicional japanese bath to adults, that is wonderful too!

We visited the swimsuit side of Yunessun, since our son wasn't comfortable with the traditional onsens. They loved it. We were there on a weekday and it was nearly empty. It meant we had lots of space, but it also meant almost none of their restaurants were open. They only

Good facilities, dining was just right for buffet and ample space during hot spring visits. Good performance of themed hotsprings. Off peak visit so worth the time which is most preferred. I will visit again with friends when possible.

We booked this because I have a tattoo and was worried about going to a traditional onsen. There are no changing rooms - you are encouraged to change next to your locker. The main pool is dated and doesn't look clean. The smaller themed pools are better - wine, sake, coffee
It was fun to try out the different pools including coffee, red wine and sake. Was quiet when we visited which meant we could have some pools to ourselves
Highly recommended place to go. The kids definitely will enjoy the place especially the slide as their highlight.

Stayed here as a guest and was probably the favourite hotel in the two weeks i was in japan. The onsen is very nice (espec the 6th floor one), room was very large and had its own outdoor bath too. Would definitely recommend

We visited on a day trip to Hakone. Great if you are in a mixed sex group as we were, because you wear a swimsuit and it is not separated by sex like a lot of the more traditional baths. There were a range of themed baths to try (green tea, coffee, wine, eucalyptus etc) for a

We bought discounted tickets via Klook to the swimsuit area only as we were going with kids (8 and 5). From Gora there are free shuttles you can catch to and from Yunessun. You receive a key on a wristband for access to lockers which also has a barcode with which you can buy

This is mainly for children and families. It's not relaxing for couples, there is no adults only area and children were often running around and splashing about. The 'themed' onsens are gimmicky and not very well designed and not overly clean either. The outdoor mountain view

It's very entertaining to experience Protein Bath, Coffee, Sake, Green Tea, and Wine Bath. It's always good to have fish doctor foot bath, too. You can go here and Hot Spring (Mori no Yu) for one day.

Since our teenage daughter wasn't quite ready for traditional (=get naked in front of other people) Japanese baths, we thought we'd give Yunessun a try on our last day in Japan. It was chilly and raining anyway, so a good day not to be touring around Hakone (which we did the two

Very gimmicky and poorly kept. Would skip entirely if had the chance or if you don't have other plans for things to do in Hakone. It was fun to discover all the different pools but their condition ruined the effect. The spa has a very run down feel overall: paint peeling, dirty

If your family aspires to try an authentic hot springs in Japan but are not ready to ditch the bathing suits in front of others, this is an option to consider in Hakone. The friendly staff will greet you and provide a bracelet for the day that you use to charge any purchases

It was raining and so we decided to spend day at yunessun. We bought a special discount ticket at the bus stop (@ hakone yumoto station) and had a huge savings. Adult was 1700yen Vs 2900yen. Inside there are many different pools, almost like onsen. Except they are filled

My friends find the baths interesting and good! Everything was clean but not wheelchair chair friendly for tourists. And be sure to check the bus schedule before going. The transportation is a bit difficult late at night.

Came here after a slight detour from the Hakone loop. Was very easy to find. Bathing suits required. My husband has tattoos so we made sure to bring a swimming shirt for him to cover up with. The kids loved it here. There was indoor pool area as well as diff themed onsen areas

This place is amazing! It was easy to get to from the train to the bus as people stood by expecting visitors to Yunessun. The process was straightforward and they even sold swimsuits inside (mostly female and children). If you have tattoos, make sure to cover them up, you can

This is an amazing place to visit for the whole family. Nothing better than a themed onzen resort from coffee, red wine (are just a few) hot springs to a chilly waterslide with a pool of hot water waiting at the end. There is an indoor hot spring play area for the younger

An incredible combination of different activities and services for everyone! From a swimming area with different pools (wine, sake, tea) to a beautiful onssen (traditional Japanese baths), this place has it all! A person is able to purchase roundtrip tickets + access the baths

Huge waste of money and time. Everything is scummy and dated. Didn’t feel clean or remotely relaxing. Even with a discount we paid approximately $60aud for two adults... definitely not worth it!!!!! Absolute tourist trap. The only reason I can fathom ever returning is if I had a

You can reach this location from the hyatt regency hakone hotel. You can grab a taxi to this location. At the day spa you have a choice whether you want to be totally naked or go to the section where you where a bathing suit. It is family friendly and kid friendly if you go to

Is that fathomable? Yes. Where everything is made possible in Japan, deep relaxation allows for those who are hard working and play hard! Swimwear is required in the outdoor slides and indoor baths. Our favorite was Dr. Fish! It’s worth going twice or three times. Wine, Sake,

I was there last year in Feb, I have to say I have never ever experienced anything like Yunessun before. They provide picture service as you enter the venue I think is around 1500 yen but its totally worth, than there are Red Wine, Sake, Chocolate, Coffee baths are just

I’ve seen photos of some Japanese water parks where you can’t see the water as it’s so busy, so I was worried about health and safety as we approached the colossal queue at 10.45am on a Monday. However, it was busy inside but not horrendous. The themed onsen were the main draw

Yunessun is a great place to come with family. It has over 11 baths and they are all refreshing. There is a big slide which is super fun, weird baths like wine baths, coffee baths, ice coffee baths and many others, cave baths etc.. The place is very crowded which can be

A spa for when the weather is bad outside. We used the swimwear-wearing section. These pools were similar to normal public swimming pools, except for the upstairs special onsens. One was a coffee bath, others were saki, green tea and wine! Also, a pool for the little fish

My fourth visit to this place and it's still as nice as ever. The bathing suit area are big hit for the kids, especially the slider. If you want to relax in hot water with great view, search for the path behind the slider, it will take you to a pool with breathtaking scenery.

Just returned from our trip to Japan and I have to say Yunessun was a little disappointing. We stayed at Tenyu which was across the street and they provided a free day pass with our stay (LOVED Tenyu). This place needs major renovation. It looked very run down and the shower

The waters here are not as hot as other places, which is good for younger children. There are different types of spa baths, like coffee, sake, and wine. We paid extra to have the fish nibble at our feet. It tickled and felt a bit weird, but it was a good experience.

text.wiki:
Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park (富士箱根伊豆国立公園, Fuji-Hakone-Izu Kokuritsu Kōen) is a national park in Yamanashi, Shizuoka, and Kanagawa Prefectures, and western Tokyo Metropolis, Japan. It consists of Mount Fuji, Fuji Five Lakes, Hakone, the Izu Peninsula, and the Izu Islands. Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park covers 1,227 square kilometres (474 sq mi).Rather than being a specific spot, the park is a collection of dispersed tourist sites that dot the region. The farthest point south, the isle of Hachijō-jima, is several hundred kilometers from Mount Fuji. The park includes a variety of geographic features including natural hot springs, coastlines, mountainous areas, lakes, and more than 1000 volcanic islands. Vegetation in the park ranges from species of mountainous trees to the subtropical vegetation of the Izu Islands.Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park was established on February 2, 1936 as Fuji-Hakone National Park, and is one of the first four national parks established in Japan. In 1950, the Izu islands were added to the park, and its name changed to its present designation. Due to its proximity to the Tokyo metropolis and ease of transportation, it is the most visited national park in all Japan.Nearby cities include Odawara, Fuji, Minami Ashigara, and Numazu.


== Points of interest ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park is divided into four general areas:
1. Mount Fuji area

Mount Fuji
Shiraito Falls
Fuji Five Lakes
Aokigahara
Lake Tanuki2. Hakone area

Old Tokaido Road
Hakone Botanical Garden of Wetlands
Ashi-no-ko Lake (Lake Ashi)
Great Boiling Valley3. Izu Peninsula

Mount Amagi
Atami hot springs
Atagawa Tropical & Alligator Garden
Jogasaki coast4. Izu Islands

Izu Ōshima
To-shima
Nii-jima
Shikine-jima
Kōzu-shima
Miyake-jima
Mikura-jima
Hachijō-jimaThe Izu islands are also a popular destination for scuba diving.


== See also ==

List of national parks of Japan


== References ==
Southerland, Mary and Britton, Dorothy. The National Parks of Japan. Kodansha International (1995). ISBN 4-7700-1971-8


== Further reading ==

A short ten minute trail with very tall cedars. If you do the lake cruise you can then take this walk down to the next port and get good views to Mt Fuji.

sights.name: Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Natural History

text.wiki:
The Kanagawa Prefectural Museum of Natural History (神奈川県立生命の星・地球博物館, Kanagawa kenritsu seimei no hoshi chikyū hakubutsukan)  is a natural history museum in the city of Odawara in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. The museum has an extensive geology section, and focuses on the flora and fauna of Kanagawa prefecture.
The museum is open from 9:00 to 4:30, and closed on Mondays and the second Tuesdays of the month (except national holidays, when they close the day after), and during the New Year's period.


== References ==
text.quote: Large, modern museum with exhibits on the earth's origins, flora & fauna, plus a cafe & gift shop.

text.wiki:
Yamanaka Castle (山中城, Yamanaka-jō) was a Sengoku period yamajiro-style Japanese castle, built by the Odawara Hōjō clan in Tagata District, Izu Province, in what is now eastern Mishima, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan. The site has been protected by the central government as a National Historic Site since 1988.


== Overview ==
Yamanaka Castle overlooks the strategic Tōkaidō highway halfway of western slope of Hakone Pass. The Tōkaidō highway was the main route between Kyoto and the Kanto region of Japan. The castle has a long and narrow structure, consisting of two lines of connected enclosures extending west and south of the second bailey, which is located just below the inner bailey. These enclosures are protected by deep, wet and dry moats.


== History ==
The late Hōjō clan was based at Odawara Castle in far western Sagami Province and only a few kilometers from the border with Suruga Province ruled by the Imagawa clan. The Hōjō and Imagawa maintained an alliance; however, after the fall of the Imagawa clan, Suruga was occupied by the Takeda clan of Kai Province and the Hōjō territories were threatened. This threat did not diminish after the Takeda clan was destroyed by an alliance between Oda Nobunaga and Tokugawa Ieyasu, both of whom were at odds against the Hōjō.  Yamanaka Castle was built by Hōjō Ujiyasu in the Eiroku era (1558–1577) to guard against this threat.
Despite the growing tension between the Hōjō and Toyotomi Hideyoshi, only a modest attempt was made to strength the defenses of the castle. When the Toyotomi armies attacked Odawara in 1590, Hideyoshi ordered Toyotomi Hidetsugu and Tokugawa Ieyasu to reduce Yamanaka Castle as quickly as possible, as it lie directly in his line of communications between the front lines and Osaka. In March, the two commanders attacked Yamanaka castle with 50,000 soldiers. In response, Hōjō Ujikatsu resisted with only 4,000 troops. Despite the disparity in numbers, the Toyotomi forces took heavy losses, including one general, Hitotsuyanagi Naosue; however, the castle fell in only a half day of combat and most of its defenders were killed.
Yamanaka Castle was not rebuilt during the Edo period, and the site reverted to forest. All that remains are fragmentary portions of its moats and earthworks.
In 2006, the site of Yamanaka Castle was listed as one of the 100 Fine Castles of Japan by the Japan Castle Foundation, primarily due to its historical significance.


== See also ==
List of Historic Sites of Japan (Shizuoka)


== Notes ==


== References ==
Schmorleitz, Morton S. (1974). Castles in Japan. Tokyo: Charles E. Tuttle Co. pp. 144–145. ISBN 0-8048-1102-4.
Motoo, Hinago (1986). Japanese Castles. Tokyo: Kodansha. p. 200 pages. ISBN 0-87011-766-1.
Turnbull, Stephen (2003). Japanese Castles 1540-1640. Osprey Publishing. p. 64 pages. ISBN 1-84176-429-9.


== External links ==
JCastle profile
Mishima CIty official home page
100 Fine Castles home page

山中城（やまなかじょう）は、静岡県三島市山中新田（伊豆国田方郡山中）にある中世の日本の城（山城跡）で、国の史跡に指定されている。

北条氏によって築城され、小田原城の支城として位置づけられる。箱根十城のひとつ。

三島市によって当時を反映した整備改修がなされ、堀や土塁などの遺構は風化を避けるため、盛土による被履の上芝を張って保護し、畝堀や障子堀の構造が明確に把握できるように整備されており北条氏の築城方法を良く知ることのできる城跡となっている。

また、北条氏滅亡と共に廃城となったため、北条氏独特の城郭の構造を多く残していることが注目される。

2012年まで、5月の第三日曜日に山中城まつりが開催されていた。（現在は中断）

text.wiki:
Odawara (小田原市, Odawara-shi) is a city in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.
As of February 2015, the city had an estimated population of 194,672, and a population density of 1,710 persons per km2. The total area is 113.79 km2.


== History ==
The area around present-day Odawara has been settled since prehistoric times, and archaeological evidence indicates that the area had a high population density in the Jōmon period.
From the Ritsuryō system of the Nara period, the area became part of Ashigarashimo District of Sagami Province. It was divided into shōen during the Heian period, mostly controlled by the Hatano clan and its branches. During the Genpei War between the Heike clan and Minamoto no Yoritomo, the Battle of Ishibashiyama was fought near present-day Odawara. During the Sengoku period, Odawara developed as a castle town and capital of the domains of the later Hōjō clan, which covered most of the Kantō region. The Hōjō were defeated by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the Battle of Odawara in 1590, despite the impregnable reputation of Odawara Castle. The territory came under the control of Tokugawa Ieyasu.
Under the Tokugawa shogunate, Odawara was the center of Odawara Domain, a feudal han ruled by a succession of daimyō. The castle town prospered as Odawara-juku, a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto.
After the Meiji Restoration, Odawara Domain briefly became 'Odawara Prefecture', which was merged with the short-lived 'Ashigara Prefecture' before joining Kanagawa Prefecture in 1876. During this period, the center of economic and political life in Kanagawa shifted to Yokohama. Odawara suffered a strong decline in population, which was made more severe when the original route of the Tōkaidō Main Line bypassed the city in favor of the more northerly route via Gotemba.
The epicenter of the Great Kantō earthquake in 1923 was deep beneath Izu Ōshima Island in Sagami Bay. It devastated Tokyo, the port city of Yokohama, surrounding prefectures of Chiba, Kanagawa, and Shizuoka Prefectures, and caused widespread damage throughout the Kantō region. Ninety percent of the buildings in Odawara collapsed immediately, and fires burned the rubble along with anything else left standing.Odawara regained some measure of prosperity with the opening of the Tanna Tunnel in 1934, which brought the main routing of the Tōkaidō Main Line through the city. Odawara was raised from the status of town to city on December 20, 1940. On August 15, 1945, Odawara was the last city in Japan to be bombed by Allied aircraft during World War II.
On November 1, 2000, Odawara exceeded 200,000 in population, and was proclaimed a special city.


== Geography ==
Odawara lies in the Ashigara Plains, in the far western portion of Kanagawa Prefecture. It is bordered by the Hakone Mountains to the north and west, the Sakawa River to the east, and Sagami Bay of the Pacific Ocean to the south.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture
Minamiashigara
Ninomiya
Ōi, Kaisei, Nakai
Hakone, Manazuru, Yugawara


=== Climate ===


== Economy ==

Odawara is a major commercial center for western Kanagawa Prefecture. Manufacturing includes light industry, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and food processing. Agriculture and commercial fishing play a relatively minor role in the local economy. Odawara is also a bedroom community for Yokohama and Tokyo.
Companies headquartered in Odawara include:

Suzuhiro Co.
Meganesuper Co., Ltd.
Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd
Odawara Auto Machine MFG. Co., Ltd.
Odakyu Sharyo Kogyo Co Ltd
Odakyu Hakone Holdings Co., Ltd.
Hakone Tozan Railway
Sagami Trust Bank
Nippon Injector Corporation

== Area attractions ==

Besides Odawara Castle, Odawara is a major transit point for the Hakone hot springs resort area and the sightseeing locations of the Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park. Within the city itself, the Yugawara area is a well-known hot spring resort.
Enoura, a coastal area of Odawara known for its pristine sea, has an abundance of kumamomi, a type of fish that prefers clear and clean water. Sea turtles are sometimes present there. Because of the clear water and plentiful undersea life, many people come to Enoura for scuba diving.
Traditionally, Odawara is known for its production of kamaboko processed fish, stockfish, umeboshi salted plums, and traditional herbal medicines. The Suzuhiro Kamaboko Village is a place to experience making and learning more about Odawara Kamaboko.


== Sister city relations ==
 - Nikkō, Tochigi, since December 19, 1980
 - Kishiwada, Osaka, since June 26, 1968
 - Chula Vista, California, United States, since November 8, 1981
 - Manly, New South Wales, Australia (friendship city), since 1991
 - Shenzhen, Guangdong, China, since February 4, 1993

The outside was great, unfortunately the inside was closed due to renovations. The surrounding area is fantastic, with many koi in the canal around it.

The 7th highest castle in Japan and near to Tokyo. The castle is a rebuild castle from edo period. The museum is very small and not worth paying extra for it. Recommend to just pay to visit the castle keep and to go to edo-tokyo museum for better museum tour.

Love at first sight! Our trip was so worth it. Even though some parts of the interior was sort of modern, I fell inlove on the exterior. I could look at this beautiful building all day! I look forward to seeing more castles here in Japan!

The neighborhood was so calm and homie. Feel so peaceful around this place. Since we came at evening, it wasn't so hot in this summer time

I actually went to Odawara castle on my first visit to Tokyo in November 2012. As a history buff, I wanted to see a castle, and Odawara Castle was the nearest to Tokyo I found. It is around a 1-hour train ride from Tokyo to Odawara. A must for fans of Castles!
We went there 10mins before it would be closed. Hydrangea were lighted up which were very beautiful. And next time I want to go there at noon because there were some wagons to sell odawara food.
Comparing to other castles in Japan, this was is pretty small; however, newly renovated, so it looks great and inside history about the castle and its owners described.
Impressive building with museum included. well done,well laid out. Good gardens to walk around and chill. This castle has been rebuilt to a fantastic standard ,well done to all involved.
as another castle in japan, they have a park ussually occupy with sakura flower during blossom. Unfortunately we came about 4 pm and about to close. but we still can play at the park
The grounds are not very big. The castle isn't as big as some other castles, but it is beatiful and well worth a visit if you are in the Odawa area.
It is the place where you can enjoy alone,with friends ,with family what do you like? There is historicall places and things to seeing ! Enjoy and visit ones time !!
Amazing place for a walk during Sakura blooming period! Very traditional and charming. Walking distance from train station.

The Castle need a walk to be reached. Elderly will not be advisable to tour there. Good to visit but not a MUST stop.

I came here with high hopes to visit the castle and also catch some good pictures. It turn out the castle is currently not available. However, we did managed to have a nice walk and enjoying the surrounding. One of the castle to visit but make sure you check with the tourist
Lovely view and walk around the castle grounds. Wisteria was growing and created a lovely asset to the castle.
I have seen castles in Japan and this is just another castle in odawara, good for locals but not so attractive for travellers who have already visited some castle.
Nice place to visit, not big. But you'll get to see the heritage part of it. Walking distance from town.

Do not worry you are not good at Japan history, just enjoy staying at Odarawa Castle and its park. We feel peaceful and joyful here.
If your passing by Odawara, come on and check out the castle. They been making it better every time I see it. Have to check out the the tiny zoo with the monkeys...

A lovely place to visit. And also, this is an replica of the original. Noted with that, the Spring season of Sakura is lovely and the Autumn season of red leaves is just as nice.
Cherry blossom blooms awesomely. There are many people drinking and eating outside of the castle to celebrate. It's a great atmosphere for this season.

We travelled to the Castle as a side tour from our planned holiday. we enjoyed the tour and the history

This was our first castle to visit in Japan. It was very interesting and it is worth the climb for the view.
Incredible exhibit of multimedia samurai art. Really nice permanent exhibition with English translation and explanations of the history of the castle and the regio.

Beautiful on the outside, but also an interesting museum about the area and samurai life on the inside. Great panoramic views from the top of the donjon.

it's not the real McCoy.... The monkeys are cool though.

google: Cool historical landmark. Beautiful inside the castle courtyards; there are even some monkeys to see. Cool place for taking some nice pictures. Only ¥500 yen to get in, and there are some interesting artifacts to check out. If you like …
Awesome castle and grounds to explore. There are multiple pay by the hour lots surrounding the castle.
Beautiful place to visit during Golden Week. There are many events here and a museum inside the castle.
The grounds here are very nice, the area was quiet when we visited (late afternoon, raining), but it brought a sense of peace to the park

Not much to see, except the castle itself.
Inside castle photography is prohibited.
A short trip near to beach makes good combination.
Wonderful. Kind staff, lovely views. Lots to see and do.
Beautiful castle and grounds. The museum inside provided only Japanese signage so all of the history was lost on me. Stunning view from the top. Volunteers were amazingly helpful!!

I visited this castle on a work trip. It’s very educational. You can download a guide on your smartphone and can listen to different discriptuons of displayed artifacts. The castle is beautiful and a great place to take photos.

trip: I have tattoos and had absolutely no problem with coming here. The facility is extremely clean and the staff are very nice.
Great location, great baths, great time! Highly recommended. (Tattoo friendly)...Now TripAdvisor is requiring I write at least 100 characters so here we go..

We headed out to Tenzan around 7 pm at night. It was mainly full of locals at this point but this made the experience all the better. The staff were very helpful and showed us how to use the ticket machine. We obtained a ticket with discount for the 1 day hakone day pass.

Great first experience, super easy to get comfortable having no clothes on! Great value and lunch lovely. Visited with my 85yr old Mum, first time onsen visit and she enjoyed this experience!

nice onsen, clean&very relaxing with the natural stone, trees, .. i went on a weekday(!!) after visiting hakone area as a day trip from tokio- it was lovely as it wasnt crowded at all and also there were very few foreigners -great experience!

This was an amazing onsen. The baths were enveloped in trees, waterfalls and natural stone. We spent several hours there enjoying the setting and various temperature pools. Highly recommend- a great refuge outside of Tokyo.
