This is a beautiful mostly outdoor museum. The exhibits and artwork are fascinating. It is a great place to bring your kids. Much of the art is hands on. There’s also a unique playground inside a building that resembles Jenga blocks. There’s a warm and relaxing foot bath. The
I love museums, art, nature, and this place had everything I wanted. Picasso exhibit is a must! Dip your feet in the hot spring water after you are done walking around, it's worth it!
fantastic location to visit for all ages. there is a hugh indoor playground for kids that is made up of nets. kids can run around the entire open air museum

A must go for the art lovers. Entrance fees apply and is not included in the Hakone pass. Lots of sculpture and a museum which hold Picasso art works. It was raining when we visited. Was cold, wet and foggy and made the walking less bearable. Nonetheless, highly recommend this

Didn't know what to expect. Didn't know anything. Boy were we pleasantly surprised. It was incredibly fun and interesting with many unusual outdoor sculptures by famous sculptors. We spent a good 3 + hours there and were reluctant to leave. Will go back again next time we're

We have been to sculpture parks before but this one is truly wonderful. Quite apart from the quality of the exhibits, the park and its layout is quite outstanding. We thought we would only be there for an hour or so but in the end stayed till closing time and could have spent

Loved this place !!! Everything is so delicately exhibited throughout the beautiful garden. The have some impressive pieces from important world artist. Greaaaaat place to take pics ! Totally worth it !

It was a cold, wet and overcast day so we decided to visit this gem. Well worth the price of admission with a beautiful layout that delivered new pieces after every turn. Good way to spend a few hours at a leisurely pace.
Avery big Open Air Museum with so many sculptures, paintings, and large art objects. It even have a Picasso Museum. A must see when in Hakone.

What an amazing setting to enjoy art. There is a huge variety of sculptures set on beautiful grounds overlooking Hakone. The art is unique and visually interesting so there is something that everyone will enjoy, even if you aren't an art lover. Also a great picasso collection.

This was a wonderful open air sculpture museum with a decent indoor Picasso collection. The backdrop of Hakone is beautiful and as a pleasant surprise - there are several features of this museum that are quite engaging for children (we traveled with our 9 year old twins).

We happened to visit this museum while exploring Hakone on foot. It’s a beautiful park setting for an amazing collection of sculptural art by Caulder, Henry Moore, Picasso, etc. On the same grounds is a building devoted to artworks by Picasso, including ceramics rarely seen.

For a non-art aficionado, I think the open air museum had a lot to offer ... well curated sculptures set within the natural landscape, large art works that were actually play grounds for kids, and an educational museum dedicated to Picasso. At 1600yen per adult i has thought it
The museum is located in a beautiful garden, with statues of the best artists in the world. It also has a showroom of several of Picasso's creations. Worth a visit.

Worth the time to visit this place, it's interesting to find the sculpture and museum with impressive colours and shapes.

Great selection of Japanese and international sculpture in a beautiful setting (gardens) set in the mountains. A gem! Loved every moment of my visit. Great facilities, indoor and outdoor. For all ages. And a unique foorbath in which to rest your weary feet. Recommended if you

This is a wonderful place! Great sculpture and nice gardens. I wish we had had much more time to spend here. The Picasso building is a great addition. I also wish adults could play on the kids' play sculptures...

This is an extraordinary collection of sculpture presented in an extraordinary environment. The gallery grounds are Japan at its finest and they showcase the collection to perfection. The scale of the gallery means that the crowd is very well absorbed and while I know it must
We brought the hakone pass and extra discount when you show pass to buy the open musuem tickets. Spend around 2-3hours there. Is very big.

We absolutely loved this Museum. The collection is amazing, many great works of art. I particularly liked the tower with the stained glass. We put our feet into the hot spring water too.

Nice walk on a cloudy day. The Picasso collection in the Black building wears very interesting!Many of the Art sculptures were interesting and pleasant to see and appreciate.The grounds were well designed and laid out.A most enjoyable walk at th Hakone Open Air Museum!

We spent an unexpectedly delightful afternoon, quietly exploring the open air exhibits. Don't forget to view the Picasso museum, you won't be disappointed and the Museum also has a lovely shop as you leave the facility.

This is an awesome museum, i imagine it would be just as good for families as it was for us (2 couples). Lots of interesting pieces, lots of world renowned artists, well put together and over a much larger area than i thought.

This mainly sculpture garden and museum is a must visit in Hakone. World class sculptures by people such as Henry Moore were on display and the Picasso section was extensive. The gardens were magnificent and well maintained to display the many sculptures.
I was surprised to find this place at Hakone. You could spend 1-2 hours just to walk and explore the open air museum with all the unique art works. It is very easy to get to.

This is an amazing museum on top of the mountain, inside the huge volcanic crater. Most beautiful place to visit from a brief trip from Tokyo. For art and nature lover, this a trip of a lifetime. You need at least 2 days to be able to go around this beautiful place. Recommended

Who would've thought a small town would have a museum/collection like this. Well worth a visit. Jump off the tram in this small town
This museum was fantastic. Such a lovely set up with great walking tracks and pathways. Even the fish were a joy to feed. Loved the sculpture for children too.

A beautiful way to spend a few hours amongst the lovely surroundings and amazing sculptures. Of course best viewed in good weather but don’t let a few showers stop you missing out on such a beautiful experience. Wonderful gift shop and restaurant here as well. Picasso

It is worth going to Hakone just to spend the day in this amazing sculpture garden. Plus the Picasso museum was well worth spending a few hours. It was well designed and very easy to enjoy with wonderful art.
Wonderful museum, great architecture, good combination of indoor and outdoor. don't miss the feet bath.

Lovely place. Architecture, grounds with statues, little Picasso museum. Nice attention is the foot bath at the end of the visit. However, for someone who has issues with his knees like me, too many steps. If you're physically disabled, don't even try. Not good.

This museum is an easy stop on the train from Hakone-Yumoto to Gora, part of the usual tourist circuit in Hakone. It’s a lovely space with great and interesting pieces of sculpture and other art in a really big space. If you enjoy art, this is a great museum.

I generally like museums, but this open air attraction contained only one original house. All of the others had been rebuilt and were shops selling craftwork and other knick knacks.

The Hakone Open-Air Museum is a fabulous place to see modern sculpture by the world's finest artists and to soak your tired feet in a foot onsen.

Give yourself at least 1 1/2 hours, no less, to see all of the attractions at the Open Air Museum. Picasso is a must. There is a hot spring to bathe your feet in when they get tired. Small towels are only 100 Yen. Check out the leadlight tower.

Dropped by on a chilly cloudy day. Was extremely surprised by the quality and extent of modern sculpture set in an idyll well maintained garden with lots of trees and flowers. Great place to spend the day.
We were really impressed with the indoor Picasso Museum. Two floors of beautifully displayed Picasso art of all media. The outdoor statuary was also well displayed. A nice way to spend an afternoon.

I dragged my husband and child here and they ended up thanking me. It was a gorgeous exhibit. Even though it was so HOT while we were here we still enjoyed our day. My only criticism would be the lack of food choices available. Had I known I would have packed some snacks.
Very varied styles of modern sculptures - from the beautiful to the funny via the bizarre and the disturbing. Nice Picasso collection. Good descriptions in English.

The open air museum is a lovely way to spend a morning or afternoon - just make sure you leave yourself enough time to stroll through at a relaxed pace rather than trying to take it all in in an hour. The artwork is quite varied - from a stained glass tower to sculptures of

I have been to this museum twice. Once ten years ago. It was a great experience then and when I had the opportunity to visit again, I went again. It was truly as great as an experience as the first time and even better because it was not as hot as I had gone in June the first

I went to the hakone open air museum twice, and in my opinion this is the most beatiful place on the planet. The art works are varied and interesting (by both japanese and western artists), the view is amazing and the curation is perfect. The combination of nature and art at
A cooling day to get inspired by the nature and art and was inspired to take lots of pictures and highly recommend to visit open museum if you at Hakone. Bring kids to get educated through play!

“Well, we’re not going to see Mt. Fuji,” we figured; “may as well do something else instead.” This museum was a fabulous surprise. In addition to an excellent indoor Picasso exhibit, there is: a huge climbable tower completely made of colorful glass mosaics; two (!) gigantic

My family of 2 adults and 2 kids (6 and 9 years) enjoyed our visit to the Open Air Museum. The two kid friendly exhibits are wonderful for the kids to run and burn off energy. They also enjoyed feeding the carp. And we definitely all enjoyed the free hot springs foot bath!

Visited the Open Air Museum on a rainy day in Hakone. Still thoroughly enjoyed it. 1600 yen entry (200 yen discount with Hakone Free Pass). A lot of different sculptures to see and a gallery dedicated to the work of Picasso. Well laid out. Cafe onsite with very basic food and
Although it was pouring with rain and misty it was well worth a visit. However in sunshine it must be amazing. Such an eclectic mix of styles but wanted to photograph nearly everything.
Definitely worth a visit ! They have a student fare and you can get a discount with the Hakone Freepass. Such a nice area to walk around and the Picasso exhibit is very interesting!

My family and I (kids 9 and 12) loved this museum. There was heaps for the kids to do and the climbing net (up to 12 year olds) was a massive hit. We attended on a wet day but it was well worth the visit. It’s only a very short walk from the closest train stop.
The scuptures, galleries and gardens are fantastic. This is an art gallery with a difference. We loved it.
This is an outstanding sculpture park that will dazzle you. Certainly a 2 hour visit is recommended. There is a cafe in the centre of the grounds which we did not use but was busy.
Surprisingly extensive collection of sculpture. Lots of Henry Moore. Picasso exhibit is really cool - lots of ceramics and other media. Cool kinetic sculpture as well.

I don't know how to begin to describe this place. This place is a dream. Even if its raining, this place is worth a visit because the mood is different at different times, thus how you see it, also changes.

Enjoyed the art itself and especially the outdoor setting. We are not art snobs but experienced a relaxing and fun time walking throughout when the cable car was closed and some slight rain. It was not too crowded as were here after school started.

this is a must see attraction-a wonderful collection of fantastic sculptures set in a beautiful landscaped park real variety of pieces - a lot of henry moores- and a big gallery of Picasso make sure to also see the 20th century gallery above the cafe and also the interactive

This is a spectacular sculpture museum in a beautiful setting. Its probably the most impressive place we visited in the area.
Offers a couple of nice things to do for the little ones, but at the same time there were some interesting exhibitions for us.

We visited as it was en route to our hotel and we needed to kill a few hours before check in. It’s a lovely place. There are lots of sculptures around but also other interesting things like a walk by the fish pond (you can feed the fish), and a hot springs bath for your feet

Great pieces of art, well spread across a beautiful green park, with a great background of mountains and woods. No overkill, so the museum can be done in a fair timing. Some nice surprises, an interactive part at the end, and a big shop. Easy accessible by bus and train.

This is probably one of the best museums I have visited. The exhibits are excellent. So much to see and ponder. The cooling foot bathing area is a must and there are towels you can purchase very reasonably. There are a couple of great climbing frames for children - they looked
This is simply one of the best art museums I ever have visited! The quality of the items are extreemly high.
If you are visiting Hakone, take some time to visit The Hakone Open-Air Museum. important sculptures, wonderful garden and Picasso Museum with important pieces from the artist.do not missed it!
Excellent placement of amazing pieces kept us all interested despite the temperature and humidity. The variety of the pieces gave us all chance to see a favourite. Would definitely recommend.
A surprise! Beautiful setting; out door sculptures and indoor comprehensive Picasso Museum. Not to be missed!
Despite record breaking and debilitating heat, this museum was a winner. We went on a whim and loved it. Incredible sculpture outside plus an opportunity to soak your feet outside,

This museum makes you feel the art in different ways! But the best ones are the ones made for the kids! This definitely makes the kids fall in love with the art around them! This place is a must if you come to Hakone !!!!

The Hakone Open-Air Museum is no doubt one of the best art museum we've ever visited! Beautiful art pieces are well presented and the visit route is also well thought and planned. Highly recommended for a family day trip and a great place for kids!

Absolutely stunning museum both inside and out!!! Fantastic outdoor sculptures throughout the grounds and an impressive Picasso collection. I could have spent an entire day wondering the grounds and the indoor exhibits. Very, very special. My #1 favorite museum in Japan.

A great collection of works in a one-of-a-kind setting. I wish I had more time. Thoroughly enjoyable for a day trip to Hakone. Allow about two hours

One of the most unique experiences in Japan! We had chosen this as the location we wanted to visit in the Hakone region. While the original forecast was for rain, we were so happy to wake up to a sunny day. The museum occupies a beautiful spot and the installations are superb.

What a fantastic place to visit. Very unexpected. Wonderful sculptures throughout the outdoor gardens and then you get to gallery. Thoroughly recommend

This is a gem. Without any expectations I was surprised about the museum. Very nice and at the time of our visit (Friday at 3pm) not crowded at all. Some very fine sculptures - also not your typical dull ones. go and see!

Wonderful collection of statues, stunning environment. Restaurants disappointing; Japanese food is so remarkable why approximate Western food is such an inferior way?
Amazing grounds with a broad range of modern/traditional, Eastern/Western sculpture. Not to be missed.

This is a great activity for singles, couples or families. The gardens are a great place to unwind and relax and the artwork they have displayed (especially the Picasso museum) are excellent. Highly recommended for a half day trip.

Words can’t even describe just how gorgeous this open air museum is. I am not usually a fan or expect on any kind of art and yet I was completely immersed in exploring the stunning park and gardens and looking at all the sculptures and statues. We easily spent 2+ hours walking

Very nice place to visit when you visit Hakone with kids. If you have are with young kids you may need more time. You will get discount with hakone Pass. You don't need to pay for the entrance fees with pre school kids (6 years and below)

The Hakone Open-Air Museum hosts a collection of about 100 works of art, set in 70,000 square meters of green space. It was founded in 1969, and is currently housing a great Picasso exhibit. There is art everywhere, inside and outside. This museum has something for everyone.
Open air museum in Hakone, Japan. Exhibition space is both outdoor/indoor. You can enjoy with ceramic work, painting and more. Easy to get there by train or walk. A must visit place in Japan!!!

We have visited quite a number of museums all over the world with our family, but my teenage daughter called this one of the best ever. The pieces of art are beautiful. The park is very well laid out. There is something for everybody, even for smaller kids. My daughter was
Not normally my thing but enjoyed the walk through the beautiful grounds and all the exhibits interspersed through the scenery.
This was a trip highlight. The museum layout and sculptures are amazing. The two children play areas are both beautiful and unbelievably fun for the kids to play in.

We were thrilled to visit the open air museum and Picasso exhibit. Huge sculpture from artists from Japan, Italy, France, Germany, the Netherlands, the Americas. Don’t miss if you like art. Huge outdoor pieces on beautiful grounds
This is a beautiful open air museum, one of the highlights of our trip to Japan. There is a lot to see and it's a large space, leave yourself enough time.

This is a beautiful outdoor sculpture museum. Even though the weather was not great, it was very enjoyable to stroll around. Do not miss the Picasso collection (it is indoors). The Moores were prevalent. Also, I enjoyed the museum store.
Beautiful gardens displaying modern art, enjoyed strolling through it and had a foot bath at the foot onsen next to the café, very relaxing.

Highly recommended place Think it would be interesting for both folks of all ages It’s basically a outdoor park with lots of interesting exhibits
This was a beautiful garden and had a surprisingly large collection of Picasso in a dedicated building. Well worth the visit.

After visiting lots of attractions around Hakone over 2.5 days, the Open-Air Museum was the best for me. The museum combines art and nature in a great way. Very relaxing to just walk around and take it all in.
This museum is an absolute top,experience thanks to the quality of the pieces of art + the most charming park in which they are exhibited.

Wonderful exhibition in a beautiful setting. We were there on a sunny day so everything looked amazing. A really well presented and set out but what else would you expect in Japan. Not to be missed are the wonderful and unusual children's play area/sculpture, you can play on

Well laid out and very interesting outdoor museum. Well worth a couple of hours on a nice day. A pretty eclectic collection of artists you've heard of and many you probably haven't.

A very good place to visit. The scenery is good. There are quite a lot of art works distributing in the area. There are also a few restaurants available.

Wow, the most amazing set of sculptures and art in the most beautiful surroundings. Moore, Miroslaw, Picasso and others in the Japanese countryside. Well worth the visit.

We went to the Hakone Open Air Museum, as it was fairly close to where we were staying. Its a nice place *(check the box) to see cool works of art. If you have kids, I'm sure they'll enjoy it.

Great Museum surrounded by nature. Great to chill, soak your feet at the foot bath there. Great for kids as well.
Should not be missed. Worth the hassle of getting to Hakone just for this museum! Perfect harmony between Art & Nature.

This is a must go place in Hakone, it is a good experience to walk in the open while enjoying the scenery and the scriptures at the same time. Especially during the Cherry blossom time, it’s so beautiful.

Fun, unique destination. Enjoyed the variety of sculptures. Note it has lockers, if you're taking the nearby train and have luggage.

Beautiful setting for sculpture in this scenic spot. Good selection of artwork including a few incredible pieces (the stained glass tower) and fun interactive pieces for kids. A must see destination in Hakone.

Hakone is not just natural beauty and onsen. This is a family friendly spot. Kids would love this place.

It is a must go when in Hakone! This is an open air museum, it is worth to spend half day there and enjoy everything it offers. For kids it is also fun, as they have lot of interactive arts for them! They also have a Picasso area with some of his arts.

Whole in Hakone you should definitely visit this museum. Very unusual and nice place to visit during the day. We very much enjoyed it.

A different kind of museum not like the usual boring ones.. enjoyed spending time at this place. Recommend to visit

text.wiki:
Fukuzumirō (福住楼) is a hotel and spa in Hakone, Japan. It was established in 1890 by Sawamura Takatoshi, a former samurai from Kumamoto province on Kyushu.


== Noted guests ==
A great number of writers, calligraphers, and artists have been regular customers in this hotel. For example, the writers and poets Fukuzawa Yukichi (the scholar who established Keio University), Natsume Sōseki, Shimazaki Toson, Iwaya Sazanami, Takeshima Hagoromo, Osaragi Jiro, Kawabata Yasunari, Satomi Ton, Yoshikawa Eiji, Hayashi Fumiko, Tamura Taijiro, and Hojo Hideji. Painters included Kawai Gyokudo and Hirafuku Hyakusui. Calligraphers and calligraphic artists included, Meikaku Kusakabe and Nakamura Randai Jr. Actors included Tsumasaburo Bando, the star of "Rickshaw Man" (Muhomatsu-no-issho).


== Design and facilities ==
The building is three-story wooden building consisting of nineteen rooms with different designs. Water is constantly pumped from only 100 meters under the ground. The temperature of the water is 63C, with spring water added to cool it: never adding water that has been treated.


== External links ==
Official website

text.wiki:
Odawara (小田原市, Odawara-shi) is a city in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan.
As of February 2015, the city had an estimated population of 194,672, and a population density of 1,710 persons per km2. The total area is 113.79 km2.


== History ==
The area around present-day Odawara has been settled since prehistoric times, and archaeological evidence indicates that the area had a high population density in the Jōmon period.
From the Ritsuryō system of the Nara period, the area became part of Ashigarashimo District of Sagami Province. It was divided into shōen during the Heian period, mostly controlled by the Hatano clan and its branches. During the Genpei War between the Heike clan and Minamoto no Yoritomo, the Battle of Ishibashiyama was fought near present-day Odawara. During the Sengoku period, Odawara developed as a castle town and capital of the domains of the later Hōjō clan, which covered most of the Kantō region. The Hōjō were defeated by Toyotomi Hideyoshi in the Battle of Odawara in 1590, despite the impregnable reputation of Odawara Castle. The territory came under the control of Tokugawa Ieyasu.
Under the Tokugawa shogunate, Odawara was the center of Odawara Domain, a feudal han ruled by a succession of daimyō. The castle town prospered as Odawara-juku, a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto.
After the Meiji Restoration, Odawara Domain briefly became 'Odawara Prefecture', which was merged with the short-lived 'Ashigara Prefecture' before joining Kanagawa Prefecture in 1876. During this period, the center of economic and political life in Kanagawa shifted to Yokohama. Odawara suffered a strong decline in population, which was made more severe when the original route of the Tōkaidō Main Line bypassed the city in favor of the more northerly route via Gotemba.
The epicenter of the Great Kantō earthquake in 1923 was deep beneath Izu Ōshima Island in Sagami Bay. It devastated Tokyo, the port city of Yokohama, surrounding prefectures of Chiba, Kanagawa, and Shizuoka Prefectures, and caused widespread damage throughout the Kantō region. Ninety percent of the buildings in Odawara collapsed immediately, and fires burned the rubble along with anything else left standing.Odawara regained some measure of prosperity with the opening of the Tanna Tunnel in 1934, which brought the main routing of the Tōkaidō Main Line through the city. Odawara was raised from the status of town to city on December 20, 1940. On August 15, 1945, Odawara was the last city in Japan to be bombed by Allied aircraft during World War II.
On November 1, 2000, Odawara exceeded 200,000 in population, and was proclaimed a special city.


== Geography ==
Odawara lies in the Ashigara Plains, in the far western portion of Kanagawa Prefecture. It is bordered by the Hakone Mountains to the north and west, the Sakawa River to the east, and Sagami Bay of the Pacific Ocean to the south.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture
Minamiashigara
Ninomiya
Ōi, Kaisei, Nakai
Hakone, Manazuru, Yugawara


=== Climate ===


== Economy ==

Odawara is a major commercial center for western Kanagawa Prefecture. Manufacturing includes light industry, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and food processing. Agriculture and commercial fishing play a relatively minor role in the local economy. Odawara is also a bedroom community for Yokohama and Tokyo.
Companies headquartered in Odawara include:

Suzuhiro Co.
Meganesuper Co., Ltd.
Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd
Odawara Auto Machine MFG. Co., Ltd.
Odakyu Sharyo Kogyo Co Ltd
Odakyu Hakone Holdings Co., Ltd.
Hakone Tozan Railway
Sagami Trust Bank
Nippon Injector Corporation


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
JR Central - Tōkaidō Shinkansen
Odawara
JR Central - Gotemba Line
Shimo-Soga - Kōzu
JR East - Tōkaidō Main Line
Kōzu - Kamonomiya - Odawara - Hayakawa - Nebukawa
Odakyu Electric Railway - Odakyu Odawara Line
Kayama - Tomizu - Hotaruda - Ashigara - Odawara
Hakone Tozan Railway - Hakone Tozan Line
Odawara - Hakone-Itabashi - Kazamatsuri - Iriuda
Izuhakone Railway - Daiyūzan Line
Odawara - Midorichō - Isaida - Gohyakurakan - Anabe - Iidaoka  - Sagami-Numata


=== Highway ===
Odawara-Atsugi Road
Japan National Route 1, to Tokyo or Kyoto
Japan National Route 135, to Shimoda
Japan National Route 138, to Fujiyoshida
Japan National Route 255, to Hadano
Japan National Route 271, to Atsugi (toll)


=== Bus ===
Bus service to Izu Peninsula


== Area attractions ==

Besides Odawara Castle, Odawara is a major transit point for the Hakone hot springs resort area and the sightseeing locations of the Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park. Within the city itself, the Yugawara area is a well-known hot spring resort.
Enoura, a coastal area of Odawara known for its pristine sea, has an abundance of kumamomi, a type of fish that prefers clear and clean water. Sea turtles are sometimes present there. Because of the clear water and plentiful undersea life, many people come to Enoura for scuba diving.
Traditionally, Odawara is known for its production of kamaboko processed fish, stockfish, umeboshi salted plums, and traditional herbal medicines. The Suzuhiro Kamaboko Village is a place to experience making and learning more about Odawara Kamaboko.


== Sister city relations ==
 - Nikkō, Tochigi, since December 19, 1980
 - Kishiwada, Osaka, since June 26, 1968
 - Chula Vista, California, United States, since November 8, 1981
 - Manly, New South Wales, Australia (friendship city), since 1991
 - Shenzhen, Guangdong, China, since February 4, 1993


== Notable people from Odawara ==
Kai Atō - actor
Yōhei Kōno - politician
Ninomiya Sontoku - Edo period economist and philosopher
Rumina Sato - mixed martial arts fighter
Kitamura Tokoku - author
Yoshiyuki Tomino - anime movie director
Baku Yumemakura - science fiction author


== Notes ==


== References ==
Hammer, Joshua. (2006). Yokohama Burning: The Deadly 1923 Earthquake and Fire that Helped Forge the Path to World War II. New York: Simon & Schuster.  ISBN 978-0-7432-6465-5 (cloth)

text.wiki:
Hakone (箱根町, Hakone-machi) is a town in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. As of June 2012, the town had an estimated population of 13,492, and a population density of 145 persons per km². The total area is 92.82 km2 (35.84 sq mi). Hakone has been designated as a Japanese National Geopark by the Japanese Geoparks Network.
Hakone is to a great degree regarded as a traveler destination; Mt. Fuji can be seen when taking a day trip from Tokyo. In addition to hot springs, museums and other recreation activities, Hakone is known for its scenery during all four seasons.


== Geography ==
Hakone is located in the mountains in the far west of the prefecture, on the eastern side of Hakone Pass. Most of the town is within the borders of the volcanically active Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, centered on Lake Ashi.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture

Odawara
Yugawara
Minami-ashigaraShizuoka Prefecture

Gotemba
Susono
Mishima
Oyama
Kannami


== History ==
Hakone is the location of a noted Shinto shrine, the Hakone Gongen, which is mentioned in Heian period literature. During the Genpei War, Minamoto no Yoritomo prayed at this shrine for victory over his enemies, after his defeat at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, which was fought in neighboring Manazuru. As with the rest of Sagami Province, the area came under the control of the later Hōjō clan of Odawara during the Sengoku period. After the start of the Edo period, Hakone-juku was a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto. It was also the site of a major barrier and official checkpoint on the route known as the Hakone Checkpoint (箱根関所, Hakone sekisho), which formed the border of the Kantō region. Under the Tokugawa shogunate, all travellers entering and leaving Edo along the Tōkaidō were stopped here by officials. Their travel permits and baggage were examined to enforce Tokugawa laws that restricted the travel of women and weapons.
After the start of the Meiji Restoration, Hakone became a part of the short-lived Ashigara Prefecture before becoming part of Ashigarashimo District in Kanagawa prefecture in August 1876. Hakone attained town status in 1889. The imperial household established the summer Hakone Imperial Villa close to the lake.
After merger with five neighboring towns and villages in September 1956, it reached its present boundaries.


== Economy ==

The economy of Hakone is strongly dominated by the tourist industry. Hakone is noted for its onsen hot spring resorts, which attract both Japanese and international visitors, due to its proximity to the greater Tokyo metropolis and to Mount Fuji. Sights include the volcanically active Ōwakudani geysers and Hakone Shrine on the shore of the lake, as well as the Hakone Botanical Garden of Wetlands. In April the cherry blossoms (sakura) and in autumn the Miscanthus sinensis (susuki) are noted sights.
Hakone has a number of art museums, including the Hakone Open-Air Museum and Pola Museum of Art.
Major events include the annual JLPGA CAT Ladies Golf tournament and the Hakone Ekiden, a long distance collegiate foot race, held at the New Year, which runs from Tokyo to Hakone and back over two days, partly in commemoration of the couriers who ran the Tōkaidō road.
One famous hotel in Hakone is the historic Fujiya Hotel in Miyanoshita, which was patronized by noted literary figures, politicians and foreign dignitaries in the Meiji and Taishō and early Shōwa periods.
A noted local handicraft is a kind of marquetry called Yosegi.Hakone is also well-known among anime fans for being the main location in the manga and anime series Neon Genesis Evangelion, in which it has been renamed Tokyo-3, and there are numerous attractions related to the franchise offered in the town. In 2017, Hakone was included as one of 88 anime pilgrimage sites for 2018 by the Anime Tourism Association. In 2020, new decorations have been introduced to the city in the anticipation of the release of the final film of the Rebuild of Evangelion tetralogy.


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
Hakone Tozan Railway
Hakone Tozan Cable Car
Hakone Ropeway
Izuhakone RailwayOdawara and Mishima, the terminus of the Odakyū Odawara Line, 70 minutes from Shinjuku, Tokyo. From Odawara, the Hakone Tozan Line continues into various resort towns in Hakone. Odakyu also runs the Romancecar limited express between Shinjuku and Hakone-Yumoto. From Gōra, the terminus of Hakone Tozan Line, the Hakone Tozan Cable Car funicular goes to Sōunzan. Ōwakudani can be reached by Hakone Ropeway from Sounzan and the lake, while the lake is crisscrossed by cartoonishly decorated "pirate" ships for tourists. There is also Hakone Komagatake Ropeway, which goes to the top of Mount Komagatake.
A popular "Hakone Free Pass", allowing unlimited use of most forms of transport for several days, is available. Hakone Free Pass can be bought at Shinjuku Station, Odawara Station, any other chief station along Odakyū Odawara Line, Hakone-Yumoto Station, Gōra Station, any other chief station along Hakone Tozan Line, Sōunzan Station, Tōgendai Station, Sengoku-Annaijo Bus Stop, Moto-Hakone Port, Hakone-Machi Port, and JR Gotemba Station Bus Information.


=== Highways ===
Hakone Shindō
Japan National Route 1
Japan National Route 138


== Education ==
Private schools:

Kanrei Shirayuri Gakuen Junior/Senior High School


== Sister cities ==
 - Tōyako, Hokkaidō, since July 4, 1964
 - Jasper, Alberta, Canada from July 4, 1972
 - Taupo, New Zealand, from October 7, 1987
 - St. Moritz, Switzerland, from November 2, 2014 (Friendship City)

text.wiki:
Hakone (箱根町, Hakone-machi) is a town in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan. As of June 2012, the town had an estimated population of 13,492, and a population density of 145 persons per km². The total area is 92.82 km2 (35.84 sq mi). Hakone has been designated as a Japanese National Geopark by the Japanese Geoparks Network.
Hakone is to a great degree regarded as a traveler destination; Mt. Fuji can be seen when taking a day trip from Tokyo. In addition to hot springs, museums and other recreation activities, Hakone is known for its scenery during all four seasons.


== Geography ==
Hakone is located in the mountains in the far west of the prefecture, on the eastern side of Hakone Pass. Most of the town is within the borders of the volcanically active Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park, centered on Lake Ashi.


=== Surrounding municipalities ===
Kanagawa Prefecture

Odawara
Yugawara
Minami-ashigaraShizuoka Prefecture

Gotemba
Susono
Mishima
Oyama
Kannami


== History ==
Hakone is the location of a noted Shinto shrine, the Hakone Gongen, which is mentioned in Heian period literature. During the Genpei War, Minamoto no Yoritomo prayed at this shrine for victory over his enemies, after his defeat at the Battle of Ishibashiyama, which was fought in neighboring Manazuru. As with the rest of Sagami Province, the area came under the control of the later Hōjō clan of Odawara during the Sengoku period. After the start of the Edo period, Hakone-juku was a post station on the Tōkaidō highway connecting Edo with Kyoto. It was also the site of a major barrier and official checkpoint on the route known as the Hakone Checkpoint (箱根関所, Hakone sekisho), which formed the border of the Kantō region. Under the Tokugawa shogunate, all travellers entering and leaving Edo along the Tōkaidō were stopped here by officials. Their travel permits and baggage were examined to enforce Tokugawa laws that restricted the travel of women and weapons.
After the start of the Meiji Restoration, Hakone became a part of the short-lived Ashigara Prefecture before becoming part of Ashigarashimo District in Kanagawa prefecture in August 1876. Hakone attained town status in 1889. The imperial household established the summer Hakone Imperial Villa close to the lake.
After merger with five neighboring towns and villages in September 1956, it reached its present boundaries.


== Economy ==

The economy of Hakone is strongly dominated by the tourist industry. Hakone is noted for its onsen hot spring resorts, which attract both Japanese and international visitors, due to its proximity to the greater Tokyo metropolis and to Mount Fuji. Sights include the volcanically active Ōwakudani geysers and Hakone Shrine on the shore of the lake, as well as the Hakone Botanical Garden of Wetlands. In April the cherry blossoms (sakura) and in autumn the Miscanthus sinensis (susuki) are noted sights.
Hakone has a number of art museums, including the Hakone Open-Air Museum and Pola Museum of Art.
Major events include the annual JLPGA CAT Ladies Golf tournament and the Hakone Ekiden, a long distance collegiate foot race, held at the New Year, which runs from Tokyo to Hakone and back over two days, partly in commemoration of the couriers who ran the Tōkaidō road.
One famous hotel in Hakone is the historic Fujiya Hotel in Miyanoshita, which was patronized by noted literary figures, politicians and foreign dignitaries in the Meiji and Taishō and early Shōwa periods.
A noted local handicraft is a kind of marquetry called Yosegi.Hakone is also well-known among anime fans for being the main location in the manga and anime series Neon Genesis Evangelion, in which it has been renamed Tokyo-3, and there are numerous attractions related to the franchise offered in the town. In 2017, Hakone was included as one of 88 anime pilgrimage sites for 2018 by the Anime Tourism Association. In 2020, new decorations have been introduced to the city in the anticipation of the release of the final film of the Rebuild of Evangelion tetralogy.


== Transportation ==


=== Railway ===
Hakone Tozan Railway
Hakone Tozan Cable Car
Hakone Ropeway
Izuhakone RailwayOdawara and Mishima, the terminus of the Odakyū Odawara Line, 70 minutes from Shinjuku, Tokyo. From Odawara, the Hakone Tozan Line continues into various resort towns in Hakone. Odakyu also runs the Romancecar limited express between Shinjuku and Hakone-Yumoto. From Gōra, the terminus of Hakone Tozan Line, the Hakone Tozan Cable Car funicular goes to Sōunzan. Ōwakudani can be reached by Hakone Ropeway from Sounzan and the lake, while the lake is crisscrossed by cartoonishly decorated "pirate" ships for tourists. There is also Hakone Komagatake Ropeway, which goes to the top of Mount Komagatake.
A popular "Hakone Free Pass", allowing unlimited use of most forms of transport for several days, is available. Hakone Free Pass can be bought at Shinjuku Station, Odawara Station, any other chief station along Odakyū Odawara Line, Hakone-Yumoto Station, Gōra Station, any other chief station along Hakone Tozan Line, Sōunzan Station, Tōgendai Station, Sengoku-Annaijo Bus Stop, Moto-Hakone Port, Hakone-Machi Port, and JR Gotemba Station Bus Information.


=== Highways ===
Hakone Shindō
Japan National Route 1
Japan National Route 138


== Education ==
Private schools:

Kanrei Shirayuri Gakuen Junior/Senior High School


== Sister cities ==
 - Tōyako, Hokkaidō, since July 4, 1964
 - Jasper, Alberta, Canada from July 4, 1972
 - Taupo, New Zealand, from October 7, 1987
 - St. Moritz, Switzerland, from November 2, 2014 (Friendship City)

Please be aware that there are tens of thousands of shrines in Japan. in  Shrines with structures that are National Treasures of Japan are covered by the List of National Treasures of Japan (shrines). trip: 乙女峠駐車場からは正面に雄大な富士山をおがむことができました。空いているし絶景だし、とてもよかったです。
金時山登山の途中にあります。富士山の絶景写真が撮れます。展望台の向かいに自撮りするための撮影する台があるのは便利でした。
相変わらず、富士山の絶景が望めます。 近くにあった「ふじみ茶屋」 どうやら閉店してしまったようです。 ここで、写真を撮って、ふじみ茶屋で味噌おでんを食べるのが 元日の定番だったのですが、これからどうしよう。 駐車場がないので、困りました。
箱根仙石原から御殿場へ。トンネルを出ると右手に富士山が迎えてくれました。前日の雨のおかげか白さを増した富士山が現れました。朝早いと道路が凍っている恐れがあるので冬季は注意が必要です。
峠の途中に温泉や茶屋などがあり、富士山を真正面から望むことができます。道路自体は箱根～御殿場を結ぶ基幹道路で大型バスなども頻繁に通るので、交通量もそこそこあるがカーブがきつく運転しにくい場所もあり注意が必要です。
富士山が綺麗に見える場所として有名ですが残念ながら雨天のため登山は断念、近くに無料の駐車場があります。
4月に入ったのに、今年は雪となった日が数日ありました。この辺りは積雪しやすい為、車だと要注意です。 乙女峠から金時山に登山でき、ふじみ茶屋さんに駐車できます。乙女峠からの富士山も素晴らしいですが、登山されない方でも『富士松展望レストラン』の駐車場からも裾野まで広がる富士山を撮影できます。

富士山がとても綺麗に見える場所です。 大涌谷の方から車で来ましたが、急に富士山が見えるのです。 そして左手に茶屋があるので急遽立ち寄ることに。 気を抜くと通り過ぎてしまいます。 車道に観光バスが停まり外国の方々が車道で写真を撮っていました。 危ないと思います。 富士山を見るのも、運転も気を付けてください。 茶屋にはお野菜なども販売されています。 ここから金時山にも登れるみたいです。 展望台もあったみたいですが、私たちは登りませんでした。 行けばよかったかな？？ 美しい富士山を見れてとても満足しました。
１１月下旬、乙女口から金時山に登り、その途中で乙女峠を通りました。 頂上までは２時間かからずに登れる手軽が山で、乙女口から乙女峠までは４０分程で上ることができます。 乙女峠には展望台、休憩所があり、展望台からの富士山は最高で、山頂からの富士山より素敵だと思います。 乙女峠から見る富士山は、"乙女富士"と呼ばれるほどの絶景ですよ。
静岡県側富士山が裾野まで綺麗に見える知る人ぞ知る絶景スポット。 乙女峠には富士見茶屋があります。 甘味どころは10時から お食事は11時から。 スタッフのサービスがとても親切！ お土産も売ってます。 お団子やソフトクリームも美味しい。 金時山登山口⛰登山口なので、登山客が立ち寄ります。 富士山の湧き水が無料で汲めるのでペットボトルをご持参ください！ プレミアアウトレットからバスで来られます。
富士山の展望スポットとしてはあまり有名ではありませんが、富士山がきれいに見え、あまり有名ではない展望台です。国道からほんの少しだけ県道に入った所です。
箱根からの帰り道、新宿行きの高速バスに乗車、乙女峠バス停手前で、富士山の素晴らしい景色が見えますとのアナウンス有り、乙女峠のバス停より、素晴らしい富士山の景色が見れた。
箱根側から御殿場に向かう場合は、峠のトンネルを越えた辺りが、抜群の富士山一望スポットです。箱根に行った際は、ドライブがてら足を伸ばすにも良いかも知れません。
箱根へ来たら必ず訪れる場所。 富士山が世界文化遺産に登録されてから５年なので年々日本人だけでなく外国人観光客も増えている。 天気が悪いと富士山に雲がかかってしまうが、良ければ最高。 夜景も綺麗との評判。真向かいに茶屋があるので、一服もできます！
日本人に留まらず、海外の方にもこの地は結構知られた「富士山を左右の裾野まで見渡せる」のがこの地です。
1018年1月に半年ぶりに金時山に行きました 乙女峠以は、前訪れた時周りの樹木が成長しすぎてせっかくの富士があまり見えない状態でした 今回訪れたら眺望を妨げていた枝が切られていて以前の素晴らしい乙女峠に戻っていました 御殿場市役所の方ありがとうございます 峠までの登山道も整備されていて、歩きやすくなっていました
国道１号線の箱根峠から芦ノ湖スカイラインに入り、そのまま箱根スカイラインを通り抜けて県道を進むと、国道１３８号線に突き当たります。国道に突き当たる少し手前に、乙女峠駐車場がありました。 大きな富士山がドーンと見えるはずだった駐車場の端にある展望台からは、富士山はすっぽりと雲に覆われたていました。展望台にあったパネルには、ここから見える特大の富士山が描かれていました。
乙女峠までは行っていません。乙女峠のバス停で降りて数分程度登る場所で景色を見ました。景色は素晴らしく富士山の迫力が伝わる場所でした。バスで冬の時期に行ったのですが行き帰りのバスの時間の下調べが必要です。帰りのバスがすぐなく日も暮れかけて防寒はしていましたがとても寒かったです。
東名高速道路御殿場インターから仙石原への往き帰りに通りました。往きは富士に雲がかかり、茶屋のそばだけを楽しみました。帰りは晴れていて、富士が見えました。下の市街の広がりと相まって、富士見に絶好の位置です。 茶屋の脇をちょっと登ると（近年つくられた）「乙女の鐘」を鳴らせるところがあり、そこからの眺めが一層見事です。
芦ノ湖スカイライン、箱根スカイラインを通り抜け、曲がりくねった県道４０１号線が、まもなく国道１３８号線に合流するところに、乙女峠駐車場がありました。 　駐車場前は開けていて、晴れていれば、そこから真正面に富士山が見えるはずの絶景スポットなんです。私たちが訪れたときは、富士山は完全に雲に隠れていました。芦ノ湖スカイラインを走っているときは、頂上部だけが雲の上に浮かんでいたのに、残念でした。
バスで仙石で降り15分くらい歩き、乙女口から金時山に登りました。乙女口から約40分くらいで乙女峠に着きました。見晴台があり正面に富士山が見えます。 それまでの疲れが一気に吹き飛びそうな素晴らしい眺めです。
トンネルを抜けると晴れていたので富士山の絶景が見えました。景色に妨害するものがないので気にいっています。晴れていたので写真を撮られている方がたくさんいました。
なんといっても天候によって、富士山の眺めが異なります。雲一つない富士や雲が良い具合に掛かっている富士、はたまた雲海の上に頭を出した富士。日頃の行いを占うような気分になります。
乙女峠バス停〜金時山登山途中の休憩ポイント乙女峠。富士山とまちのコラボです。 かわいい展望台もあります。写真はすぐ後ろの展望台から撮るとバッチリですよ〜。
運良く晴れていると富士山が綺麗に見れるスポットが御殿場側にあります。ただし、車が停車しづらいこともあります。
御殿場ICの利用でないとなかなかこっちに来ませんが、ここから見る富士山が箱根で一番きれいだと思います。
御殿場から箱根に上がる絶景ポイントです。富士山が見えれば素晴らしいのですが、この日は雲がかかってしまい、残念でした。

箱根芦ノ湖エリアと御殿場市街を結ぶ国道138号が貫く稜線の上にあるこの峠は富 士山の眺望に優れ、 日本の富士見三つ峠の一つに数えられています。また箱根外輪山の稜線の入口とし ての機能もあり、 ここから金時山や丸岳方面へハイキングコースが伸びています。 峠の上は鬱蒼とした森林地帯となっており、廃屋がひとつ、富士山方面に展望台が あります。 茶店などはなく、少し金時山方面に進んだところにベンチなどがあり休憩できます 。
ここは丁度富士山の真ん前です。富士山が見える時は沢山の人が写真を撮っています。金時山に登る人もここに駐車してから登れます。100円の産直野菜も魅力です。湧水もありますからカラのペットボトルを持って行くと美味しい水が飲めますよ。
「おとめさん」と呼ばれていた娘さんが名前の由来。 金時山の登山途中に寄るかたが多いと思います。 富士山がきれいに見えるポイントで有名ですが、それはお天気次第。
仙石原から乙女トンネルを抜けてすぐ左側の乙女峠のふじみ茶屋からの富士山。これを絶景と言わず何を絶景と言えるか。天気の良い日であれば、この世のものとは思えない素晴らしい光景を見ることができるだろう。
乙女峠にはバスでも行けます。今回は、箱根外輪山をハイキングするために、箱根湯本からバスで乙女峠まで向かいました。トンネルを抜けるとバス停がありますが、皆さんから大きな歓声が沸き起こりました。正面に富士山がはっきりと見えていました。この日は、ここから登り始めて丸岳を経由して桃源台に下りましたが、楽しいハイキングになりました。
乙女峠から、御殿場方面へちょっといたところに「ふじみ茶屋」と言うドライブインがあります。ここから見える富士山は絶景です。 御殿場の市街越しに、大きく裾を広げた富士山が見えます。 多くの方が写真を撮っています。
駐車場がないので、ジックリ見られないのが残念、でもすぐ近くに茶店があるので、そこを利用すればゆっくり楽しめる
国道138号線にある峠です。東名高速道路の御殿場ICから138号線で峠に上がる方法と、箱根を越えてこの峠に行く方法があります。 天気が良い日がお勧めです。時間が遅い場合は、御殿場の街並みの綺麗な夜景が観れます。昼間なら、富士山が見えます。車の場合は、駐車できる場所が限られているのでご注意下さい。
富士山絶景ポイントです。冬の晴天の日でしたら わざわざ行く価値あります。感動の富士山です。駐車場に停めてください。
１１/１３に御殿場から行きました。辺りは紅葉はじまり、富士山は雪をかぶり・・・空気も澄んでまさに絶景！富士山が天空に浮いていました。
道路沿いにおみやげやさんがあります。 そこの駐車場からみる富士山、ふもとまではっきりきれいにみれます。 道路に駐車してみているみている人もいるので注意してください。
金時山へのハイキングで寄りました。展望の台がありましたが霧のため視界はよくありませんでした。霧が晴れたとしても木々にさえぎられて３６０度の景色は望めません。

世界遺産「富士山」が望めるスポット。晴れていれば、わざわざ訪れるだけの価値がある。お弁当を持って出かけるのもよし。
秋の3連休に高速バスで通りました。その日は夜宿に向かうだけで、景色は見えませんでしたが、昼間の晴れた富士山は良いです
金時山への登山時又は下山時に立ち寄ることが有ります。晴れた日は富士山がとてもきれいです。東京で見るのとはスケールが全く違います。乙女峠で富士山が綺麗に見えるときは、更なる絶景ポイントの金時山へ登るに当たり気合いが入ります。
本当なら写真のように美しい富士山を期待していたのですが、全く見えず！次回に期待したいと思います。でも同じ道もつまらないよね。
金時山に登った際、下山途中に立ち寄りました。ふじみ茶屋へと箱根方面へとの分岐点にあります。展望台というか、台があるのですが、訪れた日の天候は曇り。残念ながら富士山は見ることができず雲の中でした。晴れた日に訪れましょう。
毎年箱根駅伝を見るために箱根を訪れていますが、その往復で必ず立ち寄っています。富士山が大きく見える絶景ポイント。私はここからの富士山が最も好きです。

乙女峠の自動車トンネルの上にあるのが、箱根外輪山の乙女峠です もちろん車では訪れることはできません ふじみ茶屋の駐車場に車を停めて金時山に行くときには必ず通過します 以前は、展望台から富士山が見えたのですが、先日訪れたときには木の枝が伸びてしまい富士山の眺望が乙女峠から見えなくなっていました。 箱根側は休息ベンチもあり水蒸気の上がる大涌谷や芦ノ湖の姿がよく見えます 御殿場市の観光担当者の方　この書き込みに気が付いたら少し枝を刈り込んで富士の融資を見せてください

箱根では、いくつか、富士山が見えるポイントがありますが、この乙女峠から見る富士山は、一番雄大さを感じるスポットです。駐車場もあるので、ちょっと、立ち止まって富士山を見るには最高です。ただ、曇りや、雨の日や、霧が出るときも多いので、お天気には要注意です。
御殿場ICから箱根へ向かう途中で偶然立ち寄り。乙女駐車場という観光バスも入れそうな駐車場があります。ここにはお店もありませんが、富士山を真正面から捉えられるビューポイントがあり、富士山をバックに写真が撮れます。
富士山がよく見えるスポットを探していたらここを見つけました。 トンネルを抜けると、小さい茶屋みたいなところがあって、駐車場も無料みたいでした。そこに車を停めると展望台みたいなところがあり、登ってみると（小さいお子さんでもすぐにのぼれます）素晴らしい富士山の絶景が！！ 展望台の上には幸せの鐘？みたいなのもあり、ちょっと鳴らしてみました。 このスポットはオススメです！！

仙石原交差点を乙女峠方向に進むと右側に金時神社があり入り口はゴルフ練習場からと約100m先と2か所あり神社脇に駐車スペースが3～4台無料？ありましたが安全な有料（ゴルフ場）に駐車です。 神社脇からの登山コースは勾配があり険しいが時間短縮の旨の説明がありました。短縮コースでの登山、確かに険しいものでした。山頂では茶屋（小屋）の売店で寛げました。正面に富士山の麓には御殿場の街が広がり見晴らしは抜群です。時折ドーンという音、富士の麓の自衛隊練習場からの音が響いてきましたね。
金時山登山でスタートは公時神社から金時山に登り、頂上から2つの山を縦走し1時間40分ほど乙女峠に下山しました。金時山より眺望はなかったのですが、やっと下ってきた達成感でみる景色は格別でした。ここから10分ほど歩いて公時神社に戻りました
夜の時間帯に箱根方面から138号線を走ってくると、乙女峠のトンネルを抜けてすぐの場所で御殿場市の素晴らしい夜景が見れます。また、晴れた日の明け方には朝日を浴びて赤く染まる「紅富士」もキレイに見えます。
箱根から御殿場へ抜ける途中にあります。トンネルを抜けてすぐのところにお茶屋さんがあり、広めの駐車場もあるので、車を停めて景色を楽しむことができます。お茶屋さんの横に、階段があり、上っていくと鐘があります。そこからの富士山も絶景です。
御殿場方面から登ってくると、トンネルの手前にあるのがふじみ茶屋。その前に「乙女峠」というバス停があります。バスを降りるとそこはナイスビューでした。日が沈んだ直後が最も美しいようです。
乙女峠は御殿場側には富士山の絶景が見えますが、箱根側の景色が見渡せません。少し道をそれて鎌倉往還に入ると長尾峠が有ります。ここからは眼下に仙石原、芦ノ湖、蒸気が噴出している大涌谷を見ることが出来ます。
明るいうちは富士山、夜なら御殿場の夜景が素晴らしい！ワインディングロードなので、景色に見とれて事故など起こさぬように、ちゃんと駐車場に車を停めて景色を楽しんでくださいね。
金時山から１５分位歩いて行った所に乙女峠があります。富士山が大きく正面に見えて素晴らしかったです。乙女峠という名前にはとても悲しい話の説明看板があり驚きました。
偶然かもしれませんが、仙石原から御殿場に下るカーブの途中でくっきりと富士山を眺めることができました。天気の良い日はカメラを車窓から構えておいてください。藪があったりするので、長い時間ではありませんのでご注意を。
昔から富士山が綺麗に見れる峠として有名。1時間程度で気軽にハイキングできるのも良い。夕陽や夜景もきれい。富士八景の湯近くにある乙女駐車場は無料駐車場。ここのパッピーコールベルを鳴らすと幸せになれるとか。
箱根外輪山周回トレイルに挑戦した時に通過しました。金時山から下っていく、走って20分歩いて30分くらいのところ。休憩場があって、仙石原方面を見ながら、休むことができる。私が通った時は霧があって、あまりよく見えなかった。
朝６時に行きました。朝陽に輝く富士を見たくて，日の出とともにカメラを構えました。少し蒸気があがってきた霞んでしまい，ちょっと残念でした。それでも裾野からはっきり見えるので絵になります。おすすめの場所です。
御殿場プレミアムアウトレットでお買い物をしてから箱根で一泊、というプランの場合、この峠を通るかと思います。 お買い物に夢中になりすぎて暗くなってからの運転はとにかく心細く、道も細いので細心の注意が必要です。 お気をつけて！
家族三人で強羅温泉にいきました。宿の案内で乙女峠に行って来ました。宿から車で１５分の所です。生まれて初めてこんな綺麗な富士山を観ました。三月末でしたが東京の冬支度でちょうどよかったです。ここの『ふじみ茶屋』さんのみそおでん、みたらしだんご、も美味しかったです。桜の咲いた頃にまた行きます。
リロバケーション箱根で1泊して、御台場アウトレットに向かう途中で素晴らしい富士山に出会うことができました。途中いたるところで富士山じさんの絶景が望めますので、運転に要注意です。
御殿場と箱根を結ぶ峠で、晴れた日に木々の間から雄大な富士山が見えます。週末の昼は「ふじみ茶屋」に車があふれ、そこから富士山のビュースポットである車線の反対側まで歩いて渡る人が多いため、運転者は注意が必要です。また、箱根から御殿場に向かう際は下り坂がややきついので、ここにも注意が必要です。
家族４人で仙石原に１泊しました。御殿場アウトレットに寄ってから、乙女峠を通りました。途中「チェーン装着」の表示が２度ありましたが、路面は乾いており、結局、その必要はなく無事通過できました。
御殿場アウトレットに行く途中に寄りました。 雲一つない、いいお天気だったので、尾根のほうまできれいに見れました！ さすが人気のビュースポットだけありますね。 最高の眺めでした(*´▽｀*) ちなみに、車はふじみ茶屋の駐車場にとめられますが、小さいのですぐ満車になります。 お天気のいい時はとくに混み合うようで、お茶屋での食事も待ち時間が長いです。
「ふじみ茶屋」近辺は、このあたりで、唯一といえるほど富士山がキレイにみえる場所 加えて、このお茶屋は、新鮮な野菜が格安で買えることができ、ちょっと楽しい場所です
金時山に登るために、新宿から高速バスで乙女峠に行きました。休日で紅葉シーズンは予約必須です。乙女峠近くのふじみ茶屋はお団子150円でお茶付。とてもおいしかったのでおすすめです。ふじみ茶屋からの富士山の景色は絶景です。
富士山が見えるビューポイントめぐりで立ち寄りました。 「ふじみ茶屋駐車場」以外でも、車が止められれば、いろいろな角度で富士山を楽しめます。
最近は、日帰り温泉施設がオープンして底からの景色も魅力と思いますが、もともとは箱根からクルマで御殿場に下ってくると、ずっと富士山と御殿場市街が見えるという景色のいいドライブルートです。冬は富士山に積もる雪が多くて、いい景色とはなりませんが、それ以外の時期はなかなかきれいなものです。

トンネル出口周辺は茶屋や駐車場、バス停がありますがココは乙女峠ではありません。 乙女峠や金時山への登山口です。 （茶屋では野菜や果実も販売されていました） 正しくは20分くらい登山した場所が「乙女峠」です。 本当の乙女峠は足柄峠、長尾峠と並ぶ富士見三峠のひとつで、御殿場と富士山の眺望が素晴らしいです。 （バス停付近でも富士山の眺望は良いですが） お天気と富士山の具合を確認してから訪問してください！

乙女峠と言えば富士山の眺めが良いスポットとして有名です。箱根ドライブの際にこちらを目指すのであれば、目的地は「ふじみ茶屋駐車場」になります。ここに車を停めて富士山を眺めるだけでも十分な観光になりますが、湧き水が出ていたり、少し上に上がったところに、乙女の鐘という名所があったりと、見どころがそれなりにあります。乙女の鐘のスポットは、鐘自体は思ったより小さ目で、「あ～なるほどね」の一言で終ってしまいそうな感じですが、駐車場よりもさらに高い位置になりますので、富士山の眺望目的でぜひ上がられることをおすすめします。
箱根裏街道を御殿場方面へすすみ、乙女道路（トンネル）を抜けた場所が乙女峠。ちょうど静岡県との境です。峠のバス停前には広い駐車場とふじみ茶屋がありましたが、休業中のようで閑散としていました。幸せを呼ぶ乙女の鐘もあり、富士山をのぞむ絶景ポイントでもありますが、訪れた際は春の煙霧シーズンで未透視が悪く絶景には出会えませんでした。オンシーズンに再訪したいです。

富士山が上から下まで本当に綺麗に見えます。 駐車場は狭いですが写真撮影にはもってこいの場所ですし、簡単なお土産物や野菜の販売、お茶屋もあります。 トイレはお茶屋の中にありトイレだけ借りるのが気がひけます。なのでトイレだけの人はお茶屋のある富士見茶屋ではなくその先にあるさびれたススキ茶屋でトイレ休憩する人が多いみたいです。 また金時山などにハイキングに行くのにもいい場所みたいでトレッキングの格好をしている人がたくさんいます。 中央道から箱根に向かう人はぜひこちらの峠からの富士山を！！

１日乗り放題のチケットがあり、仙石原から１０分ぐらいで「晴れていると富士山が見えますよ」と口コミで、バスから見ました。 御殿場アウトレット行きに乗ると通ります。（*_*） 峠を越えるとなんと！　　静岡県だそうで・・・・・・！ 地理が解りにくい関西人びっくり！ 美術館めぐりの合間にロープーウェイに乗らずして、富士を見に行きましたが、あいにく曇っていて見えず（* _ * ；）　残念！ このあたりが一番高い高原でここから山を下っていきました。 乗り放題なので冒険し行ってみました。 あっとゆうまに通り過ぎてしまいますが、富士が見えると良かったのになあ。。。
東富士の正面に位置する箱根の峠です。天気の良い日は雄大な富士山が正面に位置します。夜は御殿場の夜景がきれいです。

箱根の帰りはいつも国道１３８号線から乙女峠を通り御殿場Ｉ・Ｃに向かいます。 東京方面へは遠回りにはなりますが、芦ノ湖周辺や大涌谷や仙石原などに立ち寄りながら、最後に乙女峠からの富士山を眺めるといった具合です。 しかし今回梅雨のシーズンで標高の高いところは霧が１日中濃く、富士山はもちろん、 芦ノ湖も向こう岸が全く見えなかったので残念でした毎年この状態とのことなので この時期の箱根観光には注意が必要です。紫陽花はきれいでしたけど。
金時山に登った際、帰りに立ち寄りました。 お茶屋さんには立ち寄りませんでしたが、富士山がすそまできれいに見えます。 気軽に来れるということで軽装の観光客がたくさんいました。
国道138号を走ると、やがて乙女峠に辿り着く。近くに「ふじみ茶屋」なる蕎麦屋がある。そばは、値段が高かったのでやめにして、富士の絶景を楽しんだ。 見晴らしは最高。ただ、そばは、ざるそばで820円は、高く食べる気はしない。 ここは、景色だけの評価。

My bf and I just rented a private hot bath here. It's so nice and peaceful. We had our own room with the hot bath,towels,shampoo and conditioner,brush,hair ties and lotion. And there was a mini refrigerator in the room too. It was perfect! Bring water and snacks. Otherwise you

As I understand and respect that tattoos might offend other visitors or make them feel uncomfortable, we were willing to pay significant extra bucks on a private onsen. On the phone already, we were asked if we have any tattoos. I asked „would that a problem in a private

I discovered Onsen when I visited Japan 5 yrs ago and fell in love then. When I knew I was returning it was on the list to do again . This place is lovely - I didn't allow long enough - you need 2 hrs or more if you want to eat as I did. Don't be put off by having to be naked.

We booked a private bath for 1 hour, followed by a 1 hour massage. Both were so relaxing and exactly what we needed after days of travelling and so much walking. There's a free shuttle bus from Hakone yumoto Station, so getting there is easy!

I visited out of season and was lucky enough to almost have the public baths to myself. There are a series of 7 or so hot baths to use as well as a sauna. The setting is breathtaking - it’s on the side of a mountain in a forest with views of trees and mountains and the sound of

We booked the biggest private room with private bath of the onsen. The service was amazing, we had everything we needed and more: yukata, towels, hairdryer, body lotion, shampoo, conditioner, body cream, a small portable comb, sweets etc. We had an openair bathtub with a view
Experienced Japanese onsen service without the need to stay overnight. Both public and private onsen were great.

We loved Yuryo Onsen! Bath : The scenary is very nice. You kind of feel alone in the nature. The decor was perfect, the smells, the vibe and the cleanliness! Don't forget, swimsuits are forbidden (hense enjoy it naked! :) and tattoos are also prohibited. ***Only TIP for the

I went to Hakone yuryo the other day as I always do when I visit japan and was enjoying the bath in the forest and the roru sauna service when a tenant came up to me while I’m naked and escorted me out for having a tiny tattoo on my ankle. I covered it with a band aid and asked

Very beautiful onsen, easily accessible via a FREE shuttle from Hakone-Yumoto station(every 15 minutes). The staff were friendly and spoke english very well. Additionally they were responsive over email (replying within 1 day) and accommodating regarding us arriving 10 miuntes

I have to say I love the big city feeling at Tokyo. But after a trip to Tokyo and Kyoto trying to see everything and experience everything I can get my hands on a relaxing day is at hand in this beautiful onsen. This hot springs are just perfect for a day trip to relax.

Frequent private shuttle took us straight to Hakone Yuryo. From there, checkin was very easy, and staff very friendly. Our room was beautifully laid out and clean. Had a wonderful relaxing time dipping in and out of the onsen. Finished the experience off at their restaurant

My boyfriend and I rented a type 2 private onsen for an hour, and had a very relaxing time. You get a little room attached to the onsen so there’s a place to change and take breaks from the heat. We got lunch at the restaurant afterward, which was fun (you cook on the charcoal

We reserved a private onsen type three for three people but two more persons would also fit inside the onsen. The onsen is beautiful but one hour is too long to soak in 40 Celsius degrees water. You can stand maybe 15 minutes and then take a cold shower and then dip in for
Incredible private onsens. Such a relaxing environment, friendly staff, clean, with air conditioned rooms.

Had an amazing experience at Hakone Yuryo, absolutely stunning onsen in an incredibly relaxing forest environment. Clean, friendly and fantastic value for money. We went for a package that included food- which was absolutely delicious. They also offer a shuttle bus to and from

This is a great introduction to a casual onsen in Japan. This place hosts nothing special but it is well maintained, a great value, and convenient. Great as a day trip from Tokyo or a stop on your way to Kyoto or Osaka.

Where do I start, OMG this place blows my mind, we arrived at opening time (10am) Beautiful scenic setting on the foot of the hills/mountain. Very close to the station . The staff greeted us at the entrance door, very polite and professional. We booked a private room,

Beautiful tranquil spot with clean facilities and friendly staff. Entrance = $14 USD. massage treatments available and a resturant on site. Well worth the experience - one of the things in Japan that’s cheaper and nicer than North America. Birthday suits only - you’ll get over

text.quote: Small village in a scenic setting with 8 ponds, views of Mt. Fuji & vendors of food & souvenirs.
trip: Tons of china tourists. Its like a mini chinatown. Many tourist Vans or mini bus. So expect this place to be flooded with tourists. Good to visit if you wish to try some japanese street food.

Oshino Hakkai is basically a small village in the Mt. Fuji area. The main attraction of the place is the eight ponds with crystal clear water from the Mt. Fuji's melting snow. Looking at these ponds with their own freshwater plants and fish brings serenity and comfortable
They have pools of water believed to be sourced from snow melts from Mt Fuji. A gathering point for tourists with souvenir shops and food stalls.

It was very cold when we went, and the road a bit slippery, but we drove from Tokyo and arrived about 1h40min at Oshino Hakkai. There is a museum which costs 300yen and you feed the money into a machine and choose the number of persons you need to buy for. Be careful though,

Far from a Must see location. Though still a lovely spot. Somewhat overrated; though got some nice spots from which you can get a view on the ponds with Mt Fuji in the background. The Sakura added a nice touch during our visit.

Quaint little villiage along the Mt fuji perimeter. Beautiful views all around. Lots of food stalls with local delicacies. definitely worth to extra bus ride from Kawaguchiko station. I would recommend the Houtou noodle making class at one of the local hotels.

Sunny winters at, crystal clear volcanic water ponds, lots of little shops selling all kinds of local Japanese food and arts/crafts. Stunning backdrop of the amount Fuji can be clearly seen from different angles!
Not a very big place. But is nice with local snacks and fruits. Nice scenery. Very touristy place. Can be very crowded.
Visited last November and got a bit disappointed as the place is not that maintained anymore. Small ponds in different areas of the place. Not that spectacular though.

This is no doubt was one of the most memorable place I've ever seen. As I was told by our tour guide, this place has a total 8 ponds. But too bad I only had the chance to see 2 since our tour time is limited. Oshino Hakkai is a small village that is also most like a touristy

The draw of this tourist-skewed village is its 9 crystal-clear ponds. But the huge crowds on the day of our visit stopped us from seriously going round to find all 9 ponds. What was really great (to us foodies) were the many street stalls selling delicious local delights such as

The Oshino area was very holly place, once upon a time.Nowadays,it became a "tourist trap".Actually, there are a lot of things to do here.Regarding Mt.Fuji, we can't always see it.When I visited here, Mt.Fuji was covered with clouds.It depends on weather if we can enjoy the

We arrived by bus and had a fairly long walk to the ponds. It is a flat and easy walk and quite pleasant. As typical in Japan most of the route is lined with small shops/stalls offering all types of things, especially freshly cooked food. I wish I'd not had lunch before the
The main pond was amazing. I felt like staring at it for a long time. The water's so clear and beautiful. I just felt that this place has become too touristy and that made me feel sad.

Interesting to see the spring water bubbling through the bottom of one of the ponds. The water is crystal clear, really cold and drinkable - we filled our water bottles. The yellow & blue colored rainbow trout in the central pond were a surprise. The thatch roof homesteads &

Took around 30 minutes to get here from Kawaguchiko Station by regular bus. You have to walk for a bit from the bus stop to reach the place, or just follow where most people go. This small village is really peaceful and the ponds are really clear that you can see the bottom of
Nice place even when it is not hot. We had a cloudy day and unfortunately we could not seen a lot of Mt Fuji. But the ponds are impressive as well
Saw lovely views of the place online but was disappointed with the bus loads of tourists. Overcrowded, probably shouldn't have gone there on a Sat afternoon.

Magnificent view with Mt.Fuji at the back. Not many eatery but the awesome village feel is awesome. The village is located between Lake Kawaguchiko and Lake Yamanakako and it’s a popular tourist spot.
I happened to visit as its along the way for my next destination, its world heritage definitely worth a drop by, will be nice stroll if not for the many tour groups and tourists present there.

We stopped here during our trip to Mt.Fuji. It was a crowded tourist spot. This is an attractive small village with ponds, water wheel and many souvenir shops. Can have a walk from the vehicle park into the village where you may enjoy verities of street food. See my pictures how

Many loud tourists on the streets and in restaurants. Toilets are a mess due to large crowds. None of the stalls was particularly interesting. I would not recommend this place for shopping or eating or a special stop-over. If you are passing-by, come and have a look. Maybe you

It is within a small village converted in a tourist attractions with restaurants, shops selling local delicacies and a small museum. Takes about 25 minutes drive from Fuji area and there are ample car park space. Takes about 5-10 minutes walk from the car park to the village
Amazing place close to Mount Fuji with "miracle" water to lead to a longer life Surrounded by little eateries with delicious food
Oshino Hakkai was a stop over during our Mt.Fuji tour from Tokyo. It is a small village with eight ponds, water wheels, nice houses, souvenir shops and food stalls.

This is a good place to visit if you are staying in Tokyo and want something natural with a nice view of Mount Fuji. The eight ponds there with water that flows down from Mount Fuji is very nice to look at and relax in. And if you are fortunate that day to have Mount Fuji

The Magic Moments, Enjoying The Beauty Of Nature ☺️ Oshino Hakkai (忍野八海) is a touristy set of eight ponds in Oshino, a small village in the Fuji Five Lake region, located between Lake Kawaguchiko and Lake Yamanakako on the site of a former sixth lake that dried out several
So many people. Many little shops I don’t think even selling authentic food. Not much to see. Not impressed. We left after 10’ walking around.

I visited Oshino Hakkai (self-drive from Kawaguchiko, Yamanashi) on 14 Feb 2019. As I arrived just after sunrise, the place was almost empty of other tourists. Visitors can experience the serenity, zen of this place. The man-made lakes are filled with crystal clear spring water

Close view of Mt Fuji, with access to drinkable from Fuji. HAKKAI is one of the world heritage sites in Japan. But this place is crowded! Travelling with small children, there are much attractions at HAKKAI except pond with large fishes. I guess it's a good to drop by place

A must visit place if you are to go to Mt. Fuji. Crystal clear waters & well maintained traditional buildings. Mt. Fuji can be viewed from here on a clear sky. Short visit of 1 hour is more than enough.

Once a place of pilgrimage for practitioners of Fujiko (Mt Fuji pilgrims), the Oshino Hakkai Springs were designated as a Japanese Natural Monument in 1934 and in 1985 designated as one of the 100 Exquisite and Well-conserved waters by the Japanese Environmental agency. The 8

Hmm... some nice idyllic photos to be gotten from this place. However, this will most likely involve jostling around with a crowd of tourists. Honestly, you'll probably get clearer shots of Mt Fuji from one of the lakes around the area (without unwanted people in the frame).

Think there were 8 ponds. Apart from history of the ponds beginning from the pilgrimage of monks who dip into the extreme cold water of the ponds there are no other spots to see. Oh yes you can have a good view of Mt Fuji when skies are clear.

A place with crystal clear lake. Very crowded with tourists. Can do some gift shopping here. There are two areas where we could collect Mt Fuji water without any costs. Please observe hygiene when collecting the water. I saw tourists drinking directly from the ladle which was a

Our third stop was a small town in the Mt Fuji area which was apparently a lake before an eruption occured which completely made the lake liveable. Oshino Hakkai is a touristy set of eight ponds in Oshino, a small village in the Fuji Five Lake region, on the site of a former

Oshino Hakkai located in Fuji Five Lakes region is a small village with 8 ponds of filled spring water from underground water reservoir filtered through volcanic lavas. The purity of spring water is highly rated. Oshino Hakkai also showcases the thatched roof farm houses

This place used to be one of the lake at mount Fuji but unfortunately it has dried up and now is only pond. The water is very clear with some big fish inside and it is believe if you drink the water from here you will be younger by 10 years.

If you like to visit a place with tonnes of people then Oshino Hakkai is probably the place for you. No doubt the scenery is beautiful and the 8 different ponds make for good photo spots but the amount of tourists just takes away all the beauty that this place has to offer.

The water is clear. If you are going to visit this place bring a drinking container with you so you can fill it up with refreshing spring water. They sell peach green tea, hankerchiefs and seaweeds that are not found in central tokyo. Try the seaweeds it tastes different. They

We were lucky to come to thid world heritage sights, the Oshino Hakkai Spring. The water bodys is so clean, coming the Mt. Fuji and passing thru the roack formations in this volcano making it one of the best tasting natural clean water in Japan. Part of the world heritage sights

Very pretty place, but there was a ton of people. Lots of tour groups and student field trips so you’ll have to kinda push your way around. No good views of Mt Fuji from the ground here. There was a tiny roof you could climb up to near the entrance for supposedly a “better”
oshino hakai is a part of mount fuji world heritage, this place so ancient, like back to the old era of japan,

Peaceful Japanese village with specific old house and gardens. My favorite area is the lake in the center with cold water and many colorful Koi fishes. Should spend at least 2 hour there to enjoy a relaxing walking around.

I went with a tour group and it was a nice day. We had a little walk from the bus to get there. When we got there, there was lots of people so we had to wait for the other tour group to move before we could look at the pond. We got to see the fish but it was very hard to hear

I like this place, fresh air, nice scenery, pool with very clear water & many sell fresh fruits original from mount fuji like apple & grapes. Recommended place.. If you holiday in Tokyo, don’t forget to go to Oshino Hakkai, only take 2 hours by bus from Tokyo to here
The pond is mesmerising with the beautiful koi fish but was rather busy with people pushing to get past you.

Beautiful walk around a few ponds full of carp and trout and crystal clear water flowing from underground springs where the water has resided up to 20 years originating as melted snow from Fuji san. A little bit commercial but carp diem for a place catering mainly to Tourists

We came here early around 10am and it was relatively quiet and we got to walk around in peace to check out most of the ponds and shops. Around 11 the big tour groups started to arrive and it was pretty noisy and crowded. I'd definitely recommend coming here but try as early or

If you wish to see Mr.Fuji clearly, I suggest you to check the weather and visit the village on the sunny day. You will enjoy the best view of Mt.Fuji while enjoying the calm and peace atmosphere of the neighborhood. Along the way, there will be the street food you can taste and

It was a small village with ponds. The water of tge ponds are very clear and portable. Was told that the water if tge ponds are fed by snow melt from the slopes of nearby Mount Fuji that filters down the mountain through porous layers of lava for over 80 years. There are also

Visited this place for the third time with a new set of friends....water of the pond is real clean with ple ty of fishes.. A little far but you won't get tired watching the amazing fishes, its clean surrounding... Added bonus is the appearance of Mt Fuji unexpectedly...like what

The minute we arrived at Oshino Hakkai village we headed to collect the spring water which is considered one of the best spring water in Japan. The story/myth behind this spring water is that one emperor from China has directed his men to find the elixir of life and it was

It was a disappointment. I've seen pictures of crystal clear blue water of Oshino Hakkai but it was not that clear during my visit. The water are murky. You still can see fishes swimming. Not worth the visit as it looks like an ordinary pond. Maybe this is not the season for

We visited Oshino village on a mission, to fill our water bottles with water tgat is said fir one drop of this precious commodity to take 50 years from Fuji to reach this place. There are a couple of ponds with clear, clean water which houses salmon type colourful fush. Plenty

This is a great little town. Not far away from Lake Kawaguchi and there is no entry fee. It’s very peaceful and nice town to walk around if you have some time. It may take about 2-3 hours to walk around the whole site. And you can see the Mt. Fuji if you are lucky.

Around 30mins from kawaguchi lake, oshino hakkai offers 8 crystal clear ponds and very traditional Japanese houses. A lot of soveniers shops and local delicacys to be tasted here. Do spend 300yen and visit the museum.

My family came here to see Mount Fuji and we had the prettiest view. There was a little spring with fresh cold water. We were only here for a little while but it was beautiful. There’s also a lot of stalls to check out as well around the area. There were quite a few tourists
Very pretty, the water was nice and a lot of cool little shops. I was only there for 30 minutes and I wish I was there a bit longer, but i managed to see most of it.

A very popular spot. Take some empty water bottles, so you can enjoy the taste of fresh pure water filtered through the earth. Plenty of side stalls for something to eat. Take a walk through the local village and enjoy the sights of the snow and Mt Fuji.
A delightful hour or so at these spring water pools. Pretty busy but not horrendous Several shops selling tat and touristy stuff but the more interesting stalls and food are on the side streets

One of the World heritage cites in Japan, this village provides unique experience of Japanese village, art and culture of old time. So beautiful, nice landscaping with clean water ponds, and the warm welcoming form the villagers are unbeatable experiences for me.
It’s very beautiful in wintertime, there are people living around the heritage, this is a bit unusual. Mt Fuji as background make the whole place very serene!

Visited Oshino Hakkai on our Mount Fuji day tour from Tokyo. With fabulous views of the mountain it really was a perfect day. It would have been nice to have spent a bit more time wandering and admiring lakes which many stories to go with them. It was a lovely spot, but very

Our tour group covered this place called Oshino Hakkai, the eight sacred ponds in the small village of Oshino. The spring water in the ponds originates from Mount Fuji. On the way to this place, Mount Fuji can be seen from different directions that we went. A nice place to take

We visited the small village of Oshino Hakkai mid-morning during the first week of July. We mainly went to take a picture of the thatched roofs with Mt. Fuji in the background, but we were surprised to have so much fun finding all of the eight sacred spring water ponds as well!
Nice place to spend a couple of hours. Too many tourists that come in busloads. Must try the street food.

this was the 2nd stop of our Mt Fuji tour. very charming little place with lots of scenic views (and tourists too!) there are several eateries, a small shopping department and various home owned shops. the beauty and peacefulness of the place is defined by the many ponds,

We stayed for about 2 hours including lunch. A very touristy place with lots of people but the clarity of the water makes this place pretty special. It's just attractive in a unique way. Lots of restaurants, shops and you won't get bored!

Oshino Hakkai is a tourist attraction in a small village in the Fuji Five Lake region, located between Lake Kawaguchiko and Lake Yamanakako on the site of a former sixth lake that dried out several hundred years ago. There are eight ponds fed by snow melt from the slopes of

A nice small village but it was raining so we couldn't see Mount Fuji. There are plenty of food booths and shops. We tried the tofu that is made from their spring water, it was nice and smooth. We ordered the pan-fried fish but we weren't thrilled because it was overcooked thus

This is a lovely location with several ponds brimful with huge fish, and a fountain dispensing water from Mount Fuji. Of course there are the obligatory sculptured trees everywhere too. But of course there is a price to pay and that is to walk past and through gazillions of

It was raining on the day we visited Fuji mount so we decided to see five lakes and Oshino Hakkai. This village is Unesco site and dated back 1200 year old. There are nice traditional old Japanese houses. You can find clear and beautiful ponds with many fishes. Shops are arounds

We visited on a rainy day, so no view on Fuji san, but still enjoyed Oshino. Ponds with super Chrystal clear water, trouts in amazing colors inside!! Nice traditional Japanese buildings, not for tourists only, real families live here too. So daily life is seen. Also the
Beautiful and natural scenery surrounding with local farm and village but its so crowded with Chinese group on the day we went.

On the way back from Mt Fuji we stop here. Lovely clear ponds and some have attained the high status of UNESCO heritage site. ...I think if I remember correctly. Usual tourist shops are around. But recommended as it is indeed a cool place and deep ponds for good reflection...

Oshino Hakkai are a set of eight sacred ponds. The ponds are filled with water filtered through the lava rock of Mount Fuji for over 70 years before appearing here. Its not like a park as it is an open village. You can walk to all eight ponds, one is around 15 minutes away from

We can't to the village to see the ponds; I don't thin you can see all 8, maybe 6? It's a traditional style village set up mostly for tourists ; they try to sell pretty much everything and some don't allow photos! The ponds are interesting enough, but the one we liked the most

This was originally not on our itinerary but I am so grateful we went. Against the back drop of Mt Fuji is a quaint village of yesteryears that is postcard scenery. The outside area is crowded as there is no admission cost. You can catch a good view and capture very beautiful
It is a beautiful clear water lake where we can see the bottom of the lake which is 8 meter deep. There is also a shop beside where we can taste nice taufu and buy local products.

This was one of the stops from our Fuji tour and the highlight of my day. You have Mount Fuji in the background, Eight Koi ponds, beautiful picturesque houses and flower gardens, and, street food for sale all around the village. This is a must visit when you go to Mount Fuji!

We go there end of March & see the whole place covered in snow. Can't manage to cover the whole place due to snow covered road. Warm Fish Tofu on a cold day is a plus. Lots of Japanese pickles to bring back home 😅

Easily accessible by local bus from Kawaguchiko station. The village has 8 small ponds with crystal-clear waters. Apparently these water origins from the molten snow of Mount Fuji. There are also shops selling souvenirs and stalls selling street snack and strawberries. Trust me,

From the bus parking area, we had to walk for hundreds meters to reach this place. There were some ponds where natural springs gave nice natural views. There were also a food market and some food stalls around.

We stopped in at Oshino Hakkai on the way from Fujiyoshida to Lake Yamanaka. It is a really beautiful little village and you get a great view of Mt Fuji. The clear water ponds filled from the snow that melts off the slops surrounding Mount Fuji contain beautiful colour fish

Lucky to have a crystal day. In Oshino Hakkai Springs, you could find free parking lot, lots of shops for tourist. However, the ponds were too clear and fun to miss them. Fishes were visible! We spent here around 1-2 hours with lunch.

I was lucky to visit on a clear day, so I had amazing views of Mt Fuji. The ponds were crystal clear which added to the serenity of the village. There are lots of little stalls selling a variety of Japanese snacks and foods.
Oshino is very famous for its beautiful water of Mt. Fuji. Also you can enjoy Japanese Soba noodles, or Tohu both needs good water. 忍野八海は富士山の湧き水で有名で、美味しい水を使った蕎麦や豆腐も食べられます。 透き通った水を覗くと、川魚の姿も。

We were lucky with a crystal clear day, blue skies but cold and crisp with snow capped Mt Fuji looming over this charming and photogenic village. There are lots of (quite expensive) shops catering for the bus loads of (mainly Chinese it seemed) tourists but the spiritual ponds
Cool place to visit if in the area. You can drink the natural water which is actually very good. Nice to shops to visit as well for gifts and souvenirs.

The water of the pond was really clear and I can clearly see the fishes swimming inside the pond. I wonder whether it's trouts or salmon inside the pond. There are souvenir shops scattered around the area and some really nice structure like the water mill.

Lots of shops catering for tourist. However the village is clean and good for photographs. On a clear day, we were told that Mount Fuji is visible but unfortunately not on the day we visited with a tour group. Good place to visit as part of the Mount Fuji tour.

We were supposed to go to the 5th station of Fuji-sama but bad weather prevented us from proceeding. Our tour guides thus diverted us to this UNESCO Heritage site instead. Beyond the souvenir shops, crystal clear water, crisp mountain air and mouth watering "village-street

More tourists than nature. If you are frequent traveller & been to Japan several times, you won't find this place interesting at all, at least not me. Wish I have skipped this place & spend the time for other area in Fuji Five Lake as lots to see & can't finish in a day!

The place consists of eight ponds of different shape and sizes, separated by narrow pathways. The water come from the snow and underwater of Mt Fuji and the place has become part of World Heritage. It has become a very famous tourist attraction over the years. A quiet stroll in

Oshino Hakkai is one of the most famous attractions in Japan. There are several springs and water flows out from the springs. According the local, the water come from the snow on the Mount Fuji. Visitors are free to take and drink the water. The water is cool and clean, tasting
The area is not big but there are a few ponds around there. The water is very clean and clear. There are shops around that area selling food and Japanese products.
